Review title: This isn't a perfect movie but it's an entertaining and a horror Mt. Rushmore series
Review_body: Friday the 13th (1980) is a movie I recently watched out of the personal collection. The storyline focuses on a group of camp counselors trying to reopen a campground for the first time since a boy named Jason drowned at the camp. Little do camp counselors know the lake is cursed and they are about to be hunted. This movie is directed by Sean S. Cunningham (DeepStar Six) who produced but surprisingly didn't direct any additional Friday the 13th pictures. This movie stars Kevin Bacon (Tremors and everything else), Betsy Palmer (Penny Dreadful), Adrienne King (The Good Son), Mark Nelson (The Good Wife) and Robbi Morgan (The Great Outdoors. The storyline for this picture and kill scenes are of course so fun. The soundtrack is epic and absolutely brilliant very much in Jaws fashion which worked so well for this genre. Yes, there's some campy cheesy slasher lines and sequences, but that's what makes the classic slasher films great. This film has so much appreciated rewatchability. This isn't a perfect movie but it's an entertaining and a horror Mt. Rushmore series. I'd score this a better than solid 7/10.

Review title: Charmingly Hokey and Gratuitous, the 80s Slasher Boom Really Took Hold Here
Review_body: An early entry in the '80s blood-n-guts slasher boom, the first Friday checks a broad number of boxes: gratuitous amounts of gore, hormone-driven teen victims, secluded setting, mysteriously prophetic locals... even a quick flash of skin. In many ways, it's also a bridge from the clunkier horror flicks of the preceding decade. The effects are often laughable, the acting is paper-thin and the production values seem extremely cheap and dated. Very few of the characters are even remotely likable, either, which makes their relentless slaughter into something of a spectator sport. Once it ditches the vague premonitions and hammy teenage dialog that flood the first act, the film settles into a nice groove: stalk, scare, chase, kill, repeat. The mainstream success of Jason as a horror icon even gives this first entry a little boost, misleading first-time viewers into a surprise reveal at the climax (and, of course, an infamous jump-scare just before the credits). From a critical perspective it's not good, but lasting influence and dogged determination carry it a long way.

As Lisa said to part "Back then people were easier to scare""Oh, like Friday the 13th part one."And he was right. There are some amazing horror movies above a certain age. Ever seen Nosferatu? It has it's moments.But I had built up how gory this would be in my head way too high. Nothing happens for so long. It's not a slow burner, it's not building atmotphere. It's 90% bland youths and 10% anything close to what I thought a slasher was supposed to be.

Review title: Generally creepy and suspenseful, but it's held back by dumb plotting and an atrocious final act
Review_body: The basic premise here focuses on a group of teenagers who are stalked whilst staying at Camp Crystal Lake. The sight is referred to by some locals as 'Camp Blood' due to the many mysterious deaths that have occurred there over the years. However, these teenagers are unfazed and choose to ignore warnings from the locals and decide to stay there and try and re-open Camp Crystal Lake.The early stages of the film are OK and it doesn't take long to gather momentum. It's also clear that director Sean Cunningham is trying to ape Spielberg in terms of his approach here - we get lots of tight close up shots of the killer, but their identity is kept a secret for most of the running time. Cunningham does well to keep you interested in what's happening and when the inevitable killings start they are all quite well-staged (with Kevin Bacon's death being both memorable and surprising). I also liked the way that clichéd jump scares were kept to a minimum and the real hook here is wondering when and how the killer is going to off each of the teenagers. It's never really a brilliant film, but it is quite effective in what it does. I also liked the way that the story is set up in that everyone warns the teenagers about the bad things that have happened at Camp Crystal Lake and the teenagers refusing to believe it. This very much falls back on 'teenagers knowing best' and all adults are wrong and this element of the story is probably one of the more believable aspects. Anyway enough with the praise, let's look at some problems.....Well for a start, I found it hard to believe that a summer camp area would be allowed to be re-opened after several deaths have taken place there over the years. Logically, it would remain closed for the public's safety until such time as evidence would have been gathered to try and find the perpetrator's identity. Further evidence that this film isn't grounded in reality comes with the way that all the teens are picked off one by one with no-one noticing anything is wrong till there's only one or two of them are left. The first girl gets killed and no-one even notices she's missing or wonders where she is; the killer offs the protagonists in a violent and noisy manner, but no-one hears anything; the killer enters and exits the house without anyone noticing.Despite these problems, the film generally remained enjoyable and I thought as I watched it 'Yeah the plotting is a bit dumb, but the film itself isn't too bad'. What really lets this film down is its embarrassing finale which actually undid all of the intrigue and suspense that director Cunningham had created for the first 75 minutes. We see Jason's mad mother (in a rather competent, but over-the-top performance by Betsy Palmer) trying to pick off the last survivor. Whilst this was quite a fun little game of cat and mouse, it lacked the suspense and tension that we'd witnessed with all the previous killings and ended up verging dangerously close to self parody.Friday the 13th is a fairly effective film (at the least for the first 75 minutes). The dumb and far-fetched plot elements meant it was never going to brilliant, but up to this point it had enough suspense & tension to make it worth watching. However, for me the final act cheapened everything that preceded it and ended up almost ruining the overall viewing experience.

Review title: "No place to hide..." Drenched in blood was the long dark night of Friday the 13th!
Review_body: First of all, look what date it is, see what I did there? I'm the man! Whoo!!! The original is the only Friday movie that I give a ten to, there's just something very special about it to me, and it's certainly the one that I find the most creepy. It's such a good old-fashioned stalk and slash through the dark of the highest order! Perhaps it's even the granddaddy of all such grisly fare. I'm aware that it isn't quite the first slasher ever, but it was certainly an influential game changer and a definer of the genre. It was definitely one of the first to, whether they were aware of what they were doing or not, wholeheartedly embrace all of the beloved 'rules' and themes of the slasher. It works as an 'official' template for them all. Now it's probably considered to be fairly standard stuff by most folks, but I for one love it. The dialogue and characterisation is more than a little on the hokey side, but the most endearing quality is the fantastic haunting atmosphere, the ever- present surroundings of the beautiful lake and foreboding woods are so eerie. And then there's the music, and the iconic 'Jason' noise, and crazy old hag Mrs.Voorhees with her blue sweater and big nasty dentures! Very sorry to hear that gal recently passed away. Such a novel twist how it was a little old lady doing it the whole time! You'd never see that one coming.. She's so game for it in the scenes where she's grappling with the enchanting Adrienne King until she famously turns the tables and lops off her head in one legendary moment of gore! All of the gruesome effects still look really well done, Tom Savini did such excellent work. Very nice and cruel. Oh wait, let me explain. I've always found that it's okay to 'enjoy' the slaughter of this film series in that each death is like the punchline to a macabre joke, and then so begins the buildup to the next one.. It's something akin to the carnival game where you shoot the ducks that pop up! The scariest part for me is when the girl goes out into the storm after hearing a child's distant cry of ~"Help meeee!~ It gives me a chill every time I hear it. I don't like curtains being open at night. Somebody might be out in the dark, looking in. You can't see them, but they can see you. It really gives me the creeps. You never see her die, just hear her scream, and like when the annoying comic relief guy in the feather headdress is quietly finished off, I find it more unsettling when it's what you don't see, and your head fills in the rest! The cast speak fondly of their time working on the film and remember the good times they had, and I think that shows, it does have a certain enthusiasm about it. It kinda feels like this movie gets a free pass with me, forgiveness for all of its faults - because it's Friday the f*****g 13th man! It's such a romp, it always was. I think it's seminal horror viewing . There's a reason why this humble movie from 1980 with a cast of unknowns at the time, still lives on. It's suspenseful, it's funny and it's fun, and that jump scare with the boat at the end is one of the best in horror movie history! I'd like to see anything from today come close to such longevity. Most of those are forgotten on the way home from the cinema! An undeniable classic and essential for good spooky fun.

I'm all for schlock, but this was plain boring. No suspense, no interesting characters, no creepy atmosphere. All it really has going for it are some interesting gore effects and a hammy villainous performance at the very end. I'm honestly shocked this was a hit at all.

Review title: The slasher prototype and a blast of gory atmospheric fun
Review_body: 31 Days Of Horror: Day 13One of the original slasher prototypes, Friday The 13th is a beloved halloween classic for me. I have hazy recollections of nerding out on the entire franchise (which is a big commitment, believe me) when I was younger, starting with this quaint, barebones entry. Fun fact: iconic Jason Voorhees doesn't even show up until the second film, and doesn't even find his legendary hockey mask until the third. It's his demented mommy Pamela Voorhees (Betsy Palmer) who does the slicing and dicing here, on an unsuspecting bunch of soon to be (or not) camp counselors. It opens with a prologue set in the 50's, detailing the very first murders ever to be committed at Camp Crystal Lake, setting the POV tone (this movie is the king of POV shots) before fast forwarding to the 80's. The counselors arrive, and shirk their renovation duties as the director drives off into town for supplies. They goof off, get hammered and yes, engage in classic slasher movie teen sex, before being butchered one by one by an unseen Mrs. Voorhees. Makeup master Tom Savini supplies the gruesome FX, and a very young Kevin Bacon plays one of the unfortunate youngsters. Adrienne King, in one of the first incarnations of the 'final girl' archetype, is resilient as Alice. Like I've said before, atmosphere is very important here, and this one pioneers the slow, ambient buildup perfectly, punctuated by hazy interludes of forest and lake photography, accompanied by the creepy and surprisingly beautiful score. This is one corner of an integral triangle of slasher films (the other two are coming up as well) that forged an entire subgenre, an army of imitators, homages and spoofs, and a whole corner of horror culture all its own. A classic.

Review title: Slasher Classic That Started Off The '80s Horror Boom.
Review_body: "Ki ki ki ki ma ma ma ma". That's the famous trademark to the "Friday the 13th" series. This is probably one of my favorite 80's slashers, and none of the sequels it spawned (which is about 10 currently) are nearly as good. "Friday the 13th" is about a group of camp counselors who are left alone overnight to fix up the camp before its grand reopening. The teens are having fun and enjoying themselves, swimming, playing games, having sex, and just having a good time. But their good time comes to an end when a big storm hits that evening, and suddenly the teens begin to gruesomely die left and right. Who is killing off the teens at Camp Crystal Lake? Could it be Jason Voorhees, who drowned in the lake years ago? Or perhaps someone else? I wont say who the killer is, because it will ruin the whole movie if you haven't seen it, so I'll stop there."Friday the 13th" wouldn't appear to be a movie deserving of all the popularity that it received. Its overall storyline seems typical of its genre, with a bunch of worthless teenagers at the hands of a merciless killer. But this film is remembered as such a classic because it set off the domino-effect of the countless slasher movies that evolved from the '80s, many of them essential rip-offs. While the slasher-type story of "Friday the 13th" isn't unique, the twist in the end really sets it apart. The atmosphere is spooky, and the summer camp setting is perfect, plus that unforgettably eerie score adds to the film's energy. Also notable are the clever and disturbing ways that the characters are killed off, many of which have never been forgotten by genre fans. Acting-wise, it isn't amazing in the least, and the majority of our performers are mediocre at best. Adrienne King leads the cast competently, and you'll recognize a young Kevin Bacon as a camp counselor, along with Betsy Palmer as a prime example of a delusional psychopath.In my opinion this is the best movie of the series by far, the rest are just a bunch of rather cheap slasher films that were spawned consecutively after the success of the original, although they are still somewhat enjoyable on a corny-slasher flick kind of level. This movie has spawned ten sequels already if that tells you anything, but the first is still number one and I think it always will be. How can you get any better than this movie? This is the ultimate slasher movie in my opinion, and I'm having trouble deciding whether or not I like this better than "Halloween". I suppose this film is taken a little less seriously, but I think that makes it an even more fun film to watch. There are creative murders, a great setting, and one hell of an ending.Overall, "Friday the 13th" is the perfect movie to watch on a stormy summer night, because you are guaranteed to have a good time. It set the grounds for the uncountable number of slasher films that followed during the decade, and remains a prime example of what a good slasher movie is. This is one of those movies that I can watch over and over again and never really get tired of it. Sure, "Friday the 13th" may be a body count movie - but it's really the king of them all. A true must-see for horror fans, although if you consider yourself one, you've more than likely already seen it. 10/10.

Friday the 13th is a true Classic of the Slasher Horror genre & everyone knows the story & the killer so no point in going over all that again.Just gonna say how Awesome this little low-budget Slasher is.When i think of Friday the 13th i think of summertime & get Nostalgia from just thinking about how Awesome the summertime looked way back in the 1970's & 1980's, i was born in 1984 so didn't experience those but i remember the 90's well.Friday the 13th is a summer movie that's full of Mystery & suspense & most of all "FUN" yes although a violent & bloody Horror film it's still always a fun experience & entertaining.Adrienne King had her most iconic role as final girl hero Alice & she gives a terrific & memorable performance.I love the whole Camp setting with the deep forests & big beautiful lake that all gives it that feelgood summertime atmosphere.The 13th is an essential Summertime Horror Classic like Spielberg's Jaws.Friday the 13th is Classic movie just like the first ever Halloween & The Texas Chainsaw Massacre & The Fog & The Burning, amongst others of the genre.

This legendary classic 1980 slasher flick is the one that started the famous Jason Voorhees franchise. Starred Betsy Palmer and Adrienne King, this movie gives offers up plenty of gore, horny teens, and a deranged mother seeking revenge. The acting was less than satisfactory, it wasn't terrible, it's just that some of it was really cheesy at times. I did think that it took a little too long getting going, the best part was the last 40 minutes. That was when the screaming and offscreen killings and action happened. Some of the fighting and action was cheesy and kinda funny, it wasn't supposed to be though, so that's not good. At 1 point an axe rises behind a girl, and she has she the most laughable cheesy scream I've ever seen or heard, I was kinda annoyed by that, I just thought the actors could've done a lot better than that. I did enjoy Betsy Palmer's performance though. I did like that the killings occurred offscreen, so I didn't have to suffer through what most modern day horror movies do, meaning the constant full detail graphic horror violence. I like it when movies leave something to the imagination. I didn't mind seeing the somewhat bloody aftermath of the victim's bodies. So overall, just an OK horror film, enjoyed parts, and laughed at others 5/10.

Review title: The original slasher film, where it's all started to take place from countless bad slasher movies came after this one.
Review_body: Camp Crystal Lake has been closed for more than 20 years ago, since the drowning of a 11 year old boy and two counselors were killed the same night of the incident. Which the crime is still unsolved for all these years. Now it's going to re-open soon at the camp. The owner (Peter Brouwer) and the new counselors (Adrienne King, Harry Crosby, Laurie Bartham, Jeannine Taylor, Kevin Bacon, Mark Nelson and Robbi Morgan) are rebuilding the camp, despite the local residents are against the idea. But the mysterious killer has came back to haunt the camp and stalking the counselors.Directed by Sean S. Cunningham (Producer of memorable B-Movies like House, Freddy Vs. Jason, The Last House on the Left) made an moody if wooden acted, slow moving suspense horror film that brings out the goods. The independent film becomes one of the most successful horror movies in the 1980's (In the wake of John Carpenter's Halloween). This film has good atmosphere, a few suspenseful moments and great (if bloody) creative murder sequences. Which it was done by Make-Up Artist:Tom Savini (The original "Dawn of the Dead", The Texas Chainsaw Massacre Part 2, Creepshow).DVD has an sharp but an dark anamorphic Widescreen (1.78:1) transfer and an good-Dolby Digital 2.0 mono sound. DVD's only extra is the original theatrical trailer. The Collector's Box Set from the Friday the 13th series, includes interviews with the cast and filmmakers and alternate death scenes (Which the movie was trimmed a bit to get an R-Rating). Besty Palmer has an memorable role in the movie in one of the movie's best surprises. Many critics and fans of the series will call this "The original slasher picture". Although it's started with Alfred Hitchcock's Psycho and then later Bob Clark's Black Christmas and of course Halloween. But these three classic films were not graphic in their violent sequences as "Friday the 13th" was. But Friday the 13th is quite tame now, than it was over 26 years ago.While that movie received controversial for it's brutal death scenes. The acting may be stiff but the actors are likable that in the picture set at a summer camp (Which it is now way overdone with the sequels or bad countless clones) is interesting and the movie has natural feel in the performances. Bacon, who went on to be an successful Hollywood actor. He has the most memorable death scene in this one. This also have an terrific last act with an memorable conclusion. This picture is followed by nine sequels (!) and a TV series. Written by Victor Miller, which Miller went on to write an successful career at Television. Miller wrote soap operas like "All My Children" and "One Life to Live". (****/*****).

The one that started it all! This was the first in a (happily) never-ending franchise about a maniacal serial killer who stalks and splatters victims in a variety of inventive ways, and it's set at a long-abandoned camp just off Crystal Lake. In this debut film, a fresh group of teen-aged camp counselors attempt to fix up and resume business at the cursed campsite, where a young boy had drowned over twenty years earlier, followed by a string of unsolved murders. Despite the warnings of the old local town lunatic who warns them "you're doomed!", the naive youngsters are gradually slaughtered off one by one. "Friday the 13th" often gets special consideration in hindsight these days because it was the first in a long-running series that has persisted for nearly 30 years now (a brand new remake opens in a few days as of this writing!). It's a solid horror experience with several things to recommend in it, including: terrific gore effects by makeup maestro Tom Savini, a fun climax and ending, and an aura of mystery as to guessing the killer's identity. Harry Manfredini also deserves special praise for coming up with the chilling music soundtrack, which would be repeated in later sequels. *** out of ****
