Review title: It set a pattern for a whole generation!
Review_body: It's a classic that I'm not sure if aged well. It's simple and entertaining, but I can't see more than that. Even though, I can't deny its importance to the horror genre.

While this is in no way the first movie that could be coined a slasher film, this film is the first to set the standard for what became a film phenomenon; teenagers getting slaughtered by the dozen. 
There's no story here, it's just one long buildup to a massacre.  This film just jumps from one kill to the next.  Some compare this movie to Halloween (the first one) and I don't find that justifiable.  Halloween is a much superior film to this one, the craftsmanship alone should tell you that. However, I've always liked Friday the 13th and I'll defend it's right for existence anytime, anywhere.  It doesn't bother with a story, it only has cardboard characters (so we won't mind when they're getting butchered), it doesn't take itself too seriously, it's shot on a low budget and therefore looks cheap,  but in the end it gives us what we desire; A whole lot of inventive killings (from the ingenious mind of Tom Savini). 
In the documentary on the DVD, director Sean S. Cunningham tells of the making of this film and he mentions Betsy Palmer, and she admits to this as well, that when she read the script she thought it was total garbage.  But she wanted a new car and she needed the work. What Cunningham did with this film was create a formula that's going to last longer than the memory of Jason Vorhees (or mrs. Vorhees) and give a bloodthirsty audience just what they wanted.  Put all that together, and throw in a terrific one-note musical score and you've got yourself a classic.

Camp Crystal Lake has been shut down for years, seems that nothing but bad luck has followed since the death of a boy named Jason. Seems Jason drowned because the counselors were busy making love and not watching him. Now years later the camp is about to be reopened but someone is slaughtering the new counselors, but who? Could it be Jason survived? Friday The 13th became a classic only because the audience that made it so popular back in the 80's (People like me) grew up and became movie critics and looked back at this with fondness. I myself find the first Friday The 13th to be a rather by the numbers slasher flick although I did think it had it's moments. The gore level was very high back in the day but now the carnage is often cut away from in the moment of truth. I did however love the scene where an ax gets slammed into a face, or an arrow going into the neck of an unhappy camper. Oh who am I getting, I love this movie. However due to it's quality I can't rate it higher. However this series had it's ups and downs and for those curious as to what started the slasher movie craze, well look no further. Also I think that most critics failed to notice an admittedly suspenseful final reel. Indeed if the movie had been as tense as the last 10 minutes, this could be an easy 4 star movie. However looking back at this movie in hindsight, there is an element I miss in today's horror movies. In that they were so gritty and the low budget actually gave it a documentary feel which added to the tension.* * out of 4-(Fair)

Review title: Ki Ki Ki, Ma Ma Ma... or, other words - Kill her, mommy!
Review_body: Back in 1980 horror films were trying to push the boundary of what was acceptable, there had been many a video nasty already released, and some big hitters in the horror genre were birthed. "Friday the 13th" was made for around $550,000 and would go on to earn almost $60 million globally, not to mention spawn sequels, prequels, games, comics, and various entries into contemporary cinema. This is one of my favourite horror/slasher films of all time, and anyone that is serious about horror must watch this, if they have not already watched it hundred of times already.In 1957 a young boy drowns in the lake at Camp Crystal. A year later two camp councillors are brutally murdered while having sex in a storage cabin. Fast forward to the future and twenty-two-year-old camp councillor Annie Phillips is on her was to the reopened Camp Crystal to work the summer. She never quite makes it because after being dropped off close enough to walk, she is chased through the woods and gets her throat cut. And thus, the fun starts. At the camp, a group of councillors (Ned, Jack, Bill, Marcie, Brenda, and Alice) and the site owner (Steve) are preparing for the season. A storm comes in but by this time the fun has already started. Some of the camp councillors are killed in creative and brutal ways. Alice and Bill investigate as best as they can, while trying to survive while all around them hell is breaking loose. Alice meets a new arrival at the camp, Mrs Voorhees, a middle-aged woman who claims that the boy who drown in 1957 was her son Jason. She blames his death on the councillors who were supposed to be looking after him but were having sex instead. Mrs Voorhees is not revealing everything she knows though, and soon enough Alice has a fight on her hands again.This is a low-budget film that became bigger than most people would have anticipated. It came about primarily due to the success of John Carpenter's "Halloween" (1978), and like that, managed to cement itself into horror film folklore. It was produced and directed by Sean S. Cunningham, who as well as taking inspiration from Carpenter, had also worked with Wes Craven on exploitation horror film "The Last House on the Left" (1972). With this film Cunningham wanted more of a rollercoaster horror that would scare the audience. Something like "Black Christmas" (1974) but for a warmer season.When it came to casting, there was more emphasis on hiring people who seemed right for the role of camp councillor rather than seasoned actors. Most of the cast came from soap operas with a handful being auditioned from adverts. Using adverts worked well as a way of marketing the film to kids too. The role of Mrs Voorhees was given to Betsy Palmer after Estelle Parsons snubbed the film on account of it being too violent. Palmer though was not a fan; she thought the film was "a piece of 5h1t" and only accepted because she needed to buy a new car. A lot of people tend to forget, this film has Kevin Bacon in it - yes, "Footloose" (1984) Kevin Bacon.Filming took place in Hardwick, Blairstown, and Hope in Warren County, New Jersey). The camp which was used is still standing and still operates as a summer camp, it is a boy scout camp called Camp No-Be-Bo-Sco. The lovely make-up effects that you can see on screen are courtesy of make-up genius Tom Savini. He got the call after having success with George A. Romero's "Dawn of the Dead" (1978). As well as the genius make-up, there a special twist in the musical department which was headed up by Harry Manfredi. He wanted to keep things to a minimum and only used music when the killer was about. The idea was not "manipulate the audience" unnecessarily but give them enough of a clue when the killer is present. He had to create a musical score which represent the killer in their absence and for that he took some inspiration from the score created by John Williams for the 1975 smash-hit "Jaws". The famously chilling sound of "ki ki ki, ma ma ma" actually comes from the reciting "kill her, mommy!" ...... and just like that I have given a clue to the killer - damnit!Using Mrs Voorhees as the killer was a stroke of genius. Nobody was expecting it and a lot of people who claimed to love horror but had not seen this would often get it wrong, assuming that Jason Voorhees is the killer when in fact it was his mother. If you have seen Wes Craven's "Scream" (1996), it famously uses this knowledge in its dialogue when the killer is doing a pop-quiz to potential victims. Cunningham revelled in inventing a serial killer and enjoyed settling on a matriarchal murderer. "I took motherhood and turned it on its head, and I think that was great fun. Mrs Voorhees was the mother I had always wanted - a mother who would have killed for her kids".On its release, despite facing very stiff competition from the likes of "The Shining" (1980), "the Fog" (1980), and "Prom Night" (1980), this was a massive success. It might not have been a film that would garner many prestigious awards, but it set itself up as a success in the world of horror. Most of the critics in contemporary cinema actually hated the film because the plot wasn't that deep, and it was pretty straight forward - serial killer stalks sex mad kids. Some saw it as self-indulgent nihilism, inherently voyeuristic, slow paced, and over ambitious with trying to make the gender of the villain a twist. At the time though, some of those same critics did not have foresight enough to see that this film, like some of its contemporaries (including "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" (1974) and "Halloween" (1978) were part of a developing sub-genre of horror, the slasher film. There are now at least 10 sequels, a cross-over with Freddy Krueger from "A Nightmare on Elm Street" (1984), reboots, novels, comics, and a video game.I love "Friday 13th". It is iconic and genre defining. It is super low budget in comparison to other horror films, but it stands tall and proud as a success. It managed to create a tone and style for horror films which is still emulated 40 years later. With a dark and atmospheric set up there is something raw and voyeuristic about this film. Right from the off we are following the killer, we do not see the killers face till it is too late, all we get is the thrill and black humour of watching kids being brutally killed in creative ways. That is something that follows the franchise through its lifecycle and something that makes the horror almost amusing to fans of the horror genre. This film does not claim to be something it is not; it does not claim to be an intellectual film, it's refreshing in its approach as a straight-up thrill packed scare movie. I thoroughly enjoyed this movie in every decade that I have watched it. It might not have aged spectacularly due to the way the world has changed, but for atmosphere and thrills it is hard to beat. Do yourself a favour, get some popcorn, turn the lights off, and sit back. 8/10

Ah, "Halloween" - a movie chock full of suspense, drama, honest-to-goodness shocks and more intensity than any of its ripoffs.Which brings us to "Friday the 13th".  Even though they say they were making a movie that had its own agenda and originality, let's help them face the truth: it's a cash-in that was later turned into a cash cow for Paramount Pictures that lasted considerably longer than anyone ever imagined (and far longer than many movie-lovers wanted).Do you even want to know about the plot?  It's the same as any other movie with "Friday" and "13th" in the title.  A group of kids go to camp, maniac slices, cuts and juliennes them until one fights back and blah, blah, blah....And that's about it.  No imagination, no intelligence, no style.  Just chop, chop, chop.  Though this one is better than any of its far-lesser sequels, it's still nothing when compared to the real classics of this type of film.You want a GOOD mad killer movie?  There's the aforementioned "Halloween" (the original ONLY, please) as well as "Psycho" (again, the original), both of which have twelve truckloads more panache than "Friday" can muster.Just one more reason to consider that day unlucky.Two stars.  Kevin Bacon gets killed off early on - thus saving himself for more worthy projects (way to go, Kev), and Palmer demonstrates the only real acting in this one.  Oh well, that's life. ...or as close as "Friday the 13th" comes to it.

Review title: Why can't I stop watching these films?
Review_body: This is the original Friday the 13th installment. But as horror films go, there really was nothing original about it. By 1980, we had already seen Halloween and Black Christmas and countless other slasher films. I just cannot explain either the public's or my own utter fascination with the majority of the films in this series. Any time one comes on , I just have to watch at least part of it. Even if it's one of the bad ones.The first film in the series used a formula that would be repeated in most of the others. We have a group of young camp counselors getting hacked to bits in a remote camp by a mostly unseen killer. Some of the killings are incredibly brutal and some happen off screen. We learn in an unexpected twist at the end that it is a woman doing the killing. She is a former kitchen worker who is getting revenge for the death of her son (Jason Voorhees) many years earlier. He apparently drowned while the counselors on duty were making love. Perhaps that is why nearly anyone in these films who has sex gets offed. Anyway, the mother is finally defeated in a particularly gruesome scene. The following installments feature her son Jason killing off anyone who dares come into the area to have fun.Sounds simple enough, but why all the demand for more sequels? Few really famous people have ever starred in these films. Kevin Bacon (who was hardly famous at the time) and Corey Feldman are perhaps two exceptions. Other than the Tommy Jarvis character beginning in part 4, there was next to no character development in the series. The mostly unknown actors are quickly introduced and obliterated by whatever garden or implement tool is handy. The music is always fun and creepy, but Halloween already set the bar as far as that was concerned. Some may argue that the detailed brutality of the special effects were a big selling point, but these films really only had one or two memorable deaths per episode. The ax to the face featured in part one still stands as one of the best. The POV camera shots utilized in the series had also been done before. (Halloween, once again) I think there are two main factors that have made this series so on-going. First of all, you would have to cite the tiny budgets needed to make the earlier installments. Part one had well-below a one million dollar budget, and all it took was noticeable demand for sequels and you were bound to get one after the other. Another factor was the hockey mask Jason dons in part three. That mask looks very spooky, and it made him an easily recognizable icon in American cinema. Even casual film fans know Jason is the guy with the hockey mask.I love the Friday the 13th series. The older episodes in particular. I really cannot explain why, but these films have been as much a part of my life while growing up as anything else. Even the Star Wars films. 1,2,4, and 6 are probably my favorites. I hope they're yours, too! 8 of 10 stars. The Hound.

In the first installment of this scary saga, we learn the story behind Camp Crystal Lake. It seems that many years ago, the summer of 1957 to be exact, a child supposedly drown in the lake. His name, Jason Voorhees. His mother Pamela, though, has other plans for the campers and counselors.The story begins in the summer of 1979, and the camp is reopening, hoping to put the past behind them now. What they do not know is that Pamela Voorhees blames everyone for the "death" of her son, and plans to take revenge against them, all of them.The film stars newcomer Kevin Bacon in his first thriller with death, well before "Stir of Echoes". By the end of the film though, Kevin Bacon is dead, as well as other camp counselors. And for Pamela Voorhees, she is no more. Jason sees her murdered (and to know how, watch the movie) and takes revenge upon himself. This leas up to "Part 2", which is set about four or five years later.

More than 25 years since its release, more than 10 sequels and an infinite number of imitations, most people seem to remember "Friday the 13th" as just another slasher with good-looking teens being killed by a seemingly unstoppable psycho while roaming in an isolated location. However, what most people seem to forget, is that "Friday the 13th" looks so typical nowadays precisely because it was the first film of its class, the origin of all those clichés and the film that redefined the mainstream horror genre during the 80s and the 90s. At its time, it was a film as daring enough to be called controversial yet at the same time accessible enough to be appreciated by the mainstream audiences; for those reasons and more, this films can be proud of being the first one, the definitive one, the film that gave birth to the slasher sub genre. Our story begins 22 years after a series of unsolved murders happened at Camp Crystal Lake and forced the closure of the beloved Summer Camp and started the legend of the death curse of Camp Crystal Lake, now known as "Camp Blood". Now, the new owner, Steve Christy (Peter Brouwer), decides to reopen the infamous "Camp Blood" with the help of six new counselors. Ignoring the warnings of the locals, Steve and his young assistants begin the restoration of the long abandoned Camp, but on the night of Friday the 13th, the group of teens will discover that there may be some true behind the local legends, as the death curse of "Camp Blood" returns and a mysterious killer starts to claim fresh, young victims.Writer Victor Miller claims to have taken a crash course in horror writing when he wrote "Friday the 13th", as both he and director Sean Cunningham were in desperate need of a success and saw that the horror genre had potential, but knew very little about it. So, by taking John Carpenter's "Halloween" as a model, Miller crafted his story about the nightmarish night where a group of teens end up isolated and at the mercy of an unknown serial killer, with the sole purpose of making a successful horror film. And he succeeded, as he took the many different elements that would create the "slasher rules" and turned the simple and derivative plot into a roller-coaster of horror, with the perfect mix of fun, horror and mystery that just keeps getting better and better until it reaches the climatic finale.Just like Miller took ideas from other horror stories, Cunningham too employs elements from "Psycho", "Texas Chainsaw Massacre" and specially "Reazione a Catena", mixing them and taking them one step further, in a simple but very effective approach that slowly develops Miller's plot while at the same time offers a quite graphic vision of violence (thanks to Tom Savini's excellent effects) that completes what we know as the "slasher set of rules". Cunningham may not be an original filmmaker, but his "Friday the 13th" remains as one of the most effective suspense tales that despite the bad reputation earned by its sequels, still packs up some good chills thanks to its remarkably well done set pieces and the good use of visuals and music to create tension.The acting of the film is one the level of the horror films of its time; sure, those may not be the best performances in horror but are miles ahead most of what was delivered by the film's sequels. While the cast is nothing really special, two exceptions are easily noticeable: the young Adrienne King, who becomes our main character, delivers a very good performance that makes her decision of stop acting even more surprising. And of course, Betsy Palmer, who gives the performance of her lifetime as Mrs. Vorhees, a former cook at Camp Crystal Lake that knows more about the Camp's curse than what she may tell. Palmer truly created an iconic character that sadly has been overshadowed by the image of the killer with the Hockey Mask.While it's true that Cunningham and Miller made a film heavily based on previous horror classics, "Friday the 13th" doesn't feel as derivative as it should, as the many "borrowed" elements here work together with frightening perfection. And despite having average acting, and a fairly low-budget, what truly has become the movie's fatal flaw is the poor reputation that its sequels, its parodies and its imitators have given to "Friday the 13th"'s name, making the film the source of laughs instead of scares, and making the series to be synonymous with stupid horror tales. The many sequels have truly harmed this film's reputation among the classics, but the truth is that while this movie is far from being a perfect movie, it's creepy and entertaining enough to deliver fun even more than 25 years after its initial release. To enjoy "Friday the 13th", one must try to forget what it's known about the series, and simply enjoy the film as if it was the first time one heard about the infamous crimes of "Camp Blood". 8/10

Review title: Even with a irregular narrative, sometimes monotonous; however, there is no denying its leading role in the field of the slasher genre
Review_body: The film begins in the summer of 1958, at a camp called Crystal Lake, where young people sing and play the guitar, while a couple of monitors take a "escape" upstairs. While the couple is involved in their "making out", a first-person camera climbs the stairs, creating an atmosphere of suspense that culminates in the death of the two young lovers. This opening sequence sets the tone for what would be the rest of the film, never showing the killer's face or his motivations for the serial murders.After the opening credits, we have a jump in time to a Friday, June 13th of the "present" - probably 1980, as that was the film's production year, although it could very well have been 1975 (two years in which 13 June fell on a Friday). In a quiet country town, a young woman searches the Crystal Lake camp, where she will be tutoring during her vacation. People in town aren't comfortable talking about the place, but she ends up getting a ride to a nearby road. Meanwhile, new trainers are starting to arrive at camp for the training week leading up to the start of the summer season. The youngsters then have fun on their first day, told that the real training would start the next day.Meanwhile, the girl who was looking for the camp at the beginning of the film gets a new ride, but this time we don't see the driver's face. She realizes there's something wrong when the truck she's in exceeds the speed limit, and jumps out of the moving vehicle. The girl is then chased through the forest, horrified, in a sequence again in first person, in which we don't see the murderer's face again. The killing begins at nightfall, beginning the pattern of the series: night falls, it rains, the energy falls, couples have sex and die. There's not much to talk about the deaths themselves, except perhaps that one of the murdered kids was Kevin Bacon before he became famous.The plot is very close to the motto of E Não Lefte None, a novel by Agatha Christie. A group of characters find themselves trapped in an isolated location and are killed one by one. The similarities end in this argument, as Victor Miller's script follows a bloodier and more explicit direction. With a lot of creativity, the bodies are strewn across the backdrops for ornamentation of the classic final chase, with corpses hanging from trees, thrown out of a window or affixed with arrows behind doors in strategies that are now cliché thanks to repetition to exhaustion throughout the 1980s, 1990 and even contemporaneity would come (just remember the endings of Urban Legend and I Know You Did Last Summer, among others). Friday the 13th presented the definitive rules for slasher, a subgenre of horror cinema that shows random characters being chased by assassins, masked or not. As if that wasn't enough, the film scripted by Victor Miller and directed by Sean S. Cunningham ended up creating a branch in its own subgenre: the camp slasher, where scantily clad boys and girls line up at any summer camp while they wait to be sliced up. By the killer of the time.The great merit of Sean S. Cunningham was to bet on identifying the young characters, who would also be a mirror of the audience to be reached. The holiday camp killing setting was the perfect excuse to take them away from the adult realm and leave them alone, both to fall prey to someone mysterious and to be free to have sex and smoke at will. By the way, the sexualization of the characters was such a striking element that it evolved the subtlety of "Halloween" into something more open, to the point of creating the stigma of a certain morality implicit in the slasher: sex and drugs would be punishable by death.The murders were also given a "creative treatment" - something that would become the conscious focus and hallmark of the franchise - by talented effects and makeup technician Tom Savini, George Romero's usual collaborator on "Night of the Living Dead". Furthermore, by taking the position of the killer's eyes, Cunningham's camera not only hides the villain's body and identity, but places the viewer in a voyeuristic position during the hunt. This feature was not the original creation of the work, as it already existed in the Italian giallo and was present in the Canadian classic "Night of Terror" of 1974. However, the director took advantage of another effect of this technique on the viewer: in the public's view of 1980, only one man would be able to commit the atrocities of the film. Right?Thus, the expectation of finally knowing the villain's identity is overcome in a great revealing turn that is the origin of the legend of Jason Voorhees and contributed to his success in theaters. Jason as he is known, with his iconic characterizations and supernatural behavior, only begins to take shape after the sequel. In this first work, the star is different. Jason who would be the main killer of the entire franchise is very little present, we know his story at the bottom of the main plot as a disabled little boy, who drowned in the lake at the camp due to a certain negligence of the advisors at the time, he only serves as a reason for the real assassin doing what she does.Harry Manfredini's music is very psychotic. But the déjà vu feel quickly wears off, and the score becomes one of the film's strong points. The great work of makeup master Tom Savini, in line with quick and creative cuts, lends credibility to the various death scenes scattered throughout the film. Friday the 13th has already passed the 40-year mark, but its practical effects remain convincing to this day. As a film, Friday the 13th is not a masterpiece, it is an amateur work, and experimental. But those adjectives don't match the impact it had on cinema in the 1980s, when the studio bosses saw how much money this movie made, it became a given that there would be sequels, and it did.The survivor's final confrontation with the assassin is another defining moment in the film. Almost as much as the boat scene, where we have one of the most famous jump scares of the 80s. Even though a few slow moments (among them an endless coffee-making scene) compromise the experience a little, Friday the 13th is a classic that horror movie fans can't miss.However, it is necessary to emphasize that the script is not formidable, but the ending showing the real killer was a great contrast to what was being produced in the genre. The characters in the film represent the typical archetypes of the 1980s, with two very emblematic cases: Alice is the final girl charged with purity and Ned is the "clown" who loves a silly joke and becomes, mercilessly, one of the victims of the bath. Of blood proposed by the narrative. The couple who are sexually related and die soon after are also present, one of the landmarks of the films in this segment. By the way, Alice initially looks a lot like Laurie Strode from Halloween, but takes on her own contours throughout the film. There is also the comic relief, represented on Friday the 13th by police officer Dorf, a fool who appears to make us laugh and demonstrate the fragile situation of young people; after all, the representative of the law is the only and last sample of safety, before the coming night of blood and horror.It's strange in this first film that we know absolutely nothing about the identity of the killer, which causes a certain lack of empathy in the viewer. There is no way to care about any character. And, after one by one they die, leaving only the last victim, we find out who is the murderer. The problem is, we have no idea who the hell the killer is. She doesn't appear during the film, and her tragic story is only told in the final minutes. If we had some hints during the course of the plot that a boy had died from the negligence of the prefect's years before, and that strange things were happening after that, perhaps we would be more concerned about the fate of these people.Even with a irregular narrative, sometimes monotonous; however, there is no denying its leading role in the field of the slasher genre: the film inspired several "cheapest" imitations, yielded continuations to the present day and launched one of the most iconic villains in the history of cinema. Even if a person has never even watched any of the episodes of the series, it is practically impossible not to recognize the "evil" through a man who wields a machete, adorned with a hockey mask.

Review title: Old School Thrills Go "Back To Nature"...
Review_body: When you are one-half of the duo responsible for making a movie as realistically brutal as LAST HOUSE ON THE LEFT, a film so radical for its time that even people you knew didn't want to be associated with you, how in the hell do you follow that up?By scaring the chocolate sphincter pudding out of audiences AGAIN...this time with something a little more traditional.College prof-turned-screenwriter Victor Miller wondered one day: what would a horror film be like that featured all of the most gruesome ways of dying that scare people? And what would happen if you put it in a setting infamous for breeding terrifying myths of escaped lunatics and backwoods beasties, like say, a summer camp? Hey, how about one of those classic legendary tales from around the fire told after midnight...but this time for real?Welcome, campers, to Camp Crystal Lake. Any day at this secluded slaughterhouse would be unlucky for you, but here's a bonus! It's "FRIDAY THE 13TH"...HALLOWEEN knocked it out of the park, when John Carpenter and friends proved that you could wring maximum chills out of a minimum budget. Of course, when that movie became the most successful independent horror film for the time, EVERYBODY wanted to make one. It just so happens that F13 was the next out of the gate, neck-and-neck with a certain, razor-fingered dream demon...The plot, now considered a super-cliché, was oh-so-simple: Years ago at Camp Crystal Lake, the counselors looking after the kids decided to slip off for a little neckin' and nookie, but in their haste to answer the call of overheated hormones, they made the fatal mistake of leaving one of the kids alone. A kid with - shall we say - "special needs" named Jason Voorhees, who promptly drowned in the lake. The event was unlucky for Jason, but even worse for the careless kids, who were found brutally murdered the following year. Once that happened, the camp was shut down and never re-opened...Until now.The hype for this movie was unbelievable when it came out. Word of mouth pumped it up so much that it supposedly made LHOTL or even the scariest movie you've ever seen seem like an episode of ROMPER ROOM. (For the record: my scariest movie as a teen up to that point had been SUSPIRIA.)So it was nearly two years before I finally mustered up the courage to see this, on a double bill with F13 PT. 2. What amazed me was two things: how great the makeup effects were (Tom Savini working his magic), and how the more I watched, the less scared I was. Hey! How much is somebody gonna make you wet yourself after DARIO ARGENTO???Well, now this movie has passed into history as kind of a museum piece. It's been folded, spindled, mutilated, parodied, copied and re-copied every conceivable way you can think of, and even paid homage to in countless other movies, (most notably in SCREAM, which is not too surprising.) There's even a remake that will be released in 2009, just in time for...do I REALLY have to tell you?Still, it's a valuable record of horror's gory, glorious "old school" days, back when nobody knew who budding screen hunk and victim-to-be Kevin Bacon was, and once Piper Laurie's career had gotten an electric reboot from CARRIE, every languishing star from Hollyweird's Golden Era was stepping up to the plate to try and crack one off. Most famously in F13's case, a big-and-small screen celeb and game show darling named Betsy Palmer, cast WAAAAY against type as the MVP of F13 fame, Mrs. Pamela Voorhees. And what a hellacious job she did, too!Is it really scary these days? Not much, but as for the Monster's Gallery in your horror DVD collection, you can't call your stash complete without it.

A summer camp, which has been closed for years due murders that occurred there years ago, is being re-opened for the summer. The main film starts with counselors gathering a preparing the campsite and all is going fine until a storm comes and a vicious killer starts to brutally kill the counselors one by one.That is pretty much all that happens and the movie is ridiculously simplistic in its storyline, but the death scenes are among the slasher genre's finest. Tom Savini, the man responsible for the landmark gore effects in "Dawn of the Dead," treats horror buffs with what he does best and it provides for genuinely gruesome fun. Next, and perfectly matched by the gore and great deaths is the suspense, which essentially raises this film past much of the campiness resulting in a solid and mature horror film that is only limited by its budget, but the production made good use of what it had to work with. The film is also clever in the revealing of the killer which essentially puts the classic film "Psycho" on its head. Good stuff all around. 8/10Rated R: graphic violence and a sex scene, aka the usual slasher stuff.

Review title: Enjoyable , if not exactly a good horror movie
Review_body: Friday The 13th" is the movie that started one of the most famous horror franchise in the history of cinema. Hollywood made 11 sequels and a remake , if I'm not mistaken. It is also one of the most successful low-budget films ever made. The character of Jason Voorheas is definitely a pop culture icon."Friday" obviously takes a LOT ideas from other , much better movies like "Psycho" , "Carrie" and especially "Halloween" . The movie makers admit it was John Carpenter's movie that they were trying to cash in and the similarities in story are quite obvious (holiday , prophet of doom trying to war teenagers , stalker and faceless murder , teens having sex). By today standards this movie is generic as hell , but back then in the 1980 this movie along with "Halloween" became genre defining and highly influential . After it's success they were made TONS of similar movies like "Sleepaway camp" that were hardly anything , but copies of this one. It's one of the films that to this day still has repercussions.With all this being said , "Friday The 13th" is not a great movie , or exactly a good one. It's not even a great movie in it's own genre ("Halloween" and "Nightmare on Elm street" are FAR better). It's just decent enough to provide some cheap thrills even for a non horror fan like me. It has something in it that makes it fun enough and better than the rest run of the mill slashers.The story is thin and nothing special , however the approach to it is pretty great . The movie feels like a "who dunnit" type of mystery . We don't know who and why is making the killings and the twist is pretty shocking and clever joke on audience expectations.The movie has teenagers as the main heroes and it is aimed for teenage audience . The killer is symbolically a disapproving conservative parent figure that tries to punish them for unmoral behavior. There are no stereotypical teenagers here , just normal , everyday kids. It's too bad that the screenplay doesn't give them any interesting personalities , they all pretty bland . I guess they work as a sort of "everyman" type of characters .Director Sean S. Cunningham uses the point-of-view shot from the killer's eyes as he stalks victims and kills them . He wants us to identify with the killer . He makes the audience themselves feel as if they too were being stalked. Maybe he uses that trick too much during the whole movie , but it's an original idea that he fairly pioneered and was copied ever since . It simply works and the settings of the movie also very effective. The stalkings and slaying in broad daylight and open spaces are a twist in a new direction.Harry Manfredini who is responsible for the music tries to imitate the style of Bernard Hermann ("Psycho"). The score frequently starts chanting "Kill, kill, kill." The music is creepy and quite memorable.The movie is nasty and quite sadistic . If you like violence you will be probably satisfied . The movie could had been a bit more bloody and gorier but that is not what the movie is trying to achieve. The special effects do still hold up well.The acting is rather amateurish here , but not necessary terrible . Awful performance by Betsy Palmer , truly worthy a Razzie Award , she almost single handly destroys the movie at the end. Watch out for Kevin Bacon ("Footloose") playing one of the victims."Friday the 13th" might be a cliché slasher , but is an fairly effective one and too important in movie history to miss . Classic horror from the 80's , even if obviously there are many far better horror movies from that decade to watch . Ignore the sequels .I give it 6/10.

Review title: The film that started a franchise. (Possible Spoilers)
Review_body: FRIDAY THE 13TH is one of the few films that can be described as one of the "mother movies" of slasher flicks. It created a phenomenon so huge that everyone and their mother wanted to see this film. Now, here we all are, twenty years later, still talking about this film. Who would have ever dreamed that up? Certainly not director Sean Cunningham who was most likely expecting this film to flop its first week in theaters. But, instead FRIDAY THE 13TH managed to pull off staying in theaters for almost four months.Everyone knows what FRIDAY THE 13TH is about. They know all about the disaster at Camp Crystal Lake. And they all know about Jason Voorhees. But, what most people don't remember is that Jason wasn't even the killer in this film. And for those of you who don't remember, there is this great film for you to watch over and over again to remind you. FRIDAY THE 13TH gets 5/5.

Review title: "Jason was my son and today is his birthday"
Review_body: The cult series Friday THE 13TH starts right here with this film. The movie itself is no masterpiece so I think its real value is to be the beginning of this cult series. The musical score and the schizophrenic behaviour of JASON mother, MRS VOORHEES, made me remind "PSYCHO", as a lot of horror movies from the early 80's do by the way... This movie is the beginning and introduces us to the story of JASON and tells us how he died, but it's all done in the last twenty minutes. Until then it's a common Slasher flick with lots of clichés and a mysterious killer. While I were watching it I was a bit worried because I was even thinking it would had nothing to do with JASON story but then came the end and I was a bit more satisfied! Technically I think this film is nothing special. There're some good deaths in the 80's horror kind but the struggle scenes near the end are pathetically acted.

Review title: Through the eyes of the killer.
Review_body: (mild spoilers, i suppose - like any movie, you're really better off checking it out yourself first before reading what we have to say about it)Seminal kill-the-teens one-by-one has made the phrases "Camp Crystal Lake" "Voorhees" "Ch-ch-ch ha-ha-ha" iconic, and has defined the genre in many ways: the woodland setting, the summercamp have become favourite settings and the rule of sexuality predicting death.Watching this for the first time as a young adult, i'm happy to inform you that its actually quite scary. Movies like this only lose that initial effect if you've seen them before or have heard much about them.There is some corny dialogue in the first fifteen minutes, but after that its all good. Its very well structured, which comes from a very good screenplay - there is definitely more to it than killing the teens one by one, as in Texas Chainsaw Massacre, for instance (which happens to be a hell of a lot more freaky, but not as complex in the writing). It develops much better than more straight-forward horrors. Its more of a serious horror movie than Nightmare on Elm Street, which is more cheesy fun. Unlike Elm Street it cleverly steers clear of what can spoil the mood: the actors having to act like they're dealing with the deaths actually happening, treating death as if its real. This is done by no-one still alive finding out about those who are dead, and all of it taking place on one rainy night where everyone sleeps in separate cabins to make this work.The murders are quite inventive and unforgettable: two or three in particular took me by total surprise and shocked me by how realistic they looked. The killer themselves puts in a marvellous performance, which such a marvellous face!The reason i think this works so well, aside from the script and the ch-ch-ch-ha-ha-ha is that Cunningham establishes in the early scenes that the killer's scenes will be told in the first person - ie, we see what they see, so we don't know who they are. This gives the entire movie an eerie quality, because every time the camera is placed somewhere, looking at the teens, we have to ask ourselves: is this the killer looking at them right now, or just a regular scene? Are we where the killer is? We feel like the killer could be anywhere, watching everything! Very clever.4 stars.

Review title: *SPOILERS* Great Movie to Revisit for Classic Horror Fans
Review_body: Though the film is a bit aged, it's now funny as hell. The actors are bad at acting and a lot of the slasher film cliches are there (didn't this movie help create those same cliches?). Some moments are so awkward that it's funny.One surprise for me was how the original killer was Jason's mom. I was surprised to see part of Jason's lore. What a wild surprise. The film also revealed Jason in the end, intentionally open for more movies to come.3.5/5. Though a good film, too much of it was drawn out and awkward. Definitely watch it if you're a slasher movie addict.

Review title: A body count horror that has nothing else going for it.
Review_body: Friday the 13th cannot even be described as innovative - body count horrors had been around a while - take a look at Theatre of Blood, Madhouse (both with VIncent Price) or Black Christmas for example. All of which are much better than this effort.I do have a certain affecton for this film, though. Tom Savini's brilliant make-up effects hold up very well, and the movie at least tries to generate suspense. It isn't a patch on Halloween, but it does have its moments.Betsy Palmer is by far the best performer in this film (which includes a young Kevin Bacon), delivering a memorable late turn as Mrs. Vorhees. But until we get to understand the reason for all the killings at Camp Crystal Lake, we have watched a movie with virtually no plot. Horror is more than just a series of deaths lined up in a row, which to be honest is all this film is.Perhaps if the film makers had left it there I might regard it better; but they flooded cinemas with inummerable sequels and helped to utterly ruin the horror genre for 20 years. These movies are all dreck,horror franchises were in, teens made them profitible and subletly evaporated from the horror movie.It is, of course, quite conservative in its outlook. If your a goof-off teen you die, if you sleep with your boyfriend you die, if you play strip Monopoly and smoke weed you die (well all but the heroine!)So, although this film is influential it was not in a good way. As if the producers care.

Review title: the slasher that started it all
Review_body: The plot = In 1958 A tragic accident at Camp Crystal Lake a young boy drowns in the lake, while the camp councellors are too busy making out, then a little later on two teenagers are brutally murdered and the Camp is closed down. Then fast forward to 1980 and a bunch of teenagers are hired to open up the camp, despite the warnings and then one by one they are killed off.Well this is the one that started off the slasher boom,although technically started in 1978 with "Halloween", but others that followed that basically failed, it was "Friday The 13th" that started the 80;s boom of Slashers, and became a franchise. But in my opinion this and part 2 are the best ones. But this one like "Halloween" takes a place of previous safety and effectively turns it into a slaugther house. But it isn't perfect It lacks the tension building skill that made it's slasher predecessors, Halloween and Black Christmas, the chilling classics that they're known as today. But there's no denying that Friday, much like all its sequels, is the exemplification of entertaining, fun 80s cinema. While admitted by the filmmakers to have started out as merely a Halloween knock off, Friday the 13th had enough charm and personality to make a mark of its own on the horror genre. The imitator soon became the imitated.With its abandoned summer camp location, we really get a sense of isolation and vulnerability that was missing from the house lined streets of Haddonfield, Illinois. The film also played around with a "who done it?" mystery. Of course when the killer is revealed, it's a total cop out because it comes completely out of nowhere. Since they don't harp on searching for the identity of the killer, it's almost forgivable. While the characters themselves are nothing noteworthy, their demises are what put this one on the map. The effects are really good and shows even this early on that Tom Savini knows his stuff, like the throat slit, axe in the head and the epic head chopped off.The acting, well for me Betsy Palmer (Mrs Voorhees) completely steals the show, even though she only shows up in the last 15-20 minutes, she commands your attention during her too short screen time and you can see that she is having a fun time tearing up the screen. And of course we have superstar in the making Kevin Bacon giving a likable performance as one of the fodder and follows other stars like (Tom Hanks "He Knows You're Alone", Jamie Lee Curtis "Halloween", Holly Hunter "The Burning", Johnny Depp "A Nightmare On Elm Street" and so on..) making they're names in slasher movies and going on to greater things. Adrienne King does a fine job as the first final girl Alice with what she was given and really gave her all during the finale.All in all Friday The 13th is the one that started it all and a welcome addition and a must see for all fans of slasher.

Friday the 13th was released in 1980 and was produced and directed by (Sean S. Cunningham) who had previously worked with another infamous horror movie producer and director (Wes Craven) on the horror/exploitation movie The last house on the left (1972).Friday the 13th was a massive success making over thirty million dollars against a $580.000 budget and was number one at the box office for several months during it's long run in theatre's. Due to the success of this small, low budget slasher movie the 1980s became over saturated with horror/slasher movies that wanted to capitalise on the horror movie craze some went on to become classics like the Nightmare on elm street franchise but for every good movie that was made there was about fifty bad ones until every movie in the genre became tired and predictable until the genres revival with (Wes Cravens) Scream in 1996.Friday the 13th is by no means a great movie it's script is crap and it's about as low budget a movie as you can get but it is good at being an entertaining slasher movie that takes the simple idea of a killer running around a summer camp trying to get revenge for her son drowning in the camps lake and makes it a fun and bloody mess that sees a bunch of teenagers being killed off one by one in bloody and interesting ways until their's only one survivor left usually a young woman who defeats the killer until the sequel.Friday the 13th has a great cast of actor's and actresses including a young Kevin Bacon, Adrienne King and Betsy Palmer. The practical effects were done by the legendary special effects artist Tom Savini who helped make a number of slasher movies including Friday the 13th part 4 and the Burning.Upon it's release Friday the 13th was panned by critics and was labelled as nothing more than a low budget exploitation movie that would soon be forgotten but because of it's success we got ten sequels one cross over with Freddy Vs Jason and one remake so whether or not you think this movie is good or bad it's still a fun movie and remains a classic in the genre for a reason.
Not scary and not that interesting. Very plain and uneventfull. This is probably one of the least interesting iconic 80's horror movie. All in all, more just iconic than good.4/10: nope.

Review title: Just For The Hack (And Stalk, AND Slash) Of It
Review_body: John Carpenter's classic 1978 horror/suspense film HALLOWEEN, which involved teenagers at the mercy of an escaped maniac in a small Illinois town, was such a huge critical and box office success that it eventually had an unfortunate side effect on the entire horror genre that has gone on virtually unchecked for the last three and a half decades. It spawned an endless series of films in which young, nubile teenagers are placed in isolated settings, often engaging one another in illicit sexual situations, only to be hacked up in endlessly graphic and gory ways by a madman. Granted, we had those in some form or another well before HALLOWEEN, and indeed, one could say this began with Hitchcock's PSYCHO in 1960, going through to the 1971 Mario Bava film TWITCH OF THE DEATH NERVE (probably this film's true progenitor) and culminating in the ultra-controversial 1974 opus THE Texas CHAINSAW MASSACRE. But those films had a great deal of energy behind them, and a lot of thought; and even in a film like CHAINSAW, less blood was actually spilled than what everyone said. After HALLOWEEN, most films of this time were concerned with dismemberment, stalking, slashing, axing, and the like, all with both eyes on the mighty box office dollar.Into this breach stepped director Sean S. Cunningham (who helped produce Wes Craven's 1972 cult film THE LAST HOUSE ON THE LEFT) with the original Friday THE 13TH, released in 1980.The basic plot point is that Camp Crystal Lake in New Jersey has been re-opened after two decades, where a boy named Jason Voorhees drowned in the lake as a result of negligence by the camp counselors. A new set of teens have arrived to revive a traditional summer ritual there, which inevitably involves a lot of sexual fooling around. Over the ensuing fifty to sixty minutes following this set-up, those same kids get chopped up, eviscerated, and dismembered in dozens of admittedly inventive, but invariably gory and violent ways—ways that would be repeated in the dozen or so films in the series that followed, and the dozens upon dozens of other films (A NIGHTMARE ON ELM STREET; SCREAM; SAW; HOSTEL) that have come since this film came out. In the end, there is only one of them still alive, played by Adrienne King, the only one of the teens not to engage in the kind of sexual activity that led to her friends' untimely demises. But when she meets up with a seemingly kindly woman (Betsy Palmer), she actually meets up with the real killer, since Palmer is the vengeance-seeking mother of the kid that drowned there.This last part is perhaps the most inventive of the film, since, unlike the subsequent sequels that involve Jason and his hockey-mask disguise, it his deranged mother (a la Mrs. Bates in PSYCHO) that does the killing, though, wisely, Palmer doesn't show her stark-raving-bonkers side until it's absolutely necessary. And some of the daytime scenes of Crystal Lake have the feel of the 1972 John Boorman classic DELIVERANCE, itself something of a horror film. But the basic point of Friday THE 13TH's existence is the extremely graphic violence that ensues; and whatever atmosphere and suspense the film otherwise has is abandoned a little more than halfway through for the blood and gore and guts.Friday THE 13TH does boast an early appearance by Kevin Bacon as one of the teens involved; indeed, he was the only one of them who went on to bigger and much better things. And no review of this film would be complete without mentioning the graphic make-up effects of Tom Savini, who worked on DAWN OF THE DEAD in 1978. But in the end, all of this does not, to my mind, make Friday THE 13TH a classic of the horror genre in the manner of PSYCHO, or HALLOWEEN. It is good enough for a rating of six out of ten, but I have to say that's as far as I'm willing to go. In general, the slasher/mad-dog killer genre that this helped accelerate, with a scant few exceptions, has done a lot of damage to the credibility of the horror genre.

Friday the 13th is a classic slasher film, a horror cult film, it brought Jason Voorhees and his mother Pamela Voorhees to the horror cinema. The script is simple but effective, a summer camp is reopened by a group of teenagers, a serial killer looking for revenge is killing them one by one, this plotline is imitated even today but without the creepy feeling of Friday the 13th. Kevin Bacon a big Hollywood actor did one of this first roles here! The camp's atmosphere is cool, creepy and loneliness. The film also brought a new scream queen: Adrienne King, a young actress with great lungs. Tom Savini made great and gory makeup effects.Friday the 13th opened a franchise, brought an iconic 80's serial killer and the horror of this camp is still working.

Friday the 13th is a fantastic movie i think. It is a good horror movie. This was made in 1980, starring Kevin Bacon. Later on in the years there were more friday the 13th movies. And still there are more to be make. So far there is 11 friday the 13th movies, the latest is called Freddy Vs Jason. I give friday the 13th 10 out of 10.

Friday the 13th is a horror classic that deserves to be seen by all fans of the genre and of legendary serial killer Jason Voorhees. The film is really surprising for its little pretense, however pleasant and interesting result. Before criticizing the film "for this or that", it is worth remembering that it is from the 1980s; "megas" special effects were not yet the custom, nor were the most sophisticated scripting and client-taking techniques. The film really lacks some aspects of rhythm, acting, script; but who cares? Given the magnitude of witnessing "the birth" of serial legend Jason, the piece really lives up to the premise - perhaps one of the most consistent films in the saga. An ode here, mainly, to Betsy Palmer, who embodies a fantastic Pamela Voorhees, worthy of being remembered for generations to come.Film viewed on the 29th to the 30th of August 2021.

In 1957 a young boy named Jason Voorhees drowned at Camp Crystal Lake then a year later some camp counselors were horribly murdered. Now in 1979, it seems the camp is about to reopen thanks to a new owner named Steve (Peter Brower) with other counselors working on rebuilding the place. However a homicidal maniac is stalking them and killing each one of them one by bloody one until one survives to reveal the true killer.Co-starring Betsy Palmer, Kevin Bacon, Adrienne King, Robbin Morgan, Harry Crosby and Mark Nelson, this shocking slasher epic was created by Victor Miller who wrote the screenplay and Sean S. Cunningham who produced, created the concept and directed this movie. The film is influenced by Camp Fire legends including the legend of Cropsy which later was made as "The Burning" and also influenced by movies like "Twitch of the Death Nerve" (a.k.a. Bay of Blood), "Halloween", "Psycho" and even "Black Christmas". The film was done on a low budget from Georgetown productions which later got distributed by Paramount in the U.S. and Canada while Warner in foreign countries, made in late 1979 to early 1980 then released on June 13th 1980 it became a big hit. In fact it became one of the highest grossing movies of the year despite bad reviews from critics that some have declared it as a "Halloween" knock-off but this movie is quite different from "Halloween" but more of a mystery type of horror flick with slasher clichés in it. This movie spawned 11 sequels, imitators and a upcoming reboot in the works! although Jason Voorhees wasn't the true killer in this movie but does show up in a couple of sequences he wasn't the true killer of the series until the sequels.Tom Savini's make-up effects including his gore are still quite shocking as they had disgusted and frightened the hell out of people. Harry Manfredini's score is quite chilling yet very "Psycho"-esque and the climax is still scary as it today.The beginning of a great slasher series that would bring the big slasher era of the 80's to now including "A Nightmare on Elm Street".

Review title: in the top three of the most scariest in the series
Review_body: the first friday the 13th is in the top three of the most scariest,but not the most entertaining. if this movie was more entertaining. it could've been one of the best all around in the series. also the characters in this movie are pretty much cardboard cut-outs. but it's still very scary,and bloody. i give friday the 13th **1/2 out of ****

And it is surprisingly special and creepy, it terrifies us with an unknown killer creeping around the edges of the camp, but there really isn't much to these characters besides their potential to get killed, which makes it more satisfying to see them killed.Well I guess Ned is memorable for being such an idiot, and Adrienne King lends final girl Alice a strength that really comes out in the final fight, all in all, this movie is a horror classic, and I highly recommend it.

Friday the 13th, starring Adrienne King, Betsy Palmer and Kevin Bacon, is still a great horror flick.The plot is simple, teens move into Camp Crystal Lake, aka "Camp Blood", to open it again. The one problem is a maniacal killer is knocking them off one by one.This movie is very pleasing in a lot of ways. First there are plenty of gory kills and frights. Second is the infamous, Ki Ki Ki Ma Ma Ma and third the plot twist at the end is pretty good. Many people hate this movie but I still love it. This movie managed to spawn 10 sequels.Definite 4/5.

Here I sit at the age of 24 and had yet to see ANY of the Friday The 13th films!  If I'm going to claim to be a movie buff, then I really ought to see these films.  So, today I watched the first in the series, "Friday the 13th".  I don't know why it has taken me so long to watch these films, I guess it's because I'm not a huge fan of horror movies, and these film just didn't appeal to me.  Well, enough about my life story, let's get to the movie review.I have to admit that I was pleasantly surprised with this film.  I expected a really cheesy movie with a horrible plot and a bunch of mindless killing. Ok, well maybe the film IS just that, but it certainly wasn't as cheesy as I thought it would be and the plot was actually quite interesting and actually made sense.  Even now, 22 years after it's release, it's still a scary movie, I found myself jumping a few times throughout the film.The actors were pretty good I suppose, the only one that I recognized and knew by name was Kevin Bacon.  It was really cool to see him at such a young age and in one of his first films.  The rest of the cast was fine, pretty much what you would expect from a movie like this.SPOILER ALERT!!!One thing that really surprised me about this film was that Jason Vorhees wasn't even really in the movie!  He was very important to the story, but he wasn't a main character.  What shocked me even more is that there was no trace of a hockey mask throughout the film.  I thought that was a staple for all the films, like Freddy's glove in The Nightmare on Elm Street films. Anyhow, I was shocked to learn this fact.  Maybe I'll see the hockey mask in the next film?END OF SPOILERSIf you like horror films, then you should definitely see this film!  This is a classic horror film, and so many other films reference "Friday the 13th", so you really ought to know what they're talking about when they make a reference to it.  If you do end up seeing the film, I hope you enjoy it. Thanks for reading,-Chris

The day he came home! Oh no! It's Jason! J-J-J-J-Jas-s-s-son. This movie is definitely a classic, good or bad. Mainly bad but I kind of liked it. I'm not a huge fan of horror films, all I know that The Shining is the best horror film and The Exorcist the scariest. Back then this film scared me but now it doesn't at all. Review title: Where is the point in all the sequels?
Review_body: This really should score a zero. Have a flashback scene, a summer camp in the 1950's, some people get killed. Have a graphic saying present day (1 saying it was 1980 might have helped?) A guy is trying to get an old summer kids camp started up. his various staff get killed one by one, starting with the cook. We get down to 1 girl left and this is nearly 2 hours into the movie then the plot is finally explained. "Oh, I'm Mrs Voorhees. Jason's mum. Jason died by drowning because camp attendants weren't paying attention. In the 1950's" and this has WHAT to do with a bunch of people starting up the same camp 30 yrs later, exactly? They didn't kill him! Mrs. Voorhees tries to kill the last girl alive & generally shows she's a mental psycho bitch. Then the girl manages to cut the woman's head off. Fake ending with crap and predictable scare. Real ending with girl going on about dead boy thinking he's alive.Now how did they get 1 sequel out of that ending?The film is utter garbage. Possibly the busiest person in the crew was the sound man. Every time their in an interior and moving stuff the sound is SO loud! Kevin Bacon in a forgettable role, nice death scene but how did he & the girl he was screwing miss a dead man 4ft above their heads?This film gets a zero.So bad it's worse than "Best Defense" & "Ishtar" - AVOID!

Review title: A Cult Classic With Hit or Miss Results
Review_body: For almost 40 years, Friday the 13th has been praised by many as a horror movie classic, if only for its surprising twist ending and not much else. As such, it spawned over 11 sequels, a couple of reboots, and even a crossover between Freddy Krueger from the Nightmare on Elm Street series, so its status on pop culture is certainly admirable. In terms of what I think of it, while I don't consider it that great of a film, it does its job well enough with what it needed to do, if not perfectly.The basic storyline revolves around six new camp counselors at Camp Crystal Lake, which was previously closed 22 years prior after an unresolved murder case of a little boy occurred. While the new owner Steve Christy tries restoring the camp on the night of Friday the 13th with the aforementioned counselors, a mysterious killer starts to roam around murdering most of them one by one. By that plot alone, there is a direct influence from John Carpenter's "Halloween", as writer Victor Miller crafts the film's plot around the night where teens become at mercy towards an unknown serial killer. Even though the plot itself does drag on at points and it's not hard to predict who dies, the general stakes turn the film into a suspenseful thrill ride, and once we reach the famous climax, all these murders add up fantastically.In addition, the usage of slashing is very effective, as the kill count practically completes the suspense with Tom Savini's wonderful makeup effects, with some rather unique ways to murder teens. The set pieces themselves are remarkably well done, especially when it comes to the usage of lighting and shadows that paint the visuals with the right amount of fear more than the story does. While not the most original sounding music, the score also helps build tension whenever a certain character is about to get the axe. It is admirable to see a horror movie shot on a rather low budget, since they never go overboard with effects, scares, or even sets; they just perform with what little resources they have and go nuts with them.However, with everything the film gets right, there are some notable issues it has that bog it down from being special. Most of the acting, while not terrible, leaves much to be desired, as many of the actors either phone it in or are just underwhelming. The only notable exceptions would have to be Adrienne King for delivering the most genuine frightened performance in the whole feature, and Betsy Palmer for combining sweetness and insanity into one. Also, the counselors are pretty annoying when it comes to their shenanigans, and even their deaths take longer to happen than one might think. Lastly, while I get that the ending was clearly sequel bait, it does leave much questioning to those who have just watched this film for the first time, as it comes off as more confusing rather than startling.Needless to say, while by no means a perfect film, I do think the original Friday the 13th succeeds enough in what it was meant to do: thrill teenagers with shocking scares and a horrific payoff. Even if the film isn't without its flaws, it's nonetheless impressive to see a simple slasher flick that was inspired by Halloween become almost as if not more successful by franchise than the aforementioned classic. If you are still yet to see the film, give it a watch and judge whether you think it holds up or not. I know I have many more sequels to get to, so this one was a decent start to a beloved franchise for me.

Review title: set the conventions of the slasher film!
Review_body: Hugely successful slasher flick that set the standard for the genre and opened the flood gates for numerous imitators.The sinister reputation of a New Jersey summer camp is about to continue as an elusive murderer begins to stalk the new counselors.Friday the 13th (along with Carpenter's superior Halloween) became the film that all other slasher movies would be compared to. This was the movie that really set all the conventions and the clichés that would come to stereotype the slasher film genre. Friday' has them all, attractive young teens, woodsy setting, teen sex, and of course bloody murders. To say it's a clichéd film by today's standards is perfectly true, but it's also a good clichéd film. Director Sean Cunningham delivers plenty of atmospheric darkness, with the isolated settings and the raging thunderstorm and full moon images. The film builds tension very well, gives some terrific moments of stark suspense and shock. Make up FX master Tom Savini lends his talents in creating some very gory murders. Kudos also go to Harry Manfredini for his spooky score.The cast's performances are mainly mediocre, with the exception of Palmer who does a bravo performance in the films climax.Friday the 13th is a film that will always be praised by slasher fans and for good reason. It is a well-done slasher, even by today's standards.Followed by a total of 10 inferior sequels!!*** out of ****
Firstly it's the 80's so you can never compare this to modern day slashers. It's stapled itself as a Halloween classic and what more would you want to watch on Halloween.

Friday the 13th (1980, Dir. Sean S. Cunningham) On camp crystal lake, a group of young counsellors begin to get ready to lead guests in the summer. Unfortunately, for the hormone racing counsellors, someone isn't happy about what's going on in the camp. Someone enjoys playing 'kill the counsellor'. As bodies fall to the ground, no one is safe in camp crystal lake.If you asked someone to name as many famous horror icons they can think of, you would always hear Jason Vorhees mentioned. Jason Vorhees, the hockey masked, machete wielding killer from the 'Friday the 13th' series. Well, this film starts the legend off in a camp but creepy way. It's a horror movie from 1980, so you can expect all the usual ingredients. Interesting horror icon, young stars, over acting and some fake incidents. The cast is pretty forgettable, with the exception of Betsy Palmer and a very young Kevin Bacon. The acting is quite laughable, and some of the choices the characters make, really make you think why they would even attempt it. The violence is a mixed bag. Some incidents look OK compared to todays standards, whilst others look just plain fake. Although, Jason hardly appears in this movie, this is what kicks it all off, and definitely has to be watched."Think you're gonna last all summer?" - Bill (Harry Crosby) "I don't know if i'm gonna last all week." - Alice (Adrienne King)

In 1980, two years after "Halloween" scared the hell out of everybody, "Friday the 13th" was released to theaters. This was a clever knockoff of the John Carpenter horror classic, only this one was more violent and gruesome. That aspect turned critics off big time. But moviegoers couldn't resist. They flocked to see this movie and made it a big hit. I never saw this film on the big screen because I was only 9 years old when it came out. After I saw it on cable a few years later, it scared the hell out of me! It doesn't scare me that much today, but it's a far more effective horror/thriller than the last five movies in the series (parts 5 through 9). They should have stopped making these "Friday the 13th" movies after the fourth film, which was subtitled "The Final Chapter". And you know what's even scarier, they're making part 10. "Friday the 13th" was the beginning of the sick slasher genre that played out during the early 1980s. The first films in both the "Halloween" and "Friday the 13th" series' were easily the best. "Halloween" was a great horror film. "Friday the 13th" isn't up there with "Halloween", but it's a well-crafted gorefest.*** (out of four)

A few weeks ago, it happened to be Friday the 13th, and to celebrate the occassion, I finally got around to watching this movie. It is often considered one of the best and most iconic in the horror genre, and has spawned numerous sequels, spinoffs, and video games. After seeing it, I can now conclude it's a little too gory for me, but also manages to be pretty slow moving, plot-wise. I feel one of the reasons why this movie has gotten so much recognition over the years is simply because its plot is very easy to understand, so it can appeal to more people. It begins with a flashback to the 1950s where we see two camp counselors being murdered by some unknown attacker. It then fast forwards to the late 70s, and a fellow counselor named Annie wants to find directions to Camp Crystal Lake. The locals tell her it is allegedly cursed because of all the bad things and murders that happened there many years ago. Additionally, a young kid drowned in the camp's lake in 1957, adding to the macabre reputation. Annie is later killed after being dropped off from an unknown driver's car. Meanwhile at the camp, there are many counselors gathered together, the main one is usually considered to be Alice (Adrienne King). They are discussing how to best renovate the camp for its reopening, when suddenly a bad storm hits and a string of murders happen afterwards, suspiciously similar to the brutal ones that happened in the 50s. Eventually, Alice is the only one still alive and finds herself fighting for her life as her friends are suddenly killed one by one. When it's quiet, she fears the killer the most. Eventually, a car pulls up to the cabin Alice is hiding in and out steps an older woman with a rather harmless appearance. She introduces herself as Mrs. Voorhees, the mother of the boy who drowned in the lake 2 decades earlier. As it turns out, she's the one who has been killing everybody for the death of her son. She eternally hates the camp counselors for being so negligent about the camp's safety precautions, and starts to attack Alice. Following a long and drawn out fight, Alice grabs an axe and decapitates Mrs. Voorhees. Being the only surviving counselor, she takes a nearby canoe and drifts out onto the middle of the lake. The daylight comes, the cops arrive, and it appears that she is now safe. All of a sudden out of nowhere, a horrific looking, decomposed kid lunges out of the water and pulls her under with him. The first time I saw this, I felt my heart jump into my mouth. As the movie nears completion and Mrs. Voorhees is revealed to be the main villain, you finally think that Jason is not in it. Unfortunately, Alice wakes up in the hospital shortly after and is questioned by police, which means Jason didn't actually kill her. This is immensely disappointing to me because the last scene on the lake is deeply disturbing, and it would have made the film much creepier to end it right at that moment. I don't know what they were thinking. Overall, Friday the 13th is one of the most infamous horror movies, but this first one is just mediocre in my opinion. It's slow moving, has a disappointing ending, and doesn't even feature the recognizable hockey mask Jason (who wouldn't appear until like the 3rd movie). It still deserves attention for starting a whole series, but I don't feel Friday the 13th should have ended the way it did.

Like practically everybody else, I've seen this movie before. Many times. But I've never watched it with the intention of documenting my thoughts before.
This movie is okay. It's not as good as, perhaps, it could've been, but it's an hour and a half of campy horror fun. It's got all those bad 80s effects, the hit-and-miss acting (with the exception of Betsy Palmer, who absolutely steals the show).
My initial thoughts after this rewatch are lukewarm. It certainly served its purpose and it held my interest, but I'm really not sure after watching it again if it was really worthy of a franchise. This film is complete enough in itself: it's got the slasher elements that we've come to expect from these kinds of movies, and it has a light-heartedly unexplained ending that leaves the audience wanting more. And, really, that's what a good one-off horror film ought to do. The more you show the monster, the more you demystify it. This movie leaves us with enough to the imagination to really appreciate who Jason is, what happened to him, and what his (his mother's?) motives might have been.
I've never seen the vast majority of the sequels. I will be watching some over the next few days as part of the Halloween 2019 rewatch.

Review title: 6 stars plus 1 for starting a great franchise
Review_body: Let's face it. This movie is ok. Of course if you'd seen it in the theatres when it came out, I can see it getting a higher score. Rewatching it now for the first time in probably 30 years, it doesn't hold up well. Some bad acting and effects, but the start of a fun series that I'd still watch more of. It's amazing what can be done on a low budget these days.
