Review title: Helped bring horror to the mainstream
Review_body:
This is the story of a series of murders at a summer camp. If you have never seen this movie, then that is about all I can say without anything that might be a spoiler.
Now sure, there were plenty of horror movies prior to Friday the 13th, but for some reason it feels as though this was the one that pushed the genre to the more mainstream status. I saw this on HBO when it first came out. That means it was either 1980 or 81, I am not sure of the exact date. That means I was either 7 or 8. I remember it vividly, I was laying on the floor with our giant floor pillow, yes that was a thing back then. I don't think I made in three minutes into the movie before it freaked me out. It was nothing visual that did it, but the "Ki ki ki, ma ma ma" that did it. After rejoining the rest of my family on the couch I sat back and enjoyed a great horror flick, though for some reason I believe that HBO toned down the violence back then. I have a clear memory of the screen flashing to bright white light at each kill, and not showing much of the gore. This is the movie that started me on my horror watching life.

Quite impressive picture with only some dirt on the print. The sound isn't that great and lacks definition but who cares as this is a great slasher film! It was strong enough to start a legacy but there is little here that the legacy is famous for. Reminiscent of Halloween (1978) but changes the formula to be more fun. It has kitsch value and cheap thrills. The gore is excellent, like really nasty. My favourite are the first four. The start of a franchise but it isn't the best in the series, greatness awaits

The original. The myth. The cultural phenomenon. The beginning.Everybody knows Jason, Everybody knows Crystal Lake and a lot of horror troupes started here, let's not even talk about the numerous copycats with basically the same scenario and group of people.Probably it's not the best of the series (I will be revisiting all of them) and I personally prefer slashers that are not filmed in the killer's view (well, we don't even have the "real Jason" here!), but this a really well executed film, considering the basic plot, the budget, the limitations and the basic original material behind. Forget the critics, most of the time they just follow trends.I couldn't finish without mentioning the score. I'm not one of those who thinks that the best horror was on the 70s/80s, there are very good (and in much more quantity) films out there nowadays. However, I believe that the best scores and the best using of audio to create tension was definitely there.

I've seen this twice. Once in the early 1980s once in 2021.It is reasonably entertaining and sometimes scary but even Prom Night and My Bloody Valentine are probably more effective.On first viewing I felt it had similarities to Halloween (1978) with an ending borrowed from Carrie (1976). Now I also see similarities to The Texas Chainsaw Massacre (1974) - the chase scenes and the helpful older person that meets the heroine - and Black Christmas (1974).The music seems copied from the Psycho score.The cast are attractive and all pretty likable. All the guys are shown shirtless for extended scenes painting and chopping wood, and in Speedos and Daisy Dukes. The film kind of limps along with a few random scenes of the youngsters goofing off but we never really get a feeling for their character. So half the time you're confused about who is who. Then when they get killed there's no real emotional response because you never got to know the character anyway.Some of the deaths are tense in the moments before. Sometimes we see a graphic bloody death. The effects look pretty decent. In the early 1980s they seemed very bloody but by today's standards it is not that gruesome. But half the murders are off screen - we just see the body later. That seems like a waste of a character / murder. Why kill a character in a horror if we do not see the suspense in the lead up to it, or the kill itself? The goofy prank guy Ned could easily have been cut from the film and his antics and silly lines given to Kevin Bacon's character and no one would have noticed as the kids are all so generic. As it is Ned just disappears early on (killed off screen) and no one seems to notice he is missing.The character of Steve too could have been cut and some of his lines given to Bill no problem. Why did they include the diner bit and all those driving scenes and hitchhiking with Steve? All pointless and led nowhere. Maybe we were meant to think he was the killer? If so that angle didn't really work.Lacking the slickness of Halloween means the suspense here just doesn't build as well. In Halloween, the viewer knows there is a masked homicidal maniac on the loose, sees them, and knows who it is. That makes it scarier.This film added the whodunnit angle which many subsequent slashers continued.The location looks great and is well used.

This here is one of the best horror movies, Starring Betsy Palmer, Adrienne King, Harry Crosby, and Laurie Bartram Although the movie itself may not be my favorite, it laid the blueprints for one of my favorite series' of all time. I don't know why people refer to Friday the 13th as being a knock-off of Halloween, but it definitely is not. First off, Mrs. Voorhees is not immortal like Michael Myers. Also, we do not see that she is the killer until the end, whereas Halloween reveals it in the beginning. There is also much more gore in this movie than in Halloween. Also, this movie has much more 'scare value' than Halloween. For one thing, it doesn't take 20 minutes to set up a death scene like it does in Halloween. In Halloween, it'll show the victim for about 20 minutes then finally they'll be stalked for a little then killed. This movie, it'll show the people randomly but you wont really know if they're being stalked until the killer shows up and kills them. Another thing this movie has over Halloween, it takes place in the woods. This automatically makes it much more eerie than a quiet suburb. Anyone who says this movie is a copy of Halloween should be killed by Mrs Voorhees. If they had even taken the time to watch the commentary from director Sean S. Cunningham, he even says he used to make children's videos and all of that then one day decided to make a new type of movie. I don't think he would just copy a movie in its entirety. Sure, maybe he got the basic 'slasher' idea from Halloween, but thats it. If anything, Halloween later copies Friday the 13th in that it becomes a series of sequels. The only Halloween that has any unique character is the 3rd one, because it doesn't copy Friday the 13th by being yet another sequel of the same story. Over all, I like this movie much more than Halloween. Recommend for anyone looking for a late-night scare.

Review title: ki ki ki, ma ma ma
Review_body: Once upon a time, Camp Crystal Lake was an idyllic retreat to which the wealthy and beautiful sent their children. But one summer, a young boy drowned all alone in the lake and no one came to help him. The camp counselors who should have been watching him were off making out and engaging in fornication instead of doing their job. Thus, someone killed the camp counselors with a very large knife and Camp Crystal Lake was closed down. It became known as Camp Blood in local legend, a haunted and forsaken place where no one in their right mind would go. But in the late 1970s, a well meaning group of fresh, new camp counselors decided to reopen Camp Crystal Lake and restore it to its former glory. Despite dire warnings from a bicycle riding nutball, the young people set about fixing up the campsite and enjoying the beauty of another summer. However, a mysterious someone is hunting down and killing the young people one by one in horribly brutal ways. Finally, only the innocent Alice is left alive. Will she survive her confrontation with the vengeful Crystal Lake Killer?I absolutely love the Friday the 13th series and I'm not really sure why. They're all pretty dumb and predictable; horny teens/20somethings go to Camp Crystal Lake or close enough as to make no difference, have sex, get murdered and the Last Virginal Good Girl saves the day. Sometimes they replace the girl with a guy, or they move the action from the lake to Somewhere Else, wow! It's like watching someone set up a row of clay pigeons for someone else to blow to smithereens. This movie followed hard upon the heels of Halloween, and ended up being the more popular series due mostly to the character of Jason Voorhees. I'm not sure why Jason is the preferred masked madman; Michael Meyers had the exact same M.O. as Jason, but seems to lack something in comparison. Myself, I think he lacks sympathy. Jason Voorhees, an ugly, deformed little kid, cruelly ridiculed by his fellow camp goers at Crystal Lake, was left to drown a slow, terrifying death in the lake all alone, whilst the camp counselors were off making out. We can feel for Jason; we've all been that ugly little kid left to sink or swim on our own at one time or another. So hell yeah, I'm going to root for the ugly little nerd who returns a huge, muscle-bound bruiser wielding a machete. Go Jason, go!We can further sympathize with Jason in all the sequels that follow due mostly to the fact that it is NOT Jason doing all the brutal murders in this first installment, but rather his mother, a deranged and probably guilt ridden woman (where the hell was SHE when her baby was drowning, huh?) with a warped maternal instinct. One doubts that Jason could have received much love and nurturing from her, yet he remains loyal to her even after death. Jason may be a mute, masked, machine-like hulk, but at some point, he was human and it wasn't his fault that he became what he did...unlike Michael Meyers who was evil from the beginning.Anyway, that's my theory as to why this film was so incredibly popular and continues to spawn sequels to this day. It's all due to Jason Voorhees, because otherwise, all there is to this film is a bunch of dim-bulb kids, running around half dressed (sometimes in the rain), looking for places to screw and alcohol to drink, and presenting such a one-dimensional view of selfish youth that you don't give a damn when the ax rams into their face, or the knife pushes up through their jugular. Who cares? They weren't contributing much anyway, and they aren't anywhere near as interesting, complex or sympathetic as the tortured, eternal child, Jason.

Review title: Having sex = Being hacked to death !!!
Review_body: To call the characters paper thin will be an understatement. They are just meant to be in the film to get killed off one by one. I could go crazy with my interpretive brain and propose that film is trying to explore the friction between the conflicting ideologies of conservatism and the sexual liberation movement that gained strength during the 1960s and 1970s. But in reality, the film just isn't deep enough to be thought of along those lines. In reality, there is no subtext. The ultimate revelation is abrupt which ruins the credibility of everything that happens before, and the final combat scenes are downright laughable. One can easily feel that both the director Sean S. Cunningham and screenwriter Victor Miller were huge Hitchcock fans. In terms of writing, the ultimate revelation owes a heavy debt to 'Psycho'. The only thing that I genuinely liked about the film was Cunningham's visual style which again owes a heavy debt to Hitchcock. The camera acts as a voyeur. There are some scenes in which it almost feels like we are watching everything from an anonymous individual's POV. I especially liked the way Cunningham used extended long takes in certain scenes to build up tension. He constantly delays the prospect of any character confronting a dead body in the film. But when it does happen, it is done with a really well executed setup and I found that whole sequence impressive. Talking about Hitchcock, the score that accompanies the scenes of terror and murder in 'Friday the 13th' is basically a rip-off of Bernard Herrmann's 'The Murder' score from 'Psycho'.'Friday the 13th' is not deep nor is it trying to be. The characters are a bunch of nobodies. The ultimate revelation and combat scene is laughable. But I'll be lying if I say I didn't somewhat like the direction and the use of camera movements in the film.

When it comes to name recognition of a horror film and franchise, Friday the 13th is probably near the top and to many is considered the first film is considered a masterpiece in the slasher genre. The original also really stands out as its own movie compared to all of its predecessor's due tone and the ending reveal. Aside from some great scenes and an excellent suspenseful finish, the writing produced some cheesy lines and unlikeable characters from top to bottom. Adrienne King's scream queen character, Alice, was never captivating on screen with delivery and appearance. Friday the 13th is an above average film that struck gold at the right time with its promiscuous message and kicking off the popular slasher genre.

Review title: Interesting how nostalgia can distort one's point of view....
Review_body: I'm not sure how this film qualifies as an "original" seeing that's it's premise was openly, admittedly borrowed from other more superior films like "Halloween" (style, little splatter) and "Black Christmas" (mood, style, some splatter).The only thing Friday I "pioneered" was the stringing together of many successive "uniquely clever" kills with virtually little or no character development or plot and plenty of ultra-cheap production. Yes, all films want to make money on some level but Friday I and Sean Cunningham in particular never pretended to be about anything else.It's not a complete disaster, and it's not boring. There are good sequences. The suggestions to watch this one with lights off is a good one. Firstly, because the photography is so muddy and the direction so middling, you will need every bit of darkness around you to shed light on the screen. Secondly, it will lend the film a bit more credibility as a thriller (in all fairness, it has a few good jump-in-your-seat moments). Thirdly, when someone comes in the room and starts laughing at you for watching it, you will be harder to see.For those who can't tell the difference between art and commerce...probably few people under the age of 35 at this writing... it's passable and definitely why we've been getting a diet of (for the most part) the same in Horror flicks for years since.

Review title: The one that started it all.
Review_body: Friday the 13th tells the story of a group of camp councilors fixing up an abandoned summer camp so it can reopen. The camp has seen rough times in the past. In 1958, a young boy by the name of Jason Voorhees drowned there. In 1959, two camp councilors were murdered there. There were several attempts to open the camp back up, but it was met with arson and poisoned water. Now it looks like the death curse is back, because the group of renovators is being slaughtered one by one.Friday the 13th has become so famous for the following reasons. Its endless sequels, and the fad it started. You can't say that it started the slasher movie craze because it was preceded by Psycho, Black Christmas, Texas Chainsaw Massacre, and Halloween. However, it did start the craze of cheap 80's slasher movies that no one seemed to mind had bad acting, plots, and special effects. These rip offs included Prom Night, Sleepaway Camp, and Slumber Party Massacre. The acting in Friday the 13th isn't anything spectacular, although it was Kevin Bacon's claim to fame. The special effects aren't that great either. However, Friday the 13th did utilize many of the typical slasher movie formulas such as using point of view shots for the killer, having one woman live to tell the tale, and partying teens.Friday the 13th is entertaining if you're looking for a fun movie to watch in the dark on a Friday night, but it's not a movie that should be taken seriously.5.5/10

Director Sean S Cunningham took a stab at cashing in on the success of John Carpenter and does a pretty fair job in this atmospheric outing.The story is really a part of movie folklore, and 80s pop culture. A handicapped, freakishly disfigured boy named Jason Vorhees is sent to a summer camp, where he dies in a drowning accident while two camp leaders who are supposed to be watching him are committing carnal acts.This inspires Jason's mother to go on a murderous rampage when the campsite re opens, including memorably giving Kevin Bacon an unexpected tracheotomy. Mrs Vorhees being the killer was considered a big twist at the time, though Scream has well and truly taken away that surprise for modern viewers.This is about what you'd expect from a slasher film, horrible acting, basic script, mixed effects and a simple and effective score.The murder scenes on a whole are well laid out, the ending, aiming to set up the sequels, where it is in fact Jason doing the killing, is still effective now.This is an eighties horror film so watch out for nudity and tame sex scenes. But this is one trip to Summer Camp worth revisiting.

Review title: Not the best of the series, but one of the top three or four
Review_body: Why did films like "Friday, the 13th", and others succeed in the eighties while superior slasher films were made in the seventies?  Several reasons are usually given:1.  The rise of the Religious Right ("Reverend" Jerry Fallwell and the "Moral Majority") 2.  The awareness of the spread of AIDS and its consequences. 3.  Major studios after having been taken over by large conglomerates had the "revelation" that cheap films were highly profitable.Why, may be subject to debate, but their success is now the stuff of legend.I do not think the first in this series was the best, I think they got better until they peaked at number five and their success started to attract the attention of the above mentioned "Moral Majority".  This had the MPAA running scared and the threat of an "X" rating caused the studios to back to the point where the violence and sex were curtailed, but the plots did not get any more original.This one managed to be pretty good however, despite the lack of nudity.

Review title: Camp Blood, Are They Opening That Place Up Again?
Review_body: I will never forget the time I saw this movie, I was 8 years old and an active scout who went to camp every summer. This film scared the crap out of me, even though I had seen other films like Halloween, The Omen, Jaws, ETC.; this one had a major effect on me.The movie is about camp counselors who despite the numerous warning about the camp decide to reopen it. All the locals know about it's history; and That's how it received it's nickname Camp Blood. At Crystal Lake everyone is busy and Steve Christy( Peter Bower) needs to go into town to get more supplies.When Steve leaves, I thought he was the the killer at first. When Annie, the camp cook( Robbie Morgan) is trying to get to Crystal Lake. She has to walk the rest of the way. She gets lucky and gets a ride, the vehicle is a jeep. The same color as Steve's. When the jeep passes the camp site, Annie takes a risk and jumps out and into the woods. Soon the killer is right behind her and she ends up getting her throat slashed. So it made me wonder, because he is gone most of the movie.The counselors, Alice( Adrienne King), Bill( Harry Crosby), Jack( Kevin Bacon), Brenda( Laurie Marie Bartram), Ned( Mark Nelson), and Marcie( Jeannie Taylor) are left to get more work done. They blow off work, and enjoy their time while Steve is gone. They are aware of a big storm on the way and time is of the essence.When the rain begins trouble is not far behind. When I watched this the first time the kill scenes were graphic, now I have the uncut version. The difference is the kill scenes are more intense, and I believe some editing mistakes are fixed unlike on the VHS version. One of the most memorial kill scenes is Kevin Bacon's. After he and Marcie have sex, she has to leave to use the bathroom. When he lights a joint he notices blood dripping from the top bunk. All of a sudden a hand holds his forehead down, while an archery bow goes up through his neck. In the uncut version it is more intense, and you see Ned's body in a more close up while thunder and lighting strike. Then there is Marcie's, when she is looking through the showers to see if any of them are hiding; and trying to scare her. You see a shadow of an axe, when she turns the axe comes down through her face.I have to say I'm not a fan of every Friday film of the series, but this has got to be the best one. This is the first time I saw Kevin Bacon in a film and I thought Betsy Palmer's performance as Pamela Voorhees was out standing. Tom Savini make up effect were excellent, because they looked so real, unlike in other horror films. Every slasher film has these rules. Those who have sex, the know it all, and the obnoxious are usually the damned. The one who usually survives all the trauma is the heroic virgin.The movie includes those fears we think about when we are alone in the woods, the watcher across the lake, stalker in the shower/bathroom, and the psycho killer. I have always been a fan of this film, not only does Ron Milkie's character officer Dorf bring some comic relief, but Crazy Ralph sends chills up our spine with his preaching. The showdown between Alice and Mrs. Voorhees is about as graphic as it gets, but having a female heroine is priceless. Adrienne King was excellent at her role. I highly recommend this film to all Friday The 13th Fans and to anyone who loves old school horror. In a way this film has a valuable life lesson; and always be aware of your surroundings.

In 1957, Camp Crystal Lake is closed due to the deaths of two of it's counsellors. Years later, it is due to reopen. But while the new counsellors prepare the camp, an unseen intruder stalks the camp, picking the counsellors off one by one.When John Carpenter's classic "Halloween" came out, the slasher film was born. But while that film created the whole concept of the slasher, in which fun-loving teenagers are stalked & brutally murdered by a masked intruder, it wasn't until two years later that "Friday the 13th" made the concept popular. Indeed it set the standard for a whole heap of imitators & ripoffs, not to mention NINE sequels to date.For all it's success (& a sizable cult following), "Friday the 13th" is a surprisingly crude film. The film was greenlighted before a script was even written, in fact a magazine ad featuring the title smashing through glass was instrumental in getting it off the ground. The script, written in a hurry, is minimalist to an extreme degree. When you think about it, everything in the film is either very stupid or very badly written. The only reason Betsy Palmer's villain gives for going on a killing rampage is the death of her son. If that's the case, if she doesn't want any other child to die, why doesn't she work to establish a safety code for the camp, instead of just killing off all the workers? The acting varies, with the performances ranging from lacklustre to downright bad. The direction consists of stalking scenes patterned after the opening scene of "Halloween", which becomes hard on the eyes after a few seconds. Then there's the score If composer Harry Manfredini thinks that the 'ki, ki, ki, ma, ma, ma' sound is spooky, then he's an idiot. Instead of sounding spooky, it just sounds cheesy & reeks of overkill. Mind you, the film does attain a degree of intensity during the climactic scene, but overdoes it with the shock ending, which does make you jump but is essentially pointless. But for all it's faults, the film remains miles ahead of most of it's sequels.

WARNING: CONTAINS SPOILERS (like it matters) This is the one that started it all, which is amazing, since this is a fairly mediocre movie, even by slasher standards. What set this apart at the time was its realistic and excessively gory special effects (courtesy Tom Savini) which were unlike anything seen in a major studio (Paramount) release. The story is simple: twenty years ago, little Jason Voorhees (supposedly) drowned in the waters of Camp Crystal Lake as a result of negligent camp counselers, who were later murdered. Now, someone is butchering counselers at the very same camp, just before its grand re-opening. Is it the legendary Jason? As we would all soon find out, it's Jason's mother (Betsy Palmer), back to take revenge on a new generation of horny teens for daring to re-open her son's place of death. Apart from the gory effects (axe in the face, arrow through the neck, several slit throats) and one or two decent jolts (particularly the obvious, but effective CARRIE-like finale), this is a rather run-of-the-mill body count movie. There's not even much skin to speak of (other than brief breasts one nude male butt), so it's pretty surprising that this took off the way it did.Still, it's one of the better in the series (not that that's saying much) and you could certainly do worse at the video store on a Saturday night. Kevin Bacon has an early role as one of the counselers. Followed by a ridiculous number of sequels.

First of all, this movie was more of revenge-suspense drama and not horror. The main idea of this film came only after "The Halloween (1978)". The acting was less than satisfactory. Actors could've done a lot better. It took a little too long getting going. It was the last half hour when the main screaming and offscreen killings and action happened. Some of the fighting and action was cheesy and kinda funny. Overall, it is famous for giving character like Jason but this part was not that good. It could have been much better.

A group of counselors who are attempting to reopen a camp, where a young boy drowned in 1957, are murdered by an unknown killer. Someone appears to be seeking revenge.This did well at the box office and if you are a fan of slasher films then you will like it. However, the plot is weak and it is simply a blood bath. Stars Betsy Adams with an early appearance by Kevin Bacon.

Review title: One Of The Greatest Horror Films Ever Made. An Excellent,Scary,And Suspenseful Horror Classic.
Review_body: Friday The 13th is one of greatest Horror films ever made,an excellent,scary and suspenseful Horror classic that is filled with great atmospheric direction,a wonderful cast,a creepy and iconic score and amazing special effects. All of those combinations make Friday The 13th a a landmark Horror film and one of the best Slasher movies ever made.Friday The 13th tells the story of a camp called Camp Crystal Lake that was closed down in the 1950s after a boy drowned and two Camp Counselers were murdered by an unknown killer. Over twenty years later,a group of new Camp counselors have come to Camp Crystal lake to help reopen the place. Unfortunately for the counselors they are being stalked and murdered by an unseen killer on Friday The 13th a day where nothing will save them and a day when the Camp will run red with blood.After the critical and box office success of John Carpenter's Horror classic Halloween in 1978,the film spawned many imitators in it's wake two years after which included films such as Prom Night and Terror Train(both in 1980)and many others. But,one of the best Slasher films to come out after Halloween was Friday The 13th(another film that ironically spawned it's own imitators),a scary and terrifying film that was panned by film critics but a Box Office Hit and was the beginning of one of the best and most successful film and Horror movie franchises in in film history and while Friday The 13th doesn't match Halloween on a film making level,Friday The 13th is a great Horror film that has carved it's own place in Horror history. Right from the start,Friday The 13th is an amazing Horror film and is a roller coaster ride that is filled with scares,shocks and terror and is a movie that holds a tight grip on the viewer until the very end and never let's go. What I love about F13 is that the film takes the concept of Halloween and takes from a small town to a camp in the woods where in the woods you are alone and completely isolated from civilization. Also,where as Halloween was just about terror and atmosphere,F13 is a movie was about scares and gore and the scares in F13 are suspenseful and well-done making the viewer feel a sense of dread and fear and is done with great build-up and when the scares happen your heart is racing and when each scare in the film happens the movie becomes more and more intense as it goes and you will feel like no one is safe from death. The kills and gore in F13 is effective and adds to the film because the gory scenes are truly shocking and unexpected giving viewers an uneasy feeling that is felt throughout because the kills and gore are either seen on screen or off. F13 isn't just about blood and gore because the film also has a great,suspenseful atmosphere that is dark,creepy and at times gritty with falling rain,the sights of trees and cabins look realistic and intense making the Camp locations look very frightening. What also makes the atmosphere in F13 great is the killer and the killer's P.O.V and the fact we don't see the killer's face when he or she is stalking the victims hiding in the forest or in the darkest never knowing when the killer is going to strike. F13 and it's style would be imitated by later Slasher film's in the 1980s. The main characters while in a Slasher film are likable and sympathetic and you feel bad for them when things start to go wrong. Where in most of the sequels we are rooting for the killer,in F13 we root the main characters to survive and get out alive. The ending is of the scariest and most surprising endings in movie history and will make you jump out of your seat while also leaving the ending open for many of the sequels. A classic and unforgettable ending.The cast does wonderful jobs in their roles. Betsy Palmer is fantastic as Mrs. Pamela Voorhees,an old friend of Crystal Lake. Adrienne King is wonderful as Alice,with King bringing depth and sweetness to the role. Kevin Bacon(in one of his early film roles)and Jeannie Taylor do great jobs as Jack and Marcie,a couple who are counselors at the camp. Harry Crosby is sensational as Bill,one of the counselors. Laurie Bartram is outstanding as Brenda,a feisty girl. Mark Nelson is funny as Ned,with Nelson bringing Humor to the film. Debbi Morgan is fine and memorable as Annie,another counselor. Peter Brouwer is good as Steve,the head counselor. Walt Gromney is creepy and over the top as Crazy Ralph,an old man that's trying to warn the young counselors. Ronn Carroll(Sgt.Tierney)gives a good performance as well.The direction by Sean Cunningham is great,with Cunningham a dark,creepy and gritty style to the film. Fine direction,Cunningham.The score by Harry Manfredini is brilliant,intense,scary and one of the best and most iconic scores in Horror film history and it truly adds to the film. Amazing score,Manfredini.The special make-up effects by Tom Savini are terrific,gory and realistic and are among Savini's best work as an effects artist. Great effects,Savini.In final word,if you love Horror film or Slasher movies,I highly suggest you see Friday The 13th,one of the greatest Horror films ever made and an excellent,scary and suspenseful Horror classic that deserves to be in every Horror fans movie collection. Highly Recommended. 10/10.

This is a great movie. When I was a child I watched the rest of the series, and as an older teenager saw the original. The ending is SO, SO, SCARY! I dare you to think of a ending on any movie (maybe "Planet of the Apes?) which is more shocking and surprising!!    The notion that this movie has some ethics, intelligence and that it takes place in a wood is also fairly interesting.    The dumb teenagers might cast of some adult viewers though.   Anyway, death is always a good theme since it shows solidarity with those of us who are about to die (and who isn´t?)    Jason Voorhees will to power still prevails and hold true in the darkness of mysterious woods and lakes.    After all, who knows what lurks out there in the American wilderness?   This movie is as ethical as "Animal Liberation" by Peter Singer, as interesting as "Psycho" by Alfred Hitchcok, and as poetic as Walt Whitmans "Leaves of Grass".    The special effects man, Tom Savini, is a genious, and he shows us the horror he himself experienced in the Vietnam War. As he points out, even though he has created the whole setup in the end - he - and the crew - THEY get scared as well everytime they watch it. Obviously no shock in an American horror movie (the Japanese movies "The Ring" and "Dark Water" are far more shocking and scary than any American horror movie thus far, I think) has ever been more effective than the mind-blowing ending to Friday the 13th.

I thought that Friday The 13th was a great horror movie. The film starts in 1958, two summer camp counsellors at Camp Crystal Lake sneak away from a camp fire sing-along to have sex. Before they can completely undress, an unseen person sneaks into the room and murders them both. The film moves forward to 1980; a young woman named Annie (Robbi Morgan) enters a small diner and asks for directions to Camp Crystal Lake, to the shock of the restaurant's staff. A strange old man named Ralph (Walt Gorney) reacts to the news of the camp's reopening by warning Annie that they are "all doomed". Enos (Rex Everhart), a truck driver from the diner, agrees to give Annie a lift to the camp. During the drive, he warns her about the camp, informing her that a young boy drowned in Crystal Lake in 1957,At the camp, the other counsellors, Ned (Mark Nelson), Jack (Kevin Bacon), Bill (Harry Crosby), Marcie (Jeannine Taylor), Alice (Adrienne King), and Brenda (Laurie Bartram) are refurbishing the cabins and facilities along with the camp's owner, Steve Christy (Peter Brouwer. They receive a visit from Ralph, who again warns them that they are "doomed". As a violent storm closes in The unknown killer begins to isolate and murder the counsellors. I Thought that this was a great horror movie. 8/10

Review title: Another Classic Horror Genre, But Ranks A Distant Third To A Nightmare On Elm Street And Halloween.
Review_body: Hard to believe it's the 20th anniversary of this film, I remember growing up to the popularity of this film and it terrified me and many others in their younger years. After just watching it again about an hour ago I finally realized this film no longer scares or frightens and it never really did. Many people thought this film began the horror-slasher film genre, but that began two years earlier in 1978 with Halloween. Friday The 13TH fails to portray their killer as a sociopath (Freddy Kruger) A Nightmare On Elm Street, or a suspense scare the hell out of you knive wielding killer (Michael Myers) Halloween. And the whole point of horror films are to bring out emotions on an audience instead Friday The 13Th brings the rush approach of just killing and killing victims in the woods with no suspense or scares to stir up emotions. True Friday The 13Th is by far an 80's slasher classic and very watchable to any horror film fan, but if your more hard core and want your scares mixed with suspense and emotions then the Nightmare On Elm Street and Halloween series are much better to keep in memory and keepsake.

This film and the subsequent indestructible series that it spawned will never be confused with Shakespeare. That said, some of the earlier entries are fairly effective in their sense of dread and jolts before the entire series devolved into an assembly line of utter trash that fails to even live up to the minor demands of this sub-genre. Following the surprise mammoth success of the original Halloween, movie makers everywhere began vomiting forth holiday themed slasher pictures. Of the imitators, Friday the 13th is certainly notable and was arguably the most successful alongside A Nightmare on Elm Street, which came a few years later. The simple scenario of a group of camp counselors stalked by an unseen predator while undertaking their efforts to re-open a children's camp, dubbed Camp Blood by the locals due to a series of deaths from years before, is decent enough on which to hang the set pieces of the film. Unlike many of its later sequels and far worse imitators, the film sticks with the small handful of counselors for the duration of the film and does not require a brutal death every five minutes. It would be too much to say that we "care" what happens to them, so much as they at least seem credible to a good extent when the carnage starts. Even the initial victim - killed fairly early in the film - gets a lengthy exposition on her background and reasons for working at the camp. The trademark score certainly spooks things up and Sean Cunningham's direction does what it needs to - it keeps the pace moving and elevates the suspense and dread in the final third of the film to keep viewers edgy. Unlike Halloween, this film does not really skimp on the gore, but unlike far worse of its ilk, it does not dwell needlessly on it either. The death scenes are gruesome, but fairly quick. The film also doesn't make the genre mistake of having all or even most of the victims be female - a tiresome conceit from other films. The cast (including then newbie Kevin Bacon) is believable as they work, relax, flirt and die, but there are really no great stand-outs. Adrienne King is an adequate heroine, who manages to be terrified, gutsy and vulnerable, and she interestingly breaks the mold as she is depicted as having a relationship with the head of the camp and is not the standard virginal good girl. Betsy Palmer is an intimidating late addition to the film as the now legendary Pamela Voorhees and the fight scenes between her and King are incredibly suspenseful and well-choreographed. The cheap DePalma-esquire shock epilogue on the film was hackneyed then and seems worse now - and, of course, opens the door for the countless sequels.

Weirdly enough I played Friday The 13th The Game before watching any of these films. Now finally having seen the one that started it all, I was surprised by it in unexpected ways. Like how Kevin Bacon is just randomly in this, in one of his first roles. Or how it feels like a mixture of Texas Chainsaw Massacre (the gorilla camera work), Halloween (the killer), and finally Psycho (also the killer). The most unexpected thing is how terrible this is. This is particularly strange considering how iconic the Jason character has become and how many sequels there are to this bad movie. The story is basically none existent to start off. It's about camp counselors at newly reopened Camp Crystal Lake. The story is literally just them setting up the camp and also dying. The characters don't help this by being complete flat lines. They aren't even serviceable. It's hard to tell some of them apart because none have a personality. Plus, the performances are generally awful or unconvincing. Now, these types of thrown together slashers are generally all about the kills. Who cares about the characters or story when you got awesome kills?? Unfortunately, even the kills suck. It starts right away in the first scene where two counselors are murdered. It's horrifically awkward and you don't see anything. Both kills are off camera with the second one being a stupid freeze frame right before she dies. Most of the deaths are like this to an extent. Either off camera or unconvincing. There's a throat slit early on that looks just terrible. There's also very little driving this film. Plot points aren't well established, built up, or even presented at times. Long stretches of this are literally elongated kill scene after elongated kill scene. Lets talk positives though, some positives of this include the setting. I enjoyed the camp ground in the middle of renovation/controversy, that's an interesting place to set a slasher. Plus I do like the grittiness of this. It's surprisingly grim for this type of movie and offers very little happiness, which I liked. The Gorilla style and barebones production helps create a more grounded tone, but that's about it. It just doesn't work. It's a mess of influences and cheap production. Ima stick with the game over this lol.

I Wonder if When This Movie was made it intended to Spawn so Many Sequels (9 so far, Including Jason X). This Is One of the best Series Around. Not only Does it Scare, It Frightens, If Not Terrifies the Viewer. Although the Sequels Were Better, You Can NEVER Put Down the Original. Rent It if you like Mystery/Suspense/Horror. Also Reccommended: Slumber Party Massacre and Sleepaway Camp

Review title: The best of the entire series. Slasher Gold.
Review_body: Opening at summer Camp Crystal Lake 1958, an unseen prowler viciously kills two teenagers who have gone off to make love. Jump to Friday June 13th, 1980 and Annie (Robbi Morgan) is on her way to be the cook at the reopening Crystal Lake summer camp. The town nut job, known as Crazy Ralph (Walt Gorney) tells her she won't come back again and Camp Blood, as it is known has a death curse. The same unseen prowler from the beginning picks up Annie who jumps from the jeep only to be hunted down and have her throat slashed. Back at camp, there are 6 other camp counselors who engage in strip monopoly, sun bathing, playing pranks on each other and doing drugs and having sex. The unseen killer makes gruesome hamburger of the teens until Alice (King) is the last alive in a battle of wills. This practically nothing plot takes it's "Halloween" slasher inspiration, strips away the style of that film, and ups the gore and shocking deaths, and history was made. All though "Halloween" started the modern slasher phase, it was this film that was responsible for unleashing the gory slasher experience upon moviegoers in the early 1980's. Director Sean S. Cunningham keeps things simple and lets the films real star take center stage. That star is special effects man Tom Savini who certainly hits a career high point with his exceptional work here. Like he did on "Dawn of the Dead", Savini gives the audience something they haven't seen before. The death of Kevin Bacon's character Jack is a shocking moment along with Marcie's Axe to the face scene. Cunningham uses Savini's shock sequences to show the audience everything. Nothing is left to the imagination. Cunningham does deliver real suspense with brutal end results which puts the viewer in a sort of fun house with jumps and shocks mixed with the heavy gore. The acting is average at best and the film steals POV shots from "Halloween" and music from "Psycho" and still manages to be entertaining as hell in its own right. Cunningham saves his biggest jump shock for his last scene. An absolute classic Jump that is guaranteed to work the first time you see this movie. The end jolt also sets up the future of the franchise that would have a very long run. Friday the 13th was exactly what audiences were looking for in 1980 and it delivers it and then some. This is still the best film in the series and has the most scares.

SPOILERSI just don't know what the big deal is with this film, it's pretty average. A mother's son drowns because the counselors weren't paying attention. She takes revenge by killing some counselors a year later, then when it's reopened a couple years later, she kills the counselors there. This is before Jason, this is his mother, Pamela Voorhees. This is a very gory film, especially for 1980. I also want to comment on something else, this is a lot like Psycho! In this a mother kills for her son, and talks for her. In Psycho, a son kills for his mother and talks for her. Psycho obviously came first in 1960, while this came out in 1980.There are ten average deaths in this film, well, maybe except for the arrow in the neck, which is pretty original. Here are the deaths.Barry: Stabbed by a hunting knife.Claudette: Stabbed by a hunting knife.Annie: Her throat is cut with a knife.Neddy: His throat is cut with a knife.Jack: An arrow is stabbed into his neck.Marcie: She is sliced in the face with an ax while imitating Katharine Hepburn.Brenda: Killed of screen. Throat slit? Steve: He is stabbed with a hunting knife.Bill: He is impaled with numerous arrows.Pamela Voorhees: She is decapitated by Alice.Alice is the heroine by killing Mrs. Voorhees. She sets off in a canoe. She wakes up and the police are up on the hill. All of a sudden, Jason's decayed body grabs her and pulls her under.She wakes up in a hospital, Jason was just a dream. The film ends with a unusually beautiful shot of the lake at Camp Crystal Lake.Overall, this is very average, and pretty overrated.7/10 Recommended Films: Halloween, Scream, A Nightmare On Elm Street, and Black Christmas.

Review title: In this case, the original isn't the best!
Review_body: (Major Spoilers)I saw 'Friday the 13th' ages ago, and I remember I wasn't that impressed to begin with, but after going through the entire series again, I had to re-rent this one on DVD. Quite frankly, the whole franchise is rather up and down, and it really depends on how serious you take your horror/slasher films. It's quite hard to come to his movie with eyes completely closed if you are aware of Jason and Camp Crystal Lake. I heard of Jason Voorhees as a horror icon way before I saw this film, and also saw some of the sequels before I ever saw the original film. I found that you don't really need to watch the original film to understand the latter sequels.Jason is known as an unstoppable freak with a hockey-mask, yet that hockey-mask aspect doesn't come into play until 'Friday the 13th Part 3'. In the original film, Jason is not the crazed killer in the movie, and it was in fact his mother (Betsy Palmer) that started this famous movie horror franchise, and Jason wasn't an icon yet. So, it's hard to view this movie as completely fresh mystery whodunit horror style flick! Initial audiences might have been surprised at the outcome, because they suspected one of the potential victims as the killer, yet Voorhees's mother was not introduced prior.Viewing this film now, it's extremely hard to take seriously. It uses the same formula that becomes tiresome throughout the first four films. You never see the killer (until the end), and the characters are killed off one by one. Some characters are trying to have sex, or are playing stupid games, and yet all of them seem oblivious to what's going on! And for some reason, there is always a character that is a practical joker amongst them.I don't really rate the characters in the first film, and I found them pretty much stock-standard. Probably the only interesting aspect about these people is that a young Kevin Bacon is playing one of them. That's about it! The death scenes are pretty weak in the first film, and because there is no super-natural element in this movie, the believability factor is really stretched. I don't think the original 'Friday the 13th' was a great film, and I think it was the sequels that established its popularity. This movie was generally pretty crap.It has an awful script, pretty crappy acting (though Betsy Palmer made the most of it), and characters do extremely stupid things. The problems I had with the film are plentiful. The style just isn't scary. The camera taking the point of view of the killer did not creep me out at all, and it just seemed cheesy to me. And there are other things that were annoying, like *MAJOR SPOILER(s) HERE* two characters having sex completely unaware of a dead body in the bunk above- even though they could have seen it beforehand, or even smelt it when they entered the room. And of course, one of the characters goes to the toilet, and then the other character left finally notices something is up and then on cue, the killer strikes from under the bed. I was sitting there rolling my eyes. Then of course, not long after, the killer manages to get to the toilet unseen, and deal with the other one! It's hard to take seriously.The killer seems to get around way to much, and completely remove evidence; like bodies and blood in a seemingly short amount of time- and also seems to be able to plant bodies in certain places to scare the remaining survivors- you know, just for kicks! When the remaining characters clue on something is up, they seem panicked in one scene, yet they still decide to separate rather than remain together, or take a nap, or make a cup of coffee in the following scenes. Hello, your pals have disappeared and two scenes ago, you spotted a bloodied axe??? Would you really stick around and go and make coffee? The only saving grace about 'Friday the 13th' is the ending. I'm sure it would have jolted the initial audience at the time, and it certainly paved way for the horror icon in Jason Voorhees to be developed in future films. However, in the case of the first 'Friday the 13th'- the original film is not better than most of its sequels. Recommended for fans of the series, but I'm sure some horror buffs couldn't take this one seriously or get that much satisfaction from the death sequences or scares. It's simply not a good movie- not even for the horror/slasher genre, and Mrs Voorhees gets a thumbs down!*½ out of *****!

Review title: 80's slasher film that become a cult classic among fans in the horror section
Review_body: Yes the original "Friday the 13th" movie is a good, decent 80's horror slasher cult clasisc film. Why this movie get's so much hate? Okay it is not a great film, but it is still good in my opinion. I heard a lot of bad stuff about this movie, but watching this movie again it was not that bad like people are saying. It was not slow paced, boring actually in fact it was fast paced horror mystery slasher. I prefer this movie over Part 2, Final Chapter, Jason X and Jason Goes to Hell that is just my opinion. I love this movie to death, it is a decent slasher and my favorite movie that is better than next sequel.Where was Jason? This movie was never about Jason been the killer, Jason Voorhees was never the star of this film. It was writen and produced by Sean S. Cunningham who never thought this movie would become antgoing franchise. Why dosen't Sleepaway Camp get's hate but this movie that I love has too? Sleepaway Camp sucks I said it! Sue me I hate that film. Halloween (1979) movie get's better rating and it has less kills but that movie is great but this isn't a good slasher film? umm?This movie was never about Jason if you watch Scream (1996) it was explained who the original killer was in this movie, Jason showed up in the sequel.So far the story goes about reopening Camp Crystal Lake with a new owner and a young counselers. When a young boy drowned and a several vicious murders have occured. A brutal killer exacts revenge on the hapless counselors.Why I love this film: the music theme from Harry Manfredini his tune makes abolutelly a classic film. The cast: Betsy Palmer, Adrienne King, Harry Crosby, Jeannine Taylor, Laurie Bartram, Kevin Bacon, Mark Nelson, Robbi Morgan they are all adorable likable cast. It is a different movie from the rest of the sequels but that is not bad folks.Adrienne King as Alice the main girl is a unique heroine she fought back on the killer and she didn't give up. Adrienne King's performence is excellent. She is my favorite final girl in this movie I love how they filmed this movie in New Jersey. I love the fact that there was only one survival girl, who fought back against a maniac Killer. Bad-ass Alice Hardy, she kicked ass so much! The FX effects from Tom Savini are great. Young girl's neck is slashed with a knive and you see blood, It is Rated R, a girl gets an axe in the head. A killer's head is cut with a machette. Tom Savini knows his stuff. Crazy Ralph was also great in this movie in which he warned the counselers they were doomed if they stay in Camp Crystal Lake. Betsy Palmer really steals the show I really miss the actress, I am a huge fan of this film.I love A Nightmare on Elm Street and The Evil Dead so why shouldn't I love this movie? The original Friday the 13th film? I love this film to death! Actress Laurie Bartram as Brenda was excellent, I love the storm used in this film. I notice this but Friday the 13th Part IV: The Final Chapter copies the scenes from this film.R.I.P. Betsy Palmer, Laurie Bartram, Sally Anne Golden, Willie Adams, Walt Gorney and Rex Everhart you are all missed.I enjoy this movie more than Friday the 13th Part IV: The Final Chapter or Jason Goes to Hell that is my opinion. Sean S. Cunningham directed this movie well. Victor Miller wrote a good script. I have the t-shirt about this movie and i will always love this film.Friday the 13th (1980) is an 80's creative, original slasher film that started the slashers in the 80's my second favorite "Friday the 13th" film with Friday the 13th Part VII: The New Blood and a good one. It is in my top 6 "Friday the 13th" films and my favorite horror movie.

Review title: Not the best slasher, but still good.
Review_body: I was never a fan of slasher films, mainly because I always found them cheesy or typical. And though they are, generally, I can't help but thank them for the landmarks they made in horror and in cinema in general. Friday the 13th certainly deserves credit for this.It was the first camp-themed horror movie, which played into the memories that most of us had at camps as kids. I can still remember that feeling of being watched as I was alone in a camp dorm, and laying there thinking something was under my bed, which amazed me when the arrow came through the bed in this movie. Easily the most memorable part.Also, the idea of not having Jason as the original killer was ingenious. Just everything about the movie was ingenious, and it deserves the classic status it has.Age has given it a layer of cheese, but if I had grown up in its time I'm sure it would have been one of my favorite movies, period. It defied generational clichés (who was really killing), created an entire new horror setting (the camp), and solidified the slasher structure and gave it a meaning (sex killed Jason, essentially). This is a landmark in punk entertainment for its time. I appreciate it now, but as I said, the layer of cheese is still there. It's not perfect anymore. Maybe the remake will fix that.This movie is a slasher film. You watch people get killed for the space of the movie. What more is there to say? What more can you ask for if you're looking for a fun 80's movie? This is it.3/10

Review title: You'll have a vacation to die for in Camp Crystal Lake
Review_body: *They were SPOILED, now they're doomed* Friday, June the 13th, 1980; in the enchanting Camp Crystal Lake, already theater of three horrible deaths (two counselors stabbed and a kid drowned) and in course of being reopened, six camp counselors and the new owner of the Camp, Steve Christy, are brutally murdered by a mysterious serial killer, who the only survivor will face, in the catfight from HELL.OK, OK, I agree that Friday the 13th hasn't got the greatest script (or acting), but it does what it has been planned to do; scare, and do so aplenty.There's somebody who has written that this movie looks like a 'documentary' slasher; wrong, but thanks for playing. To me, it sounds more like a campfire horror story, with creative ways to die (hatchet in the face, spear in the neck, mass spearing...) and various 'final' fights.Jason makes just a cameo in this one, at the end (if only he had dragged her down for real!), as he will come into play from the sequel, which, if you liked this, will be just your cup of tea, like parts 3 and 4 (which shows the killer's headstone, with the WRONG year (1980, not 1979!)). Skip from Part 5 onwards, though, because all those films sucked ass.Friday The 13th: 7/10

These days slasher flicks are a dime-a-dozen. And most are, sadly, very bad! Honestly, who wants to see another SAW movie? How many people went to see the remake of "Texas Chainsaw Massacre"? Lately, Hollywood has been doing what it does best: Taking good movies and making crappy remakes! Please, gentle viewer, if you're a truly-devoted horror fan, skip Rob Zombie's HALLOWEEN, chuck the new "Friday the 13th" out the window, and run from the atrocious MY BLOODY VALENTINE remake! If you want good and decent slasher flicks, go back to the roots. In the early 80s, slashers were just getting started. When you went to see one of those, what did you expect? Pretty actresses, inventive deaths, and a generally creepy story! And that's all they needed. At the forefront came "Friday the 13th", which would one day become the franchise best remembered for the hockey-masked Jason. But in 1980, the filmmakers set out to make a scary movie set at a summer camp. You have mostly stereotyped camp counselors who are soon slain in a variety of ways. Many seem to hearken back to the best urban legends. As night wears on, and the body pile grows, we get what is one of the scariest performances in slasher history. But for those who haven't seen FT13 or SCREAM, I won't reveal the killer's identity! The special effects and make-up, done by the DEAD guru Tom Savini, are what this movie does best. The scares come pretty fast and most deaths only last a few seconds. Compare that with the long, drawn-out death scenes of later installments. Sheesh, sometimes less is more! All in all, this movie has the feel of a good campfire story and there will always be a special place in my heart for this and other early slasher flicks!

Review title: There lies a great mood over this film, and it's not as bad as people say.
Review_body: This could be another 80's slashermovie like any other. But it has some kind of feeling that won't show up in the most of the 80's horrors. Maybe it's just something that comes up on me, but somewhere in the slice'n'dice you can relate to the script and the kids, even if it sometimes get a bit anti-serious.                               A very big plus to the environment, acting is just as decent as you could expect, but Kevin Bacon works. The music is sometimes a great, big Psycho-rip off. This is a bit over the good-mark, but it is almost just because of some creepy, well-made details in script and directing.                              Small cult-warning! Quite creepy... 7/10

It's extremely overrated. Nothing at all fun about it. Psychopath goes around killing, never runs and never speaks. That's pretty much all that happens in the movie. Therefore I'm still mystified by the fact that it got all those sequels, just like Halloween. Guess your typical viewer with an IQ under 100 is thrilled and amazed by this type of movies.
Maybe I'm wrong, maybe it's simply not for me. Either way, I didn't like it.

You know the superstition of the number 13 being bad luck. Well thanks to movies like this one, we have grown to dread a Friday that has the number 13. 'Friday the 13th' is simply about the foolish teenage counselors staying in the cursed campground and being killed off one by one. The scenes are slightly gruesome, but not unpredictable or scary. The music that cues the murders is hardly spooky, but eventually irritating. The cast is really more a group of unknowns with only one who has an actual career (Kevin Beacon). This film is not a real good horror movie, but more of a bore. But if you want a cheap scare on Halloween then check this one out.

Review title: Good beginning to one of the greatest slasher-franchises
Review_body: I personally believe that "Friday the 13th", "Halloween" and "Nightmare on Elm Street" are the greatest slasher films ever made. 1980 was an extremely special year in horror films, and no, it wasn't just for the Shining. It was the beginning of Friday the 13th, a date which many fear due to this franchiseThere were some great aspects about this film and some not so great aspects of the film. I personally found the plot rather well done, with nothing except someone out for revenge, simply killing all that enter Camp Crystal Lake. The plot is very simplistic, yet very enjoyable. The idea of a mom being a serial killer in this film can be laughable and can also be scary. However, the film suffers from other openings to classic slashers. "Original Nightmare on Elm Street", "Original Halloween" and "Original Child's Play" were so well done that it was extremely enjoyable, whereas I personally found the film very quiet on many different occasions, with no real surprise to me. Also, unlike the sequels, the killing seems to be far too separated from one another. However, the soundtrack is the spookiest part of this film. Its done so well and the acting is good, with the entire cast chipping in. What I liked most about this film is that a mother isn't just an insane person out there killing for no reason, but its simply to revenge her son, the one she loved more than anything. What I liked about the sequels was that it was Jason, this time, getting revenge on anyone who enters the site by killing all and attempting to keep it closed in memory of his mother.The kills in this film aren't spooky but its done nicely. Overall, not one of the better horror films, but certainly good enough. 6/10

Usually when I write a review for a film I try my best to not let it contain major spoilers, but for this classic I feel I must.When I was a kid my best buddy Kevin and I were major horror fans. I was a huge Freddy fan, while Kevin was a huge Jason fan. It was with him I saw for the first time the FRIDAY THE 13TH movies and through him I became a horror film fanatic really. The first time I saw this was with him and another friend of ours John. To be honest I didn't like this movie...at all. In fact I think I hated it. My problem was I was expecting the killer to be Jason, which it is not and thought that the pace was lazy and slow. After rewatching this movie I don't know at least 30 times since then I do proclaim this to be a pretty good horror film even though it is quite flawed for a film that has spawned I can't remember exactly but I think 10 sequels. Some things this film really nails quite well, while others well it does miss the mark a bit on.Well, if you are reading this I hope you have seen the film, but if not it starts in 1958 where two camp councillors are killed when they are in the act of getting ready for some premarital sex. Flash forward twenty years and Steve Christy (Peter Brouwer) is going to reopen the camp that the locals call Camp Blood. For at Camp Crystal Lake back in the 50s a young boy named Jason Vorhees had drowned in the lake when councillors weren't paying any attention. So a new group of councillors including a young Kevin Bacon and Harry Crosby who is the son of the legendary Bing Crosby are brought to the camp early to get it ready for when it opens. The councillors are being wiped off one by one by some unknown killer.By the end of the film we find out that killer is in fact Jason's mother Pamela played by Betsy Palmer, who in my opinion easily steals the film. What is kind of incredible is she has maybe 15 minutes of screen time and she quickly becomes a horror icon for her role. Other performances in this film are okay, like it is cool to see a young Kevin Bacon in a slasher and plays his character well and no one really puts in a bad job, but no one really stands out though either. But, it wasn't written that way either. FRIDAY THE 13TH is not known for great performances or amazing story lines. They are about the kills and the nudity.I must say though that I am quite mixed about the story though. As a who-done-it to me it kind of fails and is not a giallo which just maybe writer Victor Miller was trying to create here. It is really a giallo with no suspects or people who you could think it might be beyond perhaps Crazy Ralph (Walt Gorney) or if you have heard of Jason, then him. As a set up to Jason's character or his ambitions to kill in later films it does pretty good. Just don't think too hard about it though, because it just ain't going to add up. I am also mixed on the ending as they created one of the greatest jump scares of all time when Jason grabs Alice (Adrienne King) in the canoe, but then there is more tacked on to explain it was a dream. Man, it would have been so much better to leave the ending with the jump scare and start Part 2 without the beginning with Alice, because I find it so slow and unneeded if you ended with the correct jump scare.The music by Harry Manfredini is a major plus and really a terrific horror score. Like HALLOWEEN ( a film that this one rips off to create a box office smash) without the signature theme I can not imagine them without the A+ music. Besides the original does have more than just the horror theme that was used I think in all the sequels. There are other themes here that surprisingly for a FRIDAY THE 13TH movie shows some care and depth in the music.Finally to me a real big reason why this was so huge was Tom Savini. He did the practical effects for this film who at this time was known for the makeup and effects he did on George A. Romero's DAWN OF THE DEAD. To go through his kills: Annie (throat slashed which to this day looks extremely real to me), Jack (arrow through his neck which most fans I think love the most and probably scared the MPAA when first seen), Marcie (axe to the face, which I really enjoy) to Pamela herself (might be one of the most memorable kills in the series with her beheading). They are all top notch and sadly a couple are off-screen. The only one that was lame was Steve Christy's.Produced and directed by Sean S. Cunningham who created perhaps much more than he was expecting a never-ending cash machine of a series and a horror icon in Jason (although he isn't seen much in the original, but you WILL remember him). The director of Parts 2 & 3 Steve Miner acted as associate producer here.When I first saw it I likely would have put it down on the bottom of the list of FRIDAY THE 13TH movies. Now, it really is one of the better ones, while not my favourite I know that Cunningham's style which partly was stolen from HALLOWEEN in the POV shots was copied in most of the following entries in the series and it really does create a nice early 80s atmospheric horror film.

Friday the 13th as a slasher film is quite a humble movie compared to what would eventually be in store as it would evolve into a franchise of an exploitative and later even a self-parodying nature. The first movie establishes the basic rules and storyline and in it does a decent job.The young cast provide an unusually sympathetic group of characters for what has become a real cliché group of characters. The kills aren't that gruesome but violent enough in their own right to give the movie a morbid energy. Atmospherically the film works and the added of element of nostalgia also gives it a bit of a sympathetic quality.I'd have to say all in all that the last act of the film is the strongest. Pamela Voorhees is perhaps not the most iconic of movie-killers but still a competent psychotic villain for this film. The ending is also one of the best and most classic scares in any horror movie and its effect has not changed.Friday the 13th's only problem is its close approximation and indeed rather blatant similarities to other Slashers of the day, mainly John Carpenter's Halloween, compared to which it perhaps lacks the extra finish to make it as memorable a movie, but it's still a fun, scary movie in its own right.

This is the film that started a fury of sequels and helped create the slasher genre. Friday the 13th is interesting from the rest because there is a bit of a mystery as to who the killer is. Of course, if you've seen any of the other sequels or know the horror genre, the killer's identity is pretty much a known fact. I watched Friday the 13th Part 2 before this one years ago so it gave the mystery away completely. Friday the 13th is about a bunch of young camp counsellors who are opening up Camp Crystal Lake after many serious incidents have taken place there over the years. The place kind of has a bad name so to speak. One by one, we see the counsellors being stalked in the woods by someone or something. Many of them are killed off leading up to a shocking conclusion.This first one was never as good as parts two, three and four for obvious reasons surrounding the killer's identity. I felt parts 2-4 were really the best of the Friday the 13th films. But this is a legendary film on it's own. It created that sub-genre of teens being stalked in the woods. Many other films were made after 1980 with similar plots. The Burning, Don't go in the Woods, The Final Terror come to mind as being rip offs of the early Friday the 13th films.This is definitely a must see for any horror fan. There are some genuine scares like when one girl goes to the out house/washroom and hears noises behind the shower curtains. And the gore is done well by Tom Savini. The acting is also not bad. Check it out.8/10

Maybe do you want to swim a little... no, no, no... i mean... do you want to be killed by a maniac?... sorry i say maniac?... well, come and see "Friday the 13th", to see Kevin Bacon in one of his first roles and how his character is totally murdered in a horrible way.OK... first of all, not matters how seems, i don't hate so much "Friday the 13th"... is just that that have some problems.
