Review title: Camp Blood inspired a flood, but is hardly a dud.
Review_body: After the success of a little indie horror-film by the name of "Halloween," struggling film-maker Sean S. Cunningham sought to cash in on the formula and release a holiday themed slasher all his own: "Friday The 13th." A whodunit with a fresh young cast (including a then unknown Kevin Bacon) and a score of ground-breaking make-up effects, Cunningham's little creation not only inspired a flood of sequels (10 to date, with an impending remake) but a generation of slasher films that owe their existence to it. And to this day, it still holds up.What makes the film so effective? It could be the setting, a very realistic, sometimes spooky camp that gives way to loads of atmosphere. It helps, of course, that the bulk of the characters in the film look and feel real. Even for all of their little flaws, you can't help but feel for the unfortunate kids, regardless of how many times you've seen the movie. You could perhaps chalk part of it up to the outrageous death scenes, and -- more importantly -- the effects that drive them home. Ground-breaking for their time and besting the lazier CGI work of today, Tom Savini's career-making work is still a vicious and grisly sight to behold to this day. Whatever it is, one thing is certain: "Friday The 13th" is a time-tested, eternally entertaining and flat-out fun little horror film.The story is pretty basic. Teenagers prepping for a children's camp take part in a little rest and relaxation -- a.k.a. pre-marital sex, pot-smoking and strip-Monopoly (?) -- only to find out the hard way that a brutal killer is terrorizing their isolated neck of the woods, picking off would-be counselors one by one. Obviously the mystery element of the story has been obliterated by pop-culture's grasp of a certain hockey-masked man-child, but the final reveal is still a shocker, driven home by a bold and fearless performance that gives way to the most effective stalk scene in the film. The ending -- interpreted whichever way you please -- is still a jumper to this day and is just one example of the subtle yet admirable cinematography and the chilling score by Harry Manfredini that accompanies it. From front to end, "Friday The 13th" is a true classic. Like "Halloween" -- but with less of a film-school vibe -- it's a movie that can be enjoyed again and again and has earned it's status as one of the grand-daddies of the slasher genre. In spite of the up-and-down franchise that followed in it's wake, it's still a gem.

Review title: The one that started it all
Review_body: This is the film that started the slasher movie craze. The brilliant film critics have all denounced the film. You get exactly what you should expect from this movie. If your sensibilities are so delicate, don't watch. There is much blood and gore, but there are also some genuine scares. Betsy Palmer is truly frightning in her small, but essential role. There is a scene near the end that literally made me jump out of my seat. I've seen few other horror films that I could say the same for. If you see only one Friday movie, make it this one.

After john carpenters success with Halloween,slasher movies were coming out of the woodwork,one of the better slasher movies was Friday the 13th.it started the franchise and also features a then unknown Kevin bacon as a camp counselor.ii all starts in 1958 when a mongoloid child named Jason voorhees drowns in the lake while the camp counselors that are supposed to be watching are screwing.well now its 1980 and camp counselors are being murdered along with others,brutal scenes of gore that caused the mpaa to almost give this an x rating.the sequel was toned down a bit,this was the time hen violence in horror movies was being scrutinized by the mpaa and fanatics.2 good examples were phantasm in 1979,and dawn of the dead(78)which was unrated due to the violence and gore.Friday the 13th is a classic and worth a look.although not great it will give you jolts of panic if watching for the first time.then there's the sound effects that became very popular;chi chi chi haa haa haa haa.the awesome special effects were done by the great tom savini who also did dawn of the dead and maniac with Joe spinell,7 out of 10.

"Friday the 13th" is still the best film out the entire history of the film franchise. This was the template that was really a rip-off of "Halloween" but who cares. The producers made such a creepy film that in the realty is that it has more fans than "Halloween". Yes this film is bloodier but it is still A GOOD MOVIE! In this film there is an opening of the murder of 2 camp counselors. WE do not know who is behind the crime. Then credits roll and its now present day (1980 at the time). Camp Crystal lake is set to re-open. Camp Counselors are in training and yet they are slowly being murdered. Yes this film is a whodunit. This film still delivers the chills all these years later. Mainstream critics will always hate this film but so what! This film is made for an audience not for critics. If you love horror films you will love this!

Friday the 13th redefined the slasher genre in the 80s. It's not just about a killer anymore. It's about pretty and youthful teenagers on a summer camp being killed one by one until a final girl survives. The plot becomes overused by other movies after its release, with more films about teens or college-aged people getting murdered one by one.Definitely a must see movie.

This is just a grotesque old fashioned horror film that won't acre anybody today.Story: a group of young and wayward campers visit a supposedly haunted cottage to camp there despite people's warnings, where an unknown stalker starts to trouble them one after the other.The storyline is good and fit for an old fashioned horror film. But otherwise there's only overacting, vulgarity and grotesque stuff. The music is also not scary for a horror film. Some of the makeup work is appreciable though.This is also not a family film and is unsuited for children.

Review title: The beginning of an endless string of sequels
Review_body: I like horror movies, and though the original Friday the 13th wasn't the first film I saw in this series, I believe it was Friday the 13th part 2, I figured I'd give it a go. After all, it was this movie that started a series of endless sequels.After seeing it, I would have to say that one of the few things I really enjoyed about it was the story and setting which dealt with a group of camp counselors who were opening a camp up for children which had been closed down due to a murder a few years ago. They are soon stalked by a psycho killer out for revenge that we never get a real good look at until later. This killer proceeds to kill them one by one. With this movie the killer is somewhat surprising, remember, this is the first film in the series.I also enjoyed some of the creative death scenes as well as one of the final scenes which is probably one of the best shocking moments in all of horror movie history, but other than that this movie offers little else. The actors were poor, and yes this first Friday the 13th includes a young Kevin Bacon, probably the only actor who went on to success after this film. The other names I don't even remember, except for Betsy Palmer. There is no real suspense or mystery in this film either, just a bunch of shocks and gore. That is not a good way to make a horror movie.Overall this movie, which copied it's idea from Psycho and mainly Halloween, two movies that are far superior to it, is not quite the competent horror film. But alas, the never ending sequels continued anyway with only part 6 matching the first because of it's humor more than anything. I still wait to see the perfect campfire tale. This one just doesn't quite make the grade, but sadly it is probably the best one dealing with psycho killers and camping.

Review title: The more and more I watch this film the more and more I don't care for it
Review_body: Friday the 13th is a 1980 slasher film that, when it was released, became very popular due to its violence and nudity and what not. Due to the film's success, a whole franchise of movies was born. Friday the 13th was controversial for its depictions of violence and nudity and a lot of scenes were heavily cut by the MPAA but the film has recieved an Uncut release (of which I watched). Which is good for this film but a lot of the other films are mostly unable to recieve the same treat AND I WANT MORE GORE!!! With that being said, the film was trashed by the critics but audiences loved it. The film was directed by Sean Cunningham and stared Adrienne King, Betsy Palmer, and an early performance from Kevin Bacon. Other than that, nobody else really notable. The film had a small budget of $500,000 and due to its small budget was a huge success at the box office.The film starts in 1958 at Camp Crystal Lake where we witness the murder of two camp counselors. Who is the killer? We do not know. Cut to years later and the same camp where the murders happened is going to be reopened but before it can, a group of new counselors are fixing up the place. Camp Crystal Lake is a bad place, the locals say but none of the counselors listen. Perhaps being killed will make them listen...I understand that Friday the 13th is often labeled as iconic but the more and more I watch this film, there just does not seem to be anything really iconic about this film. The film is often labeled by many as a blatant copycat of Halloween. Honestly, I don't think so. I personally do not see any similarities between the two films. Friday the 13th plays out as a mystery in a way. Sure, we do not know who the killer is (and many people who have not seen the movie know who it is). Where this film fails in that department is not giving us any good suspects. Hell, the film doesn't give us any at all. So it comes as no surprise when the killer is revealed that the killer is someone we have no idea who they are. Granted, the killer is one of the better parts of the film. The film is a slow burn with mostly filler. Nothing exciting happens and when something does, it is typically a horny person getting axed off. But when the killer is revealed, the film picks up and is really fun to watch. But in the mean time, we have to sit through over an hour of filler. Nothing exciting happens at all. The characters are not interesting and do not get developed at all. The only character trait we get from them are horny. The final girl of this film is overrated in my opinion and while she does not share the same character traits as the other people, she is still not that interesting. (Pretty much everyone knows who the final girl is but I know there is a small percentage out there who has not seen the film and therefore deserve to see a spoiler free review). With that being said the killer is the best character of the film. The killer when revealed is at first unassuming but starts being very creepy. The performance is really good here. Some other things to praise about this film is the special effects/gore which is done very well by the legendary Tom Savini. The effects while not the goriest of all the Friday the 13th films (wait till Part IV) they are still gory nonetheless and they still hold up in my opinion. The Harry Manfredini score is really good and is instantly recognizable. While the film is not scary at all, there are a few creepy moments which can be attributed to the cinematography. The POV shots are nice and at times they use these shots when not needed which I find to be effective in this film. It makes the viewer think the killer is there because of how it is shot and sometimes the killer is not there. The whole scenery is somewhat generic but the setting is interesting because like in a film like Halloween, the evil came to the people. But in Friday the 13th, they come to the evil. Again, the killer is the best part of the film but the very very end of the film is possibly the scariest part of the film but is ultimately ruined by the actual final scene of the film.Friday the 13th 1980 is a film that I would not even call good or even a meh movie. To me, there is nothing all too special about this film and lacks the entertainment value of the sequels. While there are some good or even great things to say about the film, there are more things that I can find uninteresting about the film. Yes, I make it a tradition to watch this film or even some of the sequels every Friday the 13th, but does not mean it is a good film. It is just a good old date night popcorn movie

This classic is the most iconic before Jason was the killer. The death scenes are good. Pretty much so that I like this movie. It's better than the reboot.I don't want to make this review to long so yeah the movie is good I'd recommend it.

Review:
'Friday the 13th' is an American slasher film directed by Sean S. Cunningham. Speaking just about this movie and not the franchise, makes this feel like a different type of movie than we view it as today. I wish I could have been around to see this movie when it was first released because I believe that this film is a mystery above all, but now that it's connected to the 'Friday the 13th' franchise we all know today, it's categorised as a horror film.
The film tells the story of a group of teenage camp counselors who are murdered one by one by an unknown killer while attempting to re-open an abandoned summer camp.
Almost everybody in this movie is known only for this movie. Besides Kevin Bacon and Betsy Palmer, nobody had made a name for themselves after or prior to this film. For being a movie from the 80's, I can't complain about the acting, it was on par with what you would expect for a film from that decade for the most part.
I love everything about this movie, the cheesiness of the murders, the comic relief it has throughout and the fact we always see the kills from the first-person perspective. It made an original and possibly very risky decision in doing that and I believe it pulled it off.
Overall, it is a typical slasher movie with some of its own personality intertwined throughout. If you haven't seen it and like slashers give it a try.
3.5/5

Review title: Classic cult horror that spawned an iconic foe is not as good as you think
Review_body: While our hockey mask wearing foe has gone on to become iconic looking back on this film he is not fully established. It does seem to borrow ideas from Halloween, however it does try to trick and susprise us. Music and effects are both very good and still some what chilling despite the movies age. I'm not sure this movie is quite as good as we think it is even though it gave birth to an iconic killer but it took intill later films to define him.

So I finally watched this movie. And my general consensus is that after having seen Halloween and various other slashers I feel like even though the things they did with the low budget is admirable, it lacks a bit too much.The directing is sloppy, the POV killer camera is alright though but some scenes the camera just holds for too long, and it becomes awkward like you are waiting for something to happen, but it never does. And it never ends up doing throughout the movie. So it wasn't a setup to catch you off guard in a future scene.The acting is iffy all around the board and just outright funny during some kill scenes. The scream the girl let out just before she got an axe to the head had me in tears. It was incredibly unconvincing.The characters are not too bad, but they are killed of WAY to fast. Ned, arguably the best character just for his lines and stupidity gets killed in the most unsatisfying and subtle ways. And the movie lost its comedic relief like 20 minutes in. Also, all the characters going out alone time and time again became annoying predictable.Now my main annoyance with the story, was Alice just flip a switch of being totally freaked out to ''i'm going to take a nap''. Just before she was running around with Bill paranoid out of their minds because everyone is GONE. But oh well, guess I'll take a nap? Seemed like sloppy writing just to kill off Bill because he doesn't want her to get up from her nap.. Ofcourse, Bill doesn't come back and Alice ends up finding his body and the killer chase scene commends.Now the Killer reveal was incredibly surprising but also a bit funny. All I know about this movie franchise is that there is a masked muscular killer so to see this old lady AS the killer was quite the polar opposite. The fight and chase scenes were sloppy but not too bad actually, although Alice only figures out how to finish the job after like 4 times. The final kill was pretty fun as well. If I had to rate the best kil it would still be the one where the Mrs Voorhees is under the bed and kill the guy with an arrow. One of the only jumpscares that worked for me.The music all things considered is good, really enjoyed it and definitely added a ton of suspense.Now the end, wow that caught me by surprise and I could imagine back in the day people gasping and screaming in the theatre. Because that thing (jason) was the first SCARY thing in the movie. Mrs Voorhees was intimidating, but never scary to me. And damn that boat scene got me.How she got out of the lake is never explained, just saved by the cops but no one saw Jason. So the movie ends with a pretty huge cliffhanger. And I will definitely be watching the next few movies.At the end though, I do rate it a 5/10 because I really wouldn't care to watch it again. There are much better slasher movies made before this with equally low budgets. It was still fun to watch it for the first time though, and I'm looking forward to the sequels.

OK, this film is 20 years old, there are a never ending string of sequels and the series really should have ended with part 4, but aside from those facts, the original Friday is still an interesting idea with a few good scares, lots of gore, etc...  This movie and the series pales in comparision to the Halloweens and Nightmares, simply because all of these movies seem to be the same. 
The story-line does not transition from movie to movie with ease.  True, Parts 1-4 had transitions, but they always used flashback scenes.  Then 5-9 skipped the transitions (flashback scenes) and with minor exceptions are not related story lines (even Jason (or his mother) disappears in the 5th (in reality) and 9th (basically) ones and he is the main guy).Anyway, this is one of the best in the series (top 5 anyway) because it was the first and it does have something to set it apart.Quite simply, it makes the game of Monopoly more than a battle of braking the bank, which usually takes hours.  This movie has a new form of gaming "strip monopoly".  While none of the Friday's are terrible (5 and 9 probably being the worst), none of them are tense or suspensful or anything more than the routine slashing and killing.  Part 3-D has juiced up music, but the same story. Part 8 has a new story twist, but no new music,etc...  The better ones in the series add something (like strip monopoly, or 3D, or a claustrophobic environment of a boat), but none of them seem to put it all together in one film.As horror goes, better than average, a good series, but not one of the greats.In general nothing special.

This, the very first Friday the 13th film, is an entertaining watch but hasn't held up against time very well. Much better slasher films have been made since (personally I prefer the revival slashers, especially Scream), though I guess it's a matter of opinion whether the original Halloween or Nightmare on Elm Street are better than this.Friday takes place in a single day and much of the film follows the clueless teenagers spending their time gleefully at a summer camp without supervision. One by one they get offed by an unknown murderer. The mood gets tense but not really frightening. The film suffers from its lack of conflict -- the kids have no idea someone's after them, and they never really have any time to get scared before they're killed. The ending fight is somewhat climactic but the build-up could've been handled better.The cheesy gore effects are... well, we've seen better nowadays, but the old B-movie effects have their charm.

This movie had a great plot to it, though some things about this film still annoy me and I happy to say that this film was good, it just wasn't as good as I had expected it to be.The Film is about Jason's mother who goes around killing young teens who are keeping the camp closed, Jason's Mother Pamela Voorheas wants to try and keep the camp open.I think the film was set in a good environment and background, because I like all of those forest like, wood like scenery, though I just wish that Jason was the killer instead of his mother because I do think that was just stupid. I also think that Jason could have gone on a killing spree in the first one because also 1957 & 1980, that's a freakin' long time for him to come out of the water. I also think towards the end of the film was getting too dramatic and they should have cut it out because I think the drama was way over the top. Going into the positives the film was great with it's music.This is a good film though it would never go up there with films such as Halloween or Child's Play. I would rather stick with Parts 2-4 & 6 6/10. (I still don't mind this film, just not my favorite Friday the 13th film).

Review title: Friday The 13th Is A Bloody Good Movie
Review_body: Today is Friday the 13th so i am going to have a Friday The 13th movie marathon and i am going to watch all 10 movies in the series over 2 days.Its been 26 years scene this great horror movie was made and this movie gets better with age.The plot for this movie is about at a summer camp 20 years ago a boy named Jason Voorhees drowned and two camp councilers got murdered now 20 years later the camp is reopening and some new camp councilers are at the camp setting it up and one by one the camp councilers get killed in all kinds of ways.The best two death scenes in this movie are:1.when the great actor Kevin Bacon's character is laying in his bed and the killer is under the bed and pushes a arrow throw his neck and blood gos everywhere.2.The scene in the end of the movie when Alice Hardy (Adrienne King) cuts off Pamela Voorhees (Betsy Palmer) head and u get a good close up when it happens and u should pause it and watch it in slow mode.Over all this movie is one of the best horror movies from the 1980's and of all time.If u are a fan of horror movies u should buy the DVD box set of this series even though a couple of the other movies in the series are a bit crap.Over all this is a great movie and my rating for this movie is six and a half out of ten.

There's no doubt that the Friday the 13th franchise has made its impact on film, the horror genre, and pop-culture. However, for all of its notoriety, there isn't very much here. The story is entirely barebones, which isn't necessarily a bad thing but with all of the other pitfalls that the movie meanders right into it makes the bland story all the more noticeable.I'm sure that by this point 40 years later that people know that the original Friday has a mystery. This, alongside the practical effects by legend Tom Savini are really the only things that stand out among all the tropes and mediocre acting. The story is almost a carbon copy of Black Christmas, which was effective largely because of its villain not being a blank slate. The mystery of the identity of the killer is half-baked, but instead of being the main focus of the story where it could have been more interesting than the broad strokes we got, Friday the 13th sticks with the generic late teens and twentysomethings.The characters in Friday are entirely generic, barely even hitting the marks of archetype. The characters themselves are flimsily written; with one character "Ned" playing a prank on his friends, pretending that he can't swim despite being shown swimming right in front of everyone not but a minute ago. And everyone falls for it for some reason. And "Annie", the only half-developed character is the first to die. Everyone else is just boring. It's this kind of writing, focused on cardboard characters instead of the more interesting mystery that makes me think that no one involved with Friday the 13th cared about making a good horror movie or a good mystery or characters to care about. A character is given one to two personality traits, and then they're promptly killed. There's no room to latch onto a character, the writing attempting to cheaply fall back on basic "oh no, a person is gonna die" morality.Speaking of horror, the scares in the debut of the franchise are very light, with only one single scene with Kevin Bacon invoking any reaction that isn't a yawn. Since there isn't a character to get attached to here, the score is used to attempt to ratchet up the tension when the killing start coming at a consistent rate. While this score may be iconic in a vacuum, the first Friday leans too hard on its music instead of good writing.All technical aspects are... fine. Nothing stands out here either. No special shots or memorable sound design. No standout direction or anything of the sort. Everything is just mediocre at best. Accounting for everything, the immense blandness of everything just makes the missed opportunity for a more compelling story (or compelling villain) stick out much more than they would have if there was even one memorable moment here. Not to mention the absolutely glacial pace.Those involved with Friday the 13th even admitted that it was a clone of other slashers like '74s Black Christmas and '78s Halloween. That alone should tell you all you need to know. So, unless all you're after is looking at scantily-clad people; there's not much to see.31/100

Review title: So Much Better than Its Critics Originally Gave It Credit For
Review_body: If you go back and look at the 1980 critical reception for the original "Friday the 13th", you'll find that the film was widely panned by critics, with many taking exception to the more overt gore and camera angles of the film. As I sit down to write this review some 35 years later, I find those reviews to have missed the genius of what is actually a very well made horror film.It's fair to say that Friday the 13th may not be original in its own right, with "Halloween" having been made two years previously. Still, "Friday the 13th" actually is not a typical slasher movie, as its villain is not revealed until quite late in the movie, and then we ultimately find that the antagonist in "Friday the 13th" is far from a Michael Myers clone, but rather more of a psychopathic profile. I find this film to be infinitely more cerebral than its "slasher" movie counterparts, regardless of how stereotypical its sequels may have become as the 1980's went along. And inasmuch as the camera angles may have been controversially gross at the time, with their first-person views from the angle of the killer, the convention nonetheless marks the advent of a new move in cinema, one that certainly has often been imitated even if it's seldom done as effectively as it is in the opening scene of "Friday the 13th".Another reason that this film is great is that it's not overdone. The acting of the teenage camp counselors may not be Oscar worthy in any given year, but the performances are strong, just the same. Betsy Palmer, who it's said was horrified to have taken on the script at all and only did it for the money, also turns out a truly strong performance, and ultimately provides one of the archetypes of the horror genre. The gritty texture of the film, visually, gives it a believable feel that transcends the decades, as does the soundtrack (even the odd mix of piano and synthesizer near the end after the film is coming to its dramatic conclusion). I say all of this as someone who is not a horror film buff, but can still appreciate horror when it is well done, and my estimation of this movie is that it is much more well done than its contemporary critics gave it credit for. 8/10 stars.

Review title: Shouldn't be known as an classic
Review_body: What did Friday the 13th give to the horror genre? What makes it stand out amongst the rest ? Well to be honest, it gives nothing new to the genre and it doesn't stand out amongst the best , like Halloween and TCM. It easy to say that Halloween opened the door for many Horror directors. After the huge success of Halloween, directors were given the opportunity to get there foot in the door. Sean Cunningham saw the opening and tried to make the most of it. I think why Friday the 13th stands out from the rest is because of it ending and surprising twist. These features are the reason why Friday the 13th is highly praised and remembered . Personally I thought the film was poor. I also believe that younger viewers will be left disappointed due to the fact the Iconic figure with the hockey mask doesn't feature in the film. That what I believe, I believe that the reason why everyone watches the first one is because the sequels gave the audience an iconic killer. Imagine the twist when watching it on release date, you would be surprised by it but then imagine it watching it for the first time today, expecting Jason to show up. The twist is far more surprising today than it was 29 years ago.But still, the film is pretty bad , maybe it because to me it a mindless slasher. Friday the 13th in a nutshell: friends camp at lake, friends get murdered at lake, the end. You could say the same for Halloween or TCM or in fact any slasher film but the problem is, is that Friday the 13th doesn't contain a soul of itself . There no imagination or creativity it just mindless killing, filled with gore and the gore itself isn't very impressive in today standards ( but in 1980, it was probably good ) . Halloween had the voyeurism, The shining had the physiological effect, TCM had the shocking element. These three had there own unique style while Friday the 13th seems to rip off many of other horrors .Just imagine this film as one of many other horrors, the ones that you can tell are going to be awful. When you see it on the self , just think of it as one of those awful, corny horror B movies because in fairness, Friday the 13th is pretty bad. Some of the acting is awful and corny while some is okay. Full marks for Kevin Bacon's over dramatic dive into the lake. The twist is nice but then let down because of the awful acting. I haven't watched any of the sequels but after watching this, I don't think I'll be anytime soon.

Me and a friend decided to start watching the Friday 13th series recently. So of course we started with the classic first entry: Friday the 13th (1980).I have to admit I was pretty impressed by the movie.The acting was a little hokey, but everything else was pretty darn good. There are some great scenes, a lot of scary ones at that. Also a good story that will (hopefully) be explained some more in future entries. One moment that really got me was almost at the end of the movie. I won't spoil it here, but it's definitely one of the most unexpected moments in horror movies for me. A real shocker!Friday the 13th wasn't a disappointment at all. Sure, the acting could have been a little better on some people, but I wasn't really annoyed by it because the rest was good. Oh did I mention the movie has great music too?7 out of 10 stars!

It's Friday the 13th of June 1980 and a group of teenagers start their summer off by preparing Camp Crystal lake for a grand reopening. There is one problem though, which is that a mysterious mass murderer will not stop until every one of them is dead and Camp Crystal lake remains closed permanently. Friday the 13th is the first in the series of films that follow the murderous rampage's of Jason Voorhees, only this one is a little different than what any casual viewer would expect.The film is essentially a cliché teen horror film. There is a group of dumb teenagers to which contain the typical sexually active straight couple and the dick head character. You don't particularly care about these teens and frankly can't wait to see them die (most specifically Ned). These archetypal characters then get picked off one by one in a summer camp/ forest setting. The film is clichéd, but thinking about when the film was made it probably was one of the first to utilise these conventions alongside other films such as; John Carpenter's Halloween.What makes this film engaging is the mystery surrounding the killer. Those who no little about the franchise other than the hockey masked killer would probably be surprised by the reveal of the killer (whether a good or bad surprise depends). Sadly the mystery, aside from the shooting, unfolds poorly as the evidence embedded is brief and Betsy Palmer gets top billing.The use of the killers POV was interesting but not entirely original as it was famously used in Halloweens opening. It's still good at building tension similar to a pantomime. There is one specific POV shot that I found idiotic as the killer hides behind a tree in an area where trees are sparsely populated, the killer doesn't move and the films protagonist, Alice walks right next to this tree twice, while Bill is looking directly in the killers direction when conversing with Alice. Long story short only the visually impaired would have not noticed the middle aged woman hiding behind a tree.The teens pathetic idiotic nature is expressed several times over the course of this film. Stupid moments include when, as a prank, Ned fires an arrow at a target to which Marcie is stood right in front, and when Alice puts items in front of the door to block it but the door is a pull to open on the outside (to be fair the rope on the handle was pretty smart). Also for Christ's sake somebody put some clothes and shoes on when its pouring with rain outside.Overall, Friday the 13th is a trend setter even if that trend is considered eye rolling and laughable by everyone today. A generic teen slasher film with a kind of weak mystery. It's an of-it's-time film that can be looked back at by some with nostalgia. The film may be over but by the end, Jason's story has just begun.

Review title: Good start for the Jason franchise!
Review_body: This is the first film is the one that started a series of sequels, including a 2009 reboot and a 2003 crossover with the popular "A Nightmare on Elm Street"and along with HALLOWEEN, helped create the slasher genre.Friday THE 13th is interesting from the rest because there is a bit of a mystery as to who the killer is.Of course, if you've seen the other films or any other horror movie including Halloween and A Nightmare on Elm Street, you may know about the killer.Friday THE 13th is about a bunch of young camp counselors who are opening up Camp Crystal Lake after many serious incidents have taken place there over the years. The place kind of has a bad name so to speak. One by one, we see the counselors being stalked in the woods by someone or something.Many of them are killed off leading up to a shocking and horrifying conclusion.The first Jason Voorhees film is not as violent and disturbing as some of today's feature films and Jason films and feature films.This films is a legendary film on it's own. It created the sub-genre of teens being stalked in the woods. Many other films were made after 1980 and with similar plots.This film is a movie that I think needs to be watch every Halloween films. There are some genuine scares like when one girl goes to the out house/washroom and hears noises behind the shower curtains.The acting is not bad. The gore and violence is well done by Tom Savini, the editing is cool, the music by Harry Manfredini and the theme is memorable as hell. Check this movie out before watching the reboot or it's sequels.10/10

"Friday the 13th" is a straight out slasher or splater flick that involves a bunch of camp counselors being killed off by a maniac that is never seen until the ending of the movie.The name of the camp is Camp Crystal Lake and the year is 1979.Camp Crytal Lake has been closed for twenty years due to bizzare events that has happened in the camp.The new counselors are prepping for the camp to open unaware that a killer is on the grounds hacking it's way through the area.Now eventually,two teenagers were murdered twenty years earlier so it assumed by townspeople that this camp is cursed.Camp Blood,they call it."Friday the 13th" involved some graphic scenes for it's time and the splatter effects were done by Tom Savini who worked with George A.Romero on films like "Dawn of the Dead" and "Creepshow".I enjoyed this film but it didn't have the suspense or the impact films like "Psycho" or "Halloween" had.Nevertheless,I found it to be a decent horror film.

Review title: The movie that started it all
Review_body: The very first Friday the 13th is the most influential and most recognizable movie of it's kind and seemed to be the one that defined the slasher horror genre and became a milestone of the 1980s that when people ask what you remember in the 80s, it's no doubt and no denying that people will mention this movie, it's genre and it's other predecessors. Oh yeah, it's true, it's true. This, together with Halloween and Nightmare on Elm Street became legends on the B-movie and horror genre. And next to that, it is the creepiest and most shocking of the whole series before its sequels followed along. Well, you know what they say, the original is always *best*. And even though it's the new millennium, and psychological horror movies or the horror movies from Asia have become popular and made us more frightened than slashers, the unexpected killings and bloodshed, and the methods of Jason's murders and his appearance haunts me to this day. Recommended to all fans of the series and for those who want to know how it all began.

What can I say about "Friday the 13th" that hasn't already been said? For a film that turned twenty-seven years old this year, probably not a whole lot. Still, it is worth noting this film spawned nine direct sequels and a crossover film, "Freddy versus Jason". In which two of the top horror film icons, Freddy Krueger from "A Nightmare on Elm Street" fame and Jason Voorhees must face off in a fight to the death."Friday the 13th" was not as intelligent a film as "Halloween" which was released two years prior, but it is worth renting if only to see a young Kevin Bacon in one of his earlier starring roles as a doomed camper.Anyone who hasn't seen this film but is expecting to see a hockey-masked Jason will be disappointed. It is also worth mentioning Jason doesn't wear the hockey mask until the third film.Overall, would I say "Friday the 13th" is a great film? No. However, I would say it is a classic in its genre, and for horror film fans it is worth the rental. If you're not a horror fan, you might want to pass this up, as it doesn't stand on its own without an appreciation for this type of film.

The acting in this movie is worse than that found in grade school plays. But, the "mysterious" story line for the movie makes this film interesting. Tom Savini's special effects give this movie the boost it needed to create some horrific images that may take you by surprise. I would never want to see this movie again, aside from the effects. You might want to watch this film once just to see what all the hype is about. You may also watch and wonder how Kevin Bacon was able to get acting jobs after his pathetic first role in this film. Anyway, this is kinda cool to watch late at night if you have nothing else to do. I recommend this film to horror film enthusiasts.

Friay Day the 13th is a film to live by because it is for me the start of the 80's and it is the film that defined the that decade. The definition of that decade being do everything Quick, Fast, and Cheap. This type of film making can be seen by almost all films of the decade unless it was made by Spielberg or Lucas or any of there clones. This movie (Friday The 13th) was shot for around $400,000 and made almost 50 million. That is a business procedure that still goes on today. Shoot cheap advertise well and the audience will come regardless of the film's integrity. Except this film has integrity unlike Roger Cormen films from the 50's on which were made just for profit. Yes I know that is in fact how this film started but that is not what it ended up being when the final project was shown before a projector bulb. When you watch the film you can see the love that went in to this monumental undertaking of cheapness. If there had not been that love then this film would have looked like another crappy film from that bygone era, like The Fog which was given a huge budget after the success of Halloween and sucked because John Carpenter brought nothing new too the table. He had to be humbled by the crap that is that film our we never would have gotten the low budget great The Thing. The same thing happened with Sean S. Cunningham after directing Friday The 13th. When he did the big budget dud Deep Star Six he was humbled, but it also killed his directing career. Now he is only a producer who is still looking for that next project that will bring him back to the spot light he deserves like Carpenter gets. Until such time though I will sit back and relish his masterpiece that is Friaday The 13th.

Review title: WE ALL GO A LITTLE MAD SOMETIMES!!!!!
Review_body: The creators of this movie must have been having one of those moments Norman Bates tells us about in PSYCHO, we all go a little mad sometimes. They must of been mad, because the final outcome of this movie was a complete waste of film. Kevin Bacon plays a councilor in one of his earlier roles. And tell me this since when does a woman have hairy hands, look like a man but turns out to be a woman.  PATHETIC!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

In honor of Friday the 13th, I decided to pop in the 'ol 1980 Cunningham classic "Friday the 13th". I remember the first time seeing it and thinking to myself "that was a damn good movie". Keep in mind, I was half my age too. Even with still being a horror fan since childhood, I can easily say I don't know how the hell I liked this film the first time around considering it almost put me to sleep at about the midpoint of its running time.My biggest gripe with this Halloween rip-off (I'm quoting the director people!), is the pacing. I kid you not, there are shots of absolutely nothing filling the screen and they can run as long as five minutes. If you were to actually compile all the deaths and fights/mayhem into one movie, it'd be as long as a Youtube video.Now I'm one for character development, but these characters are some of the most unlikable people I've come across. You have your genre staples, okay I get it's a run-of-the-mill slasher, but never have I suffered this much through such wooden acting. Is it bad to say I really didn't care the final girl either?And what is up with everyone saying the kills are tremendous. If you blink, you'll miss it! Not only did the MPAA butcher the hell out of these scenes, an axe to the face is hardly what I call trend-setting. Why do I think Friday the 13th retained its notoriety? For one, the clever plot twist. I might have my gripes with the pacing/characters, but one thing is that out of all the by-the-number slasher plots, this one mixes up the formula just enough to give you a taste of something new. Also, while this film is touted for its kills, it actually racks up some decent tension in its early kills. Is it embarrassing to say I was actually on the edge of my seat at some parts? And lastly, the ending. It may be a cliffhanger, but again, it's a smart one at that. What do I think would make Friday the 13th even more of a classic? Get a new editor, fight with the MPAA until you get rights to your kills, and hire a new cast. Oh right, they did that with the new remake. Strangely enough, they're both the same (quality-wise). Well, I guess no matter if you re-make Jason, pit him against Freddy, this is just one story that (so far) has not bode well from script to silver screen. What a shame.

Review title: Arguably the most influential slasher film of all time
Review_body: The original Friday the 13th is not the first, the most original, or the best slasher film ever made, but it is arguably the most influential. You almost have to take off one of your socks to count all of the sequels (and impending remake) this slasher granddaddy has spawned, and I daresay the majority of slasher films littering the genre in all the years since were constructed on the generic and simple framework of the Friday the 13th formula. Critics are still foaming at the mouth in indignation over this film all these years later, so you know it did something right. Of course, by today's standards Friday the 13th registers low (if at all) on the fright meter and really isn't all that gory, but no one can dispute the fact that this film set the stage for innumerable bloody slasher films to come.Halloween, which is technically a much superior film to this one, had already been released and made lots of money, so it's easy to see why Sean S. Cunningham (who had already cut his horror chops on The Last House on the Left) wanted to try his hand at creating a scary slasher film of his own. Cunningham did not have a big studio backing him, so he had to make this an independent, low-budget (barely more than half a million dollars) project

This movie is really underrated it isn't as bad as its ratings make it to be. The movie is a fun camp slasher in the woods with lots of fun kills and the start to an infamous slasher series with the birth of Jason. The movie is really fun and may not be great all times but it is still entertaining and just a great watch.

'Psycho' may be the grand daddy of slasher films, 'Halloween' may be the father, but this is the sick son that hooked a whole decade of teens and spawned 10 (if you count Freddy vs. Jason) sequels, a TV series and created arguably the most recognizable horror figure of the last 20 years.Camp Crystal Lake is set to open for the first time in 20+ years, following the unsolved murders of two camp counselors. Despite warnings from the locals about it being cursed and a history of misfortune, the group of kids go about fixing the place up. As night falls and a storm rolls in, they are all about to discover that some warnings should be headed. Thus begins the 24 hour nightmare of blood.Production values are about on par with it's obvious inspiration 'Halloween', yet the film feels lower budget. Part of this is due to the somewhat empty headed dialogue and unevenness to the editing. There are also some lighting issues and some janky physical action marring the experience as well. But this is a low-budget 80's horror film, so most of that is wholly forgivable, especially given what the film does right.The two major achievements of the film are the atmosphere and the death scenes, the most important parts of any slasher film. The camp location and the woods surrounding it really do take on a life of their own, almost becoming an additional character. Combined with the pitch black storm of the second half of the movie and that great synthesized score it all makes for a perfect night for a murder.And what glorious murders they are. Slashings, stabbings, impailments, courtesy of Tom Savini, all performed with the care and detail that any other artist might put into a painting or a sheet of music. Not wanting to spoil the bits for anyone who has not gotten around to this film yet, I will just say that gore-hounds will not be disappointed.The only real hurt this film puts on the viewer comes during the final chase scene. I will not ruin the scenario by divulging details, just know that it continues for far too long, contains painfully impossible events and damn near sabotages the entire film by approaching self-parody.A quick note on the MPAA rating of the film. Yes, there is a longer, gorier cut of the film than the US R-rated version; and no, it is neither better nor must see material. The uncut version runs about 30-ish seconds longer, but the R-rated version works better as the scenes cut before the SFX start to look fake. If you absolutely must see the full version it is fairly easy to find.The film is pretty dated by modern standards, but the gore holds up well and should more than appease any and all slasher fans.8/10

As a child, I was not allow to watch any of these movies, as they are R rated horror flicks that contains nudity, violence, etc. I do remember one of my vague memories when "Friday the 13th: Part 3" came on TNN before it became Spike TV, and Paramount Network, I remember seeing Jason in a hockey mask chasing some girl at a barn. Heck, I remember when my uncle brought a copy of the movie when he rented from a video store, and I sneakily put the tape in to see Jason on an old VHS tape and seeing a brief snippet of him he did look quiet scary. After that, my mother caught me, and I turned it off. Never intend to watch it, I just only wanted to see Jason for a bit and that was it. With that said, here is my review of the first one that started it all, before Jason became the main killer, as well as putting on his iconic hockey, brought back as zombie, going to Manhattan, Hell, space, fighting Freddy Krueger, and being rebooted. The first film's plot is pretty simple, as you have a group of teenagers that are trying to reopen Camp Crystal Lake, but something evil is lurking them as it kills its victims. When I first saw this movie, I really love it, but as time goes by, I began to recognize its flaws. Nevertheless, its far from being a bad movie, and it is not the worst thing ever as critics make it out to be when it first came out. There is a lot of good things to say, where is the bad isn't that much, nor that big of a deal. To start off, I thought that Tom Savini's makeup FX are outstanding, and really is a master at it. The movie does have some great kills such as putting an axe on Jeannine Taylor's face, as well as having an arrow into Kevin Bacon's neck. The music by Harry Manfredini is completely unforgettable, he made that theme sound so iconic and everyone always like to remember that theme, when something bad is about to happen when you hear "Ki Ki Ki Ma Ma Ma." Totally classic. Taking place in the woods is great, and really does have that surreal atmosphere quality as you do feel somewhat unsettle as if you were alone in the woods. The characters I'll admit, aren't really three dimensional as you would seen in other great horror films, but at the end they are still likable. The acting isn't the greatest, but its really not that bad either. They all did fine for what they have to do; the best actors, in my opinion are Adrienne King and Betsy Palmer. For King, she really does have a natural beauty, and for having the girl next door type. Now for Palmer, she is having a blast with this role, and you can't take your eyes off on how fun she is for playing Jason's mother. The plot is simplistic as it needs to be, and the direction by Sean S. Cunningham is very solid. While as much as I love Palmer's performance, it would have been interesting if she had more screen time, if the audiences would have thought that she is a nice woman, before the twist ending is being revealed that she is the killer. Imagine that. Also, while I do love the character of Alice, I do notice a character error, where she runs away from Pamela Voorhees as she gets into the Jeep, but doesn't drive off as she screams by one of the victims that Pam killed. Don't get me wrong, I do love the climax, but for a realistic standpoint, she should know that the Jeep has gas in it, and could have turned the keys over so she can get herself out of there. The Jeep has gas, when Pam first arrives at the camp. Just saying. Lastly, I do love the last scene, which I'll admit, I did get jumped by the last scene, where Jason played by Ari Lehman jumps out off the water to pull Alice into the water. Very scary, to say the least. All in all, no matter what flaws this movie has, "Friday the 13th" is a fun thrill ride that has great kills, scare factors, unforgettable music, and likable characters. I'm giving this movie a 9 out of 10.

Review title: the best of the series CONTAINS SPOILERS
Review_body: i was reading some reveiws for this movie and so many people bashed it and for what this movie is a classic, in 1957 a young boy named Jason drowned at camp crystal lake, his body was never found, the very next year two teens were killed, now the camp has been shut down for about 20 years, then a man decides to open up the camp again, so now on Friday the 13th, a bunch of horny teens fixing up the camp all find themselves getting gutted, the story to this movie was great, for a low budget film there were alot of good kills in this movie. though it's a classic it can get a little slow at times, i believe there were 9 kills in this movie and it did need them to push forward. the story is original so that's a plus, the acting was ok but hey it's a horror movie not an oscar worthy movie. i give this movie 9/10 a must see for all true horror fans out there

Review title: It exceeded my expectations...though my expectations were rather low
Review_body: Friday the 13th exceeded my expectations, though keep in mind my expectations were not very high. It did two things right that surprised me. Number one: the music is pretty solid. It was very tension filled and I liked it. Number two: they didn't show the bad guy till the very end. For once, a horror movie realized that fear of the unknown is way more terrifying than cheap jump scares. This movie has its fair share of drawbacks though. It condones some of the age old horror movie clichés (nudity/sex= death, car doesn't start, two left feet, etc.), and the end is just all around terrible. Every action the remaining character takes is stupid and the fight scenes look terrible. With all this combined, I can say Friday the 13th isn't the worst, but it really isn't all that good either. 5/10.

Believe it or not, but some people walked out because they were scared.Anyways, this movie set the standard for many more in the genre to follow.Still a good movie to watch.For some reason I like the beginning, with Annie on her way to Camp Blood. The scenery, the atmosphere, just like it.

It feels almost redundant to post a review of a movie as iconic as this one, but here goes. I assume 99% of people reading this have seen it already, but if not, watch out for spoilers, yo.Friday the 13th (which was almost titled Long Night at Camp Blood) may not have been anyone's pet project — the director, Sean S. Cunningham, admitted that it was an attempt to ride off the success of John Carpenter's Halloween, which was released two years prior, and the writer, Victor Miller, wrote the script in two weeks — but it's a cult classic for a reason. It didn't do that well when it was first released — it made about $39 million at box office but received many negative reviews, including a particularly scathing commentary from Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert (who didn't even bother to hide the ending from readers). And, technically speaking, it's not that amazing of a movie — some forgettable characters, mostly weak dialogue. But it continues to gain popularity even to this day.It's really a classic slasher flick. A bunch of young counselors have arrived at camp early to help set up and are murdered one by one by a mysterious killer. It's got the short shorts, the stormy night, and the obligatory sex scene (with Kevin Bacon and the stunning Jeannine Taylor, no less). But you really do feel the tension mounting as the movie progresses, partially due to the use of music by Harry Manfredini.As soon as Annie — innocent, freckled little Annie — gets her throat slit in the woods, I was immediately reminded of how surprisingly good the murder scenes are. They aren't over the top gory and aren't drawn out too long — it's just a quick, efficient kill and then on to the anticipation of the next one.I liked that we never saw a hint of the killer beyond maybe their feet, or a hand on a shower curtain — it's really effective in adding to the already tense mood, not to mention, of course, hiding the surprise reveal until the very end. Speaking of which, I really enjoyed the twist — again, SPOILER ALERT, but y'all know this already. Having the killer be Mrs. Voorhees was just awesome. Exacting revenge on behalf of her son, neglected by camp counselors while he drowned in the lake brilliant. And her talking with herself — or talking "with Jason" — was creepily well done. It may not be my favorite classic horror movie — of the trio (Friday the 13th, Halloween, and Nightmare on Elm Street), I'm wayyyy more of a Freddy girl.

To tell you the truth, I thought that some of the others were better than the first one, at least they had some nice twists in the end. Truly suspenseful, and the violence is pretty good. A no brainer that is sure to entertain you for years. I first saw this when I was 6 and almost 10 years later I still enjoy watching this.

Review title: Cheap thrills...cheap shots...in this piece of crap !
Review_body: Giving this "film" a 4 rating is very generous to my thinking. It ranks as one of the very worst on my list ( I enjoyed "Plan 9 from Outer Space" more than this!). Though , true, it made money for a very troubled Paramount and, true, it did wonders for Betsy Palmer and Kevin Bacon in terms of recognition, my position remains steadfast. It is a piece of crap, and was one of the films that put cinema--or aspects of it--on a decided course...a "race to the bottom". This film was more of a chore and a bore...and I am only horrified by its success at the box office. It was a very difficult watch...there is no order to the storyline, and I did not care what the heck happened to most of the characters, as they seemed to be jerks and bimbos. Manfredini's music score borrowed heavily from Bernard Herrmann's famous music cues for "Psycho", and I was appalled by the un-original touch his screeching strings let out, allegedly heightening the terror of the scene...but failing to do so successfully. This film failed to deliver, I would not want to see it or any of its derivatives ever again, and...it helped give "bad movies" a new definition.

Review title: Despite not being that good, part of the slasher canon
Review_body: We all know the story: a group of horny good-looking teens (and token geek) forgo common sense and adult supervision and, on a day of portentous note, are routinely slaughtered...usually after being so morally bankrupt as to have had pre-marital sex. Even if you haven't seen 'Friday the 13th' itself you have almost certainly seen a movie which is basically the same. Okay, 'Friday the 13th' can excuse itself from the charge of being clichéd due to the fact that it was the very success of the movie that established the clichés we have come to be so bored of. However, what it can't save itself from is the charge of just not being a good movie.Inspired by the box-office success John Carpenter's 'Halloween' enjoyed a couple of years previously, Sean Cunningham (previously known for producing Wes Craven's video nasty 'Last House on the Left') borrowed elements from films such as Mario Bava's 'Bay of Blood', DePalma's 'Carrie', Bob Clark's 'Black Christmas', and the aforementioned 'Halloween', and managed to codify the fledgling slasher genre into the trope-ridden cliché fest we have had to suffer since. This was done with the help of a one-dimensional approach to direction and script which stripped away any semblance of complexity or genuine suspense (save a couple of moments), and the lack of development of the maniac-fodder characters who, at any rate, are expressed with corny acting. The film only really distinguishes itself by its kills which, in ramping up the gore to 11 courtesy of special effects maestro Tom Savini, are pretty cool. However, existing in isolation from anything else of technical note (specifically the lack of character development) sanitises any horror and makes the film funny which (intentional or not) detracts significantly from any atmosphere it could have had.However, while I don't rate the film in terms of quality (and would recommend any of the previously mentioned films for the true would-be horror-phile) there's no denying the impact the film had in both establishing beyond doubt the slasher genre as a viable commercial form (and opening the door for some quite interesting slashers that followed) and also destroying the genre (as quite a lot of truly pale imitations also came through that door) and as a result it is basically a set text for those wishing to explore the realm of late 70s/early 80s American horror.
I really enjoy the first Friday film! The camp setting is perfect and some of the kills are pretty memorable! If your a fan of slashers or just the horror genre check out this film!

Review title: Setting the standard for horror films to this day.
Review_body: Film critic Leonard Maltin once said that the reason why kids back in 1980 were scoring low on SAT's nationwide was that because they were filling up seats of theaters that were showing "Friday the 13th", meaning he had no clue as to why these kids would find this movie slightly entertaining. Numerous sequels and millions of dollars of box-office money later, I believe Maltins words at this point are irrelevant. This movie was a genuine shocker to me, Sean Cunningham had previous experience in trauma/make you feel creeped out flicks working with legendary filmmaker Wes Craven on "The Last House on The Left" which is probably more terrifying than Friday the 13th but Cunningham showed in this movie that he hadn't lost his touch nor flair for filmaking yet. Betsy Palmer turns in a great performance as the obsessed/oppressed mother of a child who drowned as a boy. Adrienne King does a good job as Alice (the main character) and we can't forget good 'ol Kevin Bacon, we love ya man. This movie really got the slasher flick ball rollin' real quick, many greats followed such as "The Burning" "The Prowler" "Nightmare on Elm Street" and so on and so forth. I personally prefer the 2nd installment (part 2) because of the inclusion of Jason but this movie still gives me creeps. The night scenes are shot so darkly that it's actually very eerie when you watch it with the sound blaring and the lights out. 9/10 no problem rating this one.

This movie is a lot a fun to this day, and it's just the cheesy horror nostalgia I needed to cheer up. This series might not be the best, but I love them all, and I still can't deny that they are fun movies that I have grown up with to love.

Review title: A lot of fun for any fan of the slasher genre.
Review_body: I've seen this movie many times and it's still a lot of fun to watch.  It's very easily among the best in the whole series and one of the best horror films of its kind.  Perfect if you're in the mood to watch something creepy. I'd recommend it to any fan of the slasher genre.

Review title: A good start to the series
Review_body: I really loved this movie, especially the first time you watch it or haven't watched it in a long time.  This movie isn't really a rip-off from Halloween.  The little boy in Halloween killed his sister because he was a druid and the evil spirits made him. In Friday The 13th, kids were getting killed as a punishment for having sex when they were supposed to be doing their job watching the swimmers.  Because of their hormones, a little boy (Jason) drowned in the lake. One year later 2 kids who were doing, you guessed it screwing their heads off, for having sex. Flash forward to today. Steve Christy wants to open the camp after 10 years for children. Several of camp counselers come up one week early to help Steve fix the place up. When Steve leaves to go to town all hell breaks loose. It starts to storm, strange things begin to happen, and one by one the adults get hacked into pieces.  Who will live and who is the killer? Just watch the movie and you will be pleasantly surprised.

With that title I am sure most people will expect me to say that I hate this film... I assure you I do not.  I snuck into see this film when I was about 9 or 10, the second film had already come out and everyone was talking about it (I had an cousin who was 4 years older than me and he would describe the kill scenes in these movies in gory detail... I was enthralled).  If you want my defense for why I watch these movies, read my review for John Carpenter's Halloween, here I will stick to the first Friday film.The movie has no Jason in it, in fact it is almost an intelligent thriller (almost), but it wallows in its own exploitiveness too thoroughly to be that.  However, this film does have a certain charm to it, I don't really know why.  I still rent it about once every couple of years, I still watch it and still find myself amused 20 years later (I can't believe that this film is 20 years old, where is the 20th anniversary, digitally enhanced re-release? ;), but I can't really explain why.This film obviously has become one of those 'rites of passage' movies that all teenage boys must see in order to be considered cool (maybe girls too, I dunno).   I guess that this is enough to keep it culturally viable, but there must be something else to it.  I would get into issues about the sexual revolution, the confusion of the late 70s and the dawning of Reagan era, but I don't really want to bore anyone.  Ultimately, no matter how lame this film is, it will always have an audience, and no matter how old I get, I continue to go and see these films, even when I know that they will be terrible.  I guess ultimately the kill scenes and the boob shots are something for adolescent males to talk about, and adult males to remember what it was like to be an adolescent male. 
Overall, while I cannot really recommend this movie to people, I know I don't have to.  I know people will go and see it anyway, which is good I suppose, since I really do have a soft place in my heart for these goofy, gory, misogynistic violence-fests.  I don't know why, but they are part of my history and I can't bring myself to deny them.  And most of you probably can't either ;)

Review_body: I am a major fan of the Friday the 13th films. I have seen all of them,and this certainly isn't best. It wasn't a bad movie,but horror movies with a woman psycho involved just do not scare me....Alright!Possibly a few shakes! The acting was awful,but hey the actings awful in all Fridays!
