I still shake my head when I remember the sensation this film caused when it was released. I guess the teenage market was primed and ready for blood and mayhem. That can be the only explanation why this marginal at best horror film made millions and spawned so many sequels which were even worse then this.It's not a terrible movie. It's not the worst horror film I have ever seen. It's a bad movie though. It is ineptly directed and written, the editing is so choppy you will swear you are on a boat, and the acting is just terrible. The casting director must have cast the actors based on their looks without having them read a line. The film is needlessly bloody to a fault. Do we really need to see an arrow in someone's eye? Or repeated shots of throats being slit? This is more like a geek show.The ending has a surprise scare which does work (at least it did on me back in 1980) but is really just a ripoff of the ending of "Carrie".

Review title: From the ashes of 70s horror, a new era emerges...
Review_body: If you want to get technical about it and are a true horror fan like I, you would know that "Friday the 13th" is actually a knock-off of "Halloween" (1978), which in itself is a knock-off of "Black Christmas" made 4 years prior to that. But if you dig deeper into the birth of slasher movies, you can go a bit earlier to 1971 with the foreign film by Mario Bava called "Bay of Blood" aka "Twitch of the Death Nerve". But, it was "Friday the 13th" that was the pied piper that would lead an endless list of great (and not so great) slasher films in the early '80s. It basically blasted the sub-genre of slasher horror from it's cabin door hinges! So, enough about the origins of the slasher era, we'll get to the classic that is Friday THE 13th! The film is next to perfect in it's execution (haha, no pun intended?). A decent cast for what you're gonna get in a low budget picture like this. They really lucked out with Kevin Bacon. And Betsy Palmer really stole the show as the worst mother in movie history since Faye Dunaway's role as Joan Crawford in "Mommie Dearest"! The atmosphere is great, and the location where it was filmed is the best out of any Friday the 13th movie (the worst location being part 3...was THAT mudhole even a lake?). The good thing about this movie (as opposed to the many artless imitations out there) is that the tension builds gradually until it hits a grand apex. This, however, is one of the things some people find annoying about this movie, but unless you have ADHD then you will follow the story as it gains momentum. I won't get into a detailed description of the plot itself in this review(everyone should know the plot by now),I just wanted to take the time to point out the greatness of this film in the horror universe. Further, the ending is the still one of the most frightening and heart stopping moments in horror history! No one can deny that.There are a few things that taint this otherwise flawless piece of work, and that is the highly edited death scenes. I know that it was the MPAA that did it and not the director or anyone involved in the film, but I think they should have tried to get away with a lot more. There are simply too many off-screen murders! Out of 10 deaths, 5 of them are off screen which is mainly because they couldn't get away with showing the scene because it was "too violent" and also because the effects didn't work out the way they were intended. I have read that Brenda's death scene was originally her being impaled by a few arrows while standing in the rain at the archery, but it was cut by the MPAA. Marcie's face axing scene was intended to be shown without any film cuts which means you would have seen the ax hit her face, but they couldn't get the effects just right to do it that way so they had to cut away to the ax, then show her fall to the floor with the ax in her face (still turned out very well). The quick cuts of the death scenes is another annoyance (once again you can thank the MPAA), you get no more than a full second of screen time on any given end result of a gore killing. The one standout gore scene in the whole movie goes to the death of Kevin Bacon's character Jack who gets an arrow through the neck from the killer hiding under the bed (a scenario that creeped me out as a kid!) They show everything, and the fact that they didn't have computer graphics back then really showed the filmmaker's creativity in doing these death scenes from scratch. BUT don't even try to watch this on network TV, because you may not even notice you're watching a horror film. It's overly (and needlessly) edited of all gore.Although some of it's sequels may surpass this film's body count, visual effects, and coolness factor, they will never match the sheer shock value that this movie possesses. And that is simply why this is the best one in the series.

Review title: Camp Crystal Lake, It's Got A Death Curse
Review_body: Friday the 13th has interesting beginnings. Sean Cunningham put out an ad for the film and called it "the scariest film ever made" when, in reality, there wasn't even a script written for the film. He wanted to see if he'd get sued for using the name, luckily he didn't, and with the help of some investors, made the movie.Many people at the time felt that this film was a rip off of Halloween, which had been released just a couple of years earlier, but Friday would go on to have its own imitators.This first film in the series is considered a horror classic and it's a well thought out story; there's a motive for the murder, the cast is great, the score is superb and it has one of the best endings of any horror film. If you love horror and have not seen Friday the 13th, stop what you are doing and watch this classic right away.

Review title: Tedious drivel. Makes you wonder how it ever spawned any sequels.
Review_body: Sean Cunningham needed to make some money fast, and this was the result.  A group of teenagers stay in a camp which has been re-opened again some years after a young boy drowned in the nearby lake.I won't bore anyone with details of the plot because there isn't one.  It's just one gory murder after another, a feeble cash-in on the superior 'Halloween'.  There's not a sympathetic victim in the film so you couldn't care less what happens to anyone.  In fact some of the teenagers are so downright obnoxious you often find yourself applauding when they're finally dispensed with after the obligatory wandering around calling out 'is anyone there?' in monotonous fashion.  Things are very boring and slow-moving, virtually the only worthwhile part of the film being its climax out on the lake.  Mrs Voorhees is effective and actually comes across as the one character in the film who approaches being sympathetic.  The music has its ups and downs.  The climax/closing credits tune is great, but the music during the opening credits sounds like someone honking a car horn.It has to be mentioned that the worst part of the film is a harmless snake being brutally chopped up in loving detail by one of the teenagers, after which one of his cronies makes a comment about 'knowing what's for dinner'. This whole scene made me want to be physically sick.  Whatever possessed Cunningham into thinking people would give a damn about these characters?

I was really looking forward to watching this because I heard many good things about it. After watching it, I pleaded for the ending to come.The story is good but the whole entire film I think it just leads off the tension. As the film went, I thought I was going to go to sleep.I just lost interest.The acting is average but there is no connection with the characters.The ending was a good climax, with me thinking "thank god, something is actually happening bu then ended just like that.Mrs Vorhees was good psycho, but I think thats only character you connect with.I'm a huge horror film fan but not this movie.

Friday the 13th is a 1980 independent slasher film directed by Sean S. Cunningham and written by Victor Miller.Although the film was poorly received by most, if not all, mainstream film critics, it went on to become one of the most popular slasher films in cinema history, and was the first movie of its kind to secure distribution by a major studio (Paramount Pictures). The film's box office success led to a long series of sequels.Production Friday the 13th was produced by Sean S. Cunningham, who had previously worked with filmmaker Wes Craven on the film The Last House on the Left. Cunningham was inspired by the success of John Carpenter's influential Halloween, and conceived Friday the 13th as an exploitation film that would cash-in on the success of Halloween. Ironically, Friday the 13th became a huge box-office hit, caused even more slasher films to be made, and spawned a seemingly unending franchise of sequels.The script was written by Victor Miller, who has gone on to write for several television soap operas, including Guiding Light, One Life to Live, and All My Children. Miller delighted in inventing a serial killer who turned out to be somebody's mother, a murderer whose only motivation was her love for her child. "...I took motherhood and turned it on its head and I think that was great fun. Mrs. Voorhees was the mother I'd always wanted - a mother who would have killed for her kids." Miller was unhappy about the filmmakers' decision to add Jason Voorhees to the film, making him leap out of the lake at the end to grab the heroine. "Jason was dead from the very beginning. He was a victim, not a villain." The idea of Jason appearing at the end of the film was not in the original script, and was actually suggested by makeup designer Tom Savini. Savini said "The whole reason for the cliffhanger at the end was I had just seen Carrie, so we thought that we need a 'chair jumper' like that and I said, 'let's bring in Jason.'".

Review title: It will always be a favorite horror flick!
Review_body: "Friday The 13th" was well-hated by film critics when it was released to theaters in 1980. Many film critics blasted Paramount Pictures for releasing the movie, and they also tried to shame Betsy Palmer for her role in the movie. The movie was also slammed along with other slasher movies as violence against women, but this is incorrect with "Friday The 13," because more men are murdered than women. The movie made a lot of money at the box office, which resulted in several sequels. The plot is very simple (SPOILERS ahead): a killer is stalking the staff of a summer camp; killing them one by one until there is one staff member left. That staff member (Adrienne King) must battle the killer to save her life.  The plot was meant to be simple, but thought and care went into the low-budget production. The movie was well filmed, and the night scenes are nicely atmospheric. Other nice atmospheric touches are squeaking doors, and the sounds in the forest that surround the summer camp. There's even a nicely done thunderstorm as the evening turns into a night of terror. The acting is mostly average and the movie does have its shortcomings, but I gladly overlook them because I have enjoyed this movie over and over. The original music by Harry Manfredini is creepy, and quite effective. Tom Savini created the gruesome special effects for the murders that are shown. It is interesting that "Friday The 13th" was one of Kevin Bacon's first movies. Betsy Palmer appearing as a maniac was also interesting, and quite a switch from her previous film and television appearances. Also of interest is that Bing Crosby's son, Harry Crosby, had starred in such a movie. "Friday The 13th" is a low-budget and simple shocker that succeeds in entertaining. It will always be a favorite horror flick of mine! This film is rated R, and contains graphic violence, gore, drug use, sexuality, and nudity.

Review title: Thank You Mario Bava for inspiring Sean Cunningham!!!
Review_body: Back in the early 70's 10 years before the slasher craze in the United States, Mario Bava from Italy created a film that would be the apparatus for slasher horror for years to come. That film was Twitch of the Death Nerve ( released on VHS under the dubious title Bay of Blood ). This film really introduced the stalk and slash that would become the landscape for American horror for almost two decades. Friday the 13th was born at the dawn of the 1980's and was followed by a myriad of sequels. This the original still holds up today as a creepy piece of slasher celluloid and features a young Kevin Bacon meeting his demise. Rookie fans looking for Jason's traditional hockey mask must wait until the second sequel.

This is a movie about a boy named Jason( who becomes the hockey -masked killer in the series), who gets drouned at Camp Crystal Lake, and his mother starts killing off camp counselors one by one. A dark movie. Kevin Bacon is in this movie for A little while(much younger looking though.) Rated R : for Gory Violence, and Sex.

Review title: So this is what the fuss is about...
Review_body:
Well this movie (along with The Exorcist and The Omen) was aired where I live on... yeah, you guessed it- Friday the 13th (of October, if it's of any importance). After watching The Exorcist this movie was very refreshing. I can't compare between the two. The Exorcist and Friday the 13th are very different movies. But after the chills that the Exorcist sent up my spine watching a slasher-flick (which The Exorcist is not) was very refreshing.
Of course I already knew who the killer was because they have to mention this movie in every post Scream movie and Dawson's Creek episode but it didn't ruin it for me. This movie did deliver chills and was very much worth watching. The acting was not bad for a horror movie. I really started liking Annie, in fact I thought the movie would revolve around her, boy was I wrong. The end was a bit strange and ruined the very possibility of 'realistic' in this movie but I don't regret watching- hey look what a fuss it started!

Terror and suspense abound in this 24-hour nightmare of blood. Camp Crystal Lake has been shuttered for over 20 years due to several vicious and unsolved murders. The camp's new owner and several young counsellors are readying the property for re-opening despite warnings of a "death curse" by local residents. The curse proves true as one by one each of the counsellors is stalked by a violent killer. This film is widely acclaimed for it's horrifying and creative murder sequences.This film starred Betsy Palmer, Adrienne King & Kevin Bacon.This was the start of the Friday The 13th movies which consists of 10 films + a remake and if you want to count it Freddy Vs Jason. It isn't the best of the series but it was a good start to an entertaining series***/***** good

While it no doubt started a huge trend (maybe even more so than Halloween), Friday the 13th is a modest little movie that's not even that well made or revolutionary in its storytelling. It takes the low budget grit and realism of Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Black Christmas, and other low budget horrors of the 70's and mixes it with an Agatha Christie whodunnit angle. The killer reveal (which is still so great that I hesitate to reveal it due to spoilers) wasn't that novel either and several people of that type had been depicted as killers before.Even the film's gripping chair jumper finale was lifted from Carrie. So, what was it that made this one so special? There had been gore on screen before, but it was always of the bright red, candy colored variety and not particularly realistic. It was Tom Savini's realistic effects that really offered something different and unique that we'd never seen before and he's probably the true unsung genius in this film.

Review title: This film is 20 years old.Hard to believe.The film...
Review_body: This film is 20 years old.Hard to believe.The film basic plot is well known by now.The scares are there in this film.Mrs Palmer does a good job in this film.These films were always made to have you jump out of your seat and spilling your popcorn as a direct result. I love the sounds of the night and rain in the first 2 films.There is some beautiful country in this film.Hollywood ruined this series do to its own greed.Year after year they threw a friday the 13 out there.People tired of it by the mid 80s.I give the orginal 7 out of ten stars.The sequels g are horrible from part 7-9.

There is some suspense as well.They should have stopped at part 3. The sequels all stunk up the moviehouse.

Friday the 13 is a strange film.The film is a combination of mystery,horror and comedy. What is it? The woods give the film a secluded spot. Both part 1 and 2 did this well.The music is okay. The main trouble is the characters are wooden. Halloween had people you cared about. The friday movies treat people like fodder.The film depends on gore for its money. Real suspense does not need GORE. Halloween, TCM, Psycho, Jaws all depend on the thought of gore. Friday the 13 is A 7 out of 10.

"Ki Ki Ki Ki Ki! Ha! Ha! Ha! Ha! Ha!" That signature sound goes right up your spine. Tension builds with each gruesome demise. I was constantly shocked by the variety & suddenness. The makeup & effects are impressive. "Camp Blood" is indeed the perfect name for the site. The silent, unseen killer is genuinely scary. When its identity is revealed, the actor gives full justice. The younger cast are keen and likable. The "Prophet of Doom" fits the role perfectly. The ending does not disappoint. The score supports it brilliantly. Definitely one of the classics. 10/10

The entire movie plays on fear of the killer getting our councilors and it proves that POV shots from the killer are effective to see when they are going to kill. the cast were great at being what they were suppose to be teenagers who are enjoying a summer job. Kevin Bacon and Betsy Palmer were two stars who shone in their roles but the overall story line made up one of the most iconic horror movie franchise of all time and while their is a lack of the iconic Jason Vorhees any fan of the series will be happy to tell you that's not the last you will see of him. The movie does what it's supposed to and gives us gore and violence and that's what i would expect from a horror. This one is a great start and from after this one the fans will see and enjoy more gore and blood.

Friday the 13th is a classic masterpiece, it uses a clever sort of storytelling to hide the identity of the killer as well as who the main character is to the end. For a slasher movie, it's not as bloody as a modern slasher, but it still delivers brutal kills. The music and sound effects are all great. The suspense-building is great as you can kinda figure out when someone's is going to get murdered. And without spoiling anything, the acting of the killer is truly terrifying! Some acting is kind of cheesy but that doesn't change mutch. It has a great atmosphere and after rewatching it, Friday the 13th from 1980 is now one of my favourite horror movies of all time! Overall it's a must see movie with a score of 9/10 from me!

Review title: Am I The Only One Who Hates The 1st One!?
Review_body: Supposedly the film along with Halloween that kicked off the 80's slasher franchise, Friday the 13th is nothing but a preposterous, stupid rip-off of John Carpenter's brilliant horror masterpiece. True, the familiar slasher hallmarks are developed further, for example: the promiscuous teenagers, the wise oracle who warns them of the impending danger, the isolated woodland setting and notably in this the gore by the legendary Tom Savini. But none of this means anything unless the key ingredient of the slasher, the killer, is convincing and lets face it pretty darn menacing. This is ruined by the most ridiculous killer of the 80's slasher film influx and throw in unconvincing, cliché slasher fodder and pretty unoriginal, predictable direction from Last House on the Left producer Sean Cunningham and you have a total waste of time. The series definitely got better when Jason appeared!3/10

I consider Friday the 13th a classic, however it is nowhere near being a perfect film in the horror genre. The acting is mediocre, and the story at some parts is dull. However, this film is still very enjoyable 41 years later.
This was the start of the Friday the 13th movies but it was simple and boring but I guess for the 1980s this was a scary movie but watching it now it's just plain and simple.

Review title: This film does deliver some genuine shocks.
Review_body: It has to be said...this film is good for what it does.The storyline is ever so simple, a kid drowns in Camp Crystal Lake and ever since then, someone has been killing anyone who comes near there.HERE'S THE PLOT TWIST, AND THERE ARE A FEW MORE!!! **** the killer is the mother of the kid. Mrs Voorhees.No-one expected the twist, it was quite a good way to surprise us as a viewewr. But why oh why do the killer's ALWAYS have to tell us the reasons why they kill in such OTT performance's? Look at later films such as Scream - OTT. Urban Legends - OTT. It becomes laughable.*** But, nonetheless, the mother's reason's are understandable, but then again, the death of her son has got absolutely nothing to do with the new batch of students who have come to 'Camp Blood'. Of course, if she thought that, then we wouldn't have a film!!!Good for what it does, being a film from the early early 80's, and redefining the 'slasher' genre, this film delivers some very good shocks and some gruesome deaths. Of course, the killings all occur on the fateful date Friday the 13th.  All the cast are unknowns, so we don't know who, if any will survive the film. That's always a good thing, it keeps us guessing. When I first watched this film, I convinced myself that the first character we see in the 'present' day would be the main character. Shame really, cos she was kinda cute. That's what happens when you have a cast of unknowns.Some of the deaths/murders are quite unexpected and shocking, although they're a little bit dated, don't hold that against it.This film, although not totally unique, does deliver a few good shocks and as I've said, the end twist is a nice touch. Another nice touch is the definite ending. *** Now we weren't expecting THAT!!! Jason makes an appearance, as a child!!!!So the director left an open opportunity for a sequel?? Judging by this first installment, it might be quite good.6/10

Review title: The most amazing thing about this film is that with such a thin plot it spawned 10 sequels.
Review_body: A holiday camp that has been closed for 20 years or so because of some murders is reopening and a group of one dimensional teenage workers then start to frolic about in their underwear while a serial kills them off one by one. The music and the camera shots that are from the perspective of the killer without revealing the killer are the only things this film has going for it and even they are not a patch on John Carpenter films made around the same time.

The 1980's saw the rise of the Slasher film sub genre and many films were created as a result. Most of those are still well known for this day and countless remakes and sequels were made as well. One of the more notable slasher films out there is Friday the 13th, and this short review will be talking about the film that started it all.The basic idea of this story was that a group of teenagers go to this old camp as a counselor retreat. They go to Camp Crystal Lake for the weekend. Various people tell the teenagers not to go there since it's cursed and people have been killed there.A bad storm arrives and one by the one the counselors are killed off by a killer.I won't give away the rest of the story, it's better to watch the film. When this film came out it was pretty scary which was 27 years ago. By today's standards it's a fairly tame film. It's kinda like Psycho when it came out in the 60's. It was shocking back then, but now it's kidna the norm to have stuff like that in a film, so it's not shocking.The script could be better along with the acting. Overall it's not a bad film and if you haven't seen it, then I would suggest that you either buy or rent it.

Friday the 13th is a classic, no doubt about it. The story is simple and well meaning and it provides little disapointment. If you like Horror movies then you'll love Friday the 13th. The deaths maybe a little on the gory side and it may not be as scary as it was 20 years ago but it is still really entertaining stuff. 9/10If you like this try: PsychoHalloweenScreamFriday the 13th Part 2

Review title: The Original Slasher flick (it's just fun).
Review_body: Friday the 13th (1980) is a fun movie. The setting is perfect, the killer is actually kinda of an interesting character, and the movie is iconic in-general. Gore is fun, the characters are fun, I personally love the opening scene. This movie is just a fun slasher film with maybe one or two heartfelt moments with those hints of sex, and of course some iconic moments like the jason reveal scene or simply the title card. This movie is just fun, there's not a lot to it. 8/10.

The first of the classic Friday The 13th series. This movie has very chilling moments, for those whom are sensitive to horror movies. This movie also presents memorable scenes for the horror movie world. Harry Manfredini produced an excellent score. The feel of this horror classic, is a feel of excitement, especially when the eight sequels come to mind.As well as the upcoming Jason X and Freddy Vs. Jason

Review title: This is one of my favorites of all time.
Review_body: In my opinion, only sequels should be judged against the films that came before it.  This film should be judged as if none of the other F the 13th films have occurred yet.  The make-up is awesome in this film, no CGI to help make it look real.  The scariest part in the film to me is when the axe raises up behind Annie in the bathroom.  You know what is coming, but you can't even breathe.  I give this movie a 6/10 based upon the realness of the setting.  Summer camps back in 1979 were supposed to be dirty, with no TV, and you would have to walk to the bathroom with your flashlight.  The acting is sub-par for the most part.  Mrs. Voorhies and Alice give good performances which make up for a frantic and scary 15 minutes.

Review title: Ch, ch, ch. Ah, ah, ah. "Friday the 13th" is classic slasher fare!
Review_body: After "Psycho" in 1960, 1978's "Halloween" was a major hit due to its truly frightening premise and terrifying villain. So, other directors wanted to try and make their own "Halloween"-style film. The first to come out was Sean Cunningham's 1980 horror hit "Friday the 13th." The plot: Ever since the terrible coincidences in 1958, Camp Crystal Lake has been shut down and hidden for years. Now, it is finally being reopened, and for Alice, Bill, Jack, Marcie, Brenda, Ned and Annie, it's going to be a dream come true being the counselors at the camp. But they didn't listen to the locals when they warned them that they were all doomed if they didn't get out. And today is Friday the 13th. And an unknown assailant is stalking the campsite, killing the counselors one by one. Who could it be? What do they want? And can Alice stop them? "Friday the 13th" has everything you want in a slasher movie: Tons of gore, a few scares, likable teens, including a good heroine, and a little bit of nudity, if you like that sort of thing.Featuring Tom Savini's classic gore effects, great music, and a gigantic cult following, "Friday the 13th" gave birth to over 11 sequels and a re-imagining of the film. It is most famous not just for its wonderful "BOO!" ending, but also for creating a horror icon...Jason Voorhees.**** Rated R for strong horror violence/gore, some language, drug references and a scene of sexuality.

Review title: Capitalizing on the success of "Halloween," "Friday the 13th" manages to stand out with its own merits
Review_body: Clearly, the team behind "Friday the 13th" expected at least to make a reasonable profit out of it, but I seriously doubt that anyone involved in the making of this film even considered the possibility of it becoming the cult classic that it is today. Victor Miller, who wrote the story, openly admitted that he was riding off the success of Halloween (1978). The late actress Betsy Palmer even claimed that, after reading the script, she thought the story was trash (well... she actually used another word), but she took the job because she needed a new car. Little did she know when she took the role that her character would immortalize her as one of the biggest horror icons of all times.Yes, it is evident that Victor Miller and Don Mancini capitalized on the success of Halloween (1978), but the truth is that "Friday the 13th" manages to stand out on its own, and in the end, other than being two slasher films about a killer who prowls around murdering teenagers; these two films don't really have that much in common. To this day, John Carpenter's "Halloween" is considered a more "serious" horror film (for the lack of a better word), while "Friday the 13th" remains a classic, but is still seen as a less underappreciated respectable flick. Why? Probably because, even though I absolutely love it, I will admit that "Friday the 13th" certainly has a campy nature (no pun intended). In my case, I don't mind the campiness, I actually enjoy it.In "Friday the 13th", the story begins in 1958, in a summer camp named Camp Crystal Lake. We see two young camp counselors who are about to have sex, when someone appears out of nowhere and murders them both. We don't get to see who the killer is, since the murders are shown in a point-of-view shot, and the reason behind the murders is not yet explained either. The story then jumps to 1980 and it focuses on Alice, a young and sensible girl who, along with other kids of her age, is hired as a counselor by a man who attempts to reopen Camp Crystal Lake. Unfortunately, someone doesn't seem too thrilled about the reopening of the place, which will lead to a series of gruesome murders. Could it be the same person who killed those two counselors back in 1958? In the end, it is Alice who will have to come face to face with the killer and fight for her own life.Spoilers aheadPlot-wise, "Friday the 13th" may not be too remarkable, but it doesn't really need to be either. I could be wrong, but I believe this film first introduced the formula that consists on: a summer camp as a scenario, a pinch of mystery, plentiful gore, creative deaths and a gratifying reveal towards the last minutes. Just like this film attempted to ride off the success of a previous slasher, ironically, "Friday the 13th" itself ended up generating a bunch of (arguably) inferior clones as well. Of course, commercial success doesn't necessarily imply quality, but I do think "Friday the 13th" has a certain something that makes it appealing to a lot of people.For the most part, the characters in this film seem somewhat generic and one dimensional, which is a common attribute in slasher films. There really isn't much of a character development, and we don't get to know them very well. Most of the victims are young boys and girls who seem to be in the camp to have a good time themselves, rather than working hard to make the children happy. Surely, these characters don't really deserve to die for being immature and silly, but at the same time, it is hard to feel too bad for them either. However, the first character that gets killed after the time-jump seems genuinely sweet and caring, so one obviously feels bad for her when she is brutally murdered, just for being naïve enough to trust a stranger. I think this death after the time-jump was a perfect move, because it sets the tone perfectly for what is going to happen later: a bunch of innocent young people will be brutally murdered without having done anything to deserve it.The acting in "Friday the 13th" is mostly plain or, in some cases, over the top, which, along with the silly dialogs and lines, provides the film with an enjoyable campy nature. The late Betsy Palmer, who played the role of Mrs. Pamela Voorhees, was nominated for a Razzie Award, and while I love the character of Mrs. Voorhees and I felt bad to hear about Palmer's passing, I can understand why she was nominated. It's true, Betsy's portrayal of Jason's mother is over the top and it can appear as unintentionally funny during her delivery of some of her lines, but at the same time, I'm not sure if I can imagine the character being played differently at this point. Then we have Crazy Ralph, literally jumping out of a closet, telling the kids to leave, because they're doomed and that Camp Crystal Lake has a death curse. This character, aside from being called "Crazy" Ralph, (in case anyone didn't notice that he was crazy in the first place), is perhaps one of the campiest characters in the slasher subgenre, which earned him an iconic place in the franchise and even a small part in the first sequel."Friday the 13th" offers a nice variety of gory murders, with Tom Savini in charge of the makeup effects, which is an undeniable seal of quality. The legendary "axe in the face" death scene is perhaps one of the most memorable parts of the film for many fans. In this scene, Sean Cunningham and Tom Savini not only offer a morbidly satisfying and shocking on-screen death, we also get a lot of tension and suspense preceding the murder, which creates a feeling of panic and desperation.The final confrontation between Alice, our final girl, and Mrs. Voorhees, Jason's vengeful mother is really extensive for a good cause, as it helps to build a lot of tension that culminates with a gruesome murder. To some extent, when Mrs. Voorhees suddenly appears out of nowhere and begins to tell the story of what happened to that "poor boy", it is easy to assume that she is responsible for the carnage, or at least, that she is involved to a certain degree. Up until this point, we had never seen her before throughout the entire film, so why is she popping out now? There are no other supporting characters left to blame for the murders and Mrs. Voorhees shows up the exact moment when things got really ugly? What could she be doing at Camp Crystal Lake in the middle of the night, other than murdering boys and girls? Of course, our final girl, even though she is not unintelligent, seems to be somewhat oblivious of what is really happening and this is what makes up want to scream "Get out of there!". Mrs. Voorhees is basically explaining the whole story to the audience, but at the same time, she is subtly revealing herself as the killer, before going into a weird trance, in which she starts talking as if she is possessed by Jason, her own son, who drowned at the lake (I always considered this like a switched version of Norman Bates and his mother).As mentioned before, the acting in this final confrontation is not exactly brilliant and the audience ends up getting more than they probably needed to understand the story, since Mrs. Voorhees' monologue basically goes into detail of what happened, just to make sure we get it right (just like when they make sure that we understand that Ralph is a crazy old man, by calling him "Crazy Ralph"). Regardless of the over the top acting and the spoon-feeding to the audience, the confrontation is full of tension, and it is still considered one of the most memorable "killer reveal" moments in the history of horror for a good reason.

It's not a good start for great movies coming up. It is kind of boring and there is not really any action tell the end and you can't see most of the stuff this is one you try to forget but you can't cause it's not first one

If I had to chose one movie to be my most disliked movie, this would win the award. Talk about the biggest Halloween rip-off. It was made shortly after Halloween was released. I just don't know why this was made. The plot has a bunch of dumb counselers getting killed in this camp. It doesn't have acting. I don't think they even had a script. You can't drown and come back to life. Maybe they should have just made this into a sci-fi or something. Friday the 13th: D-

Review title: Camp can't be that bad can it?
Review_body: Friday the 13th is an American slasher movie with many sequels and is about serial killer Jason from whom their is no escape. When Jason is drowned at Camp Crystal Lake, he comes back from the dead as a grown man wearing a mask who hunts down unsuspecting camp counsellors in revenge for what happened to him.Each person is picked off one by one by Jason in horrendous ways and in the end you should not expect things to turn out happy.Friday the 13th was written by Victor Miller and was initiated from the movie Halloween's previous success. The movie was released by Warner Bros and Paramount Pictures. The movie was made on a budget of $550,000 and made over $39.7 million at the U.S box office which is every movie makers dream come true. Friday the 13th will get your scare nerves going, even though currently the world has become desensitized to more original horror movies, Friday the 13th Part One is still a good horror classic. - Asif Zamir

Review title: Most folks forget how it all began...
Review_body: The original Friday the 13th is almost quant now. You can tell it was made on a small budget, and as a result, several of the scenes are very dark and grainy.However, the story is classic. Someone is slaughtering camp counselors at Camp Crystal Lake one by one, in graphic fashion. The killer's identity isn't revealed (or telegraphed, despite what some naysayers think...) until the final act, when the killer is pitted against the final counselor. The finale is very tense and well filmed, especially those last few seconds of slow motion.The FX by Tom Savini are first rate, and the atmosphere of the film is excellent.If you forgot how it all began, sit down and prepare to be shocked!

Review title: Barebones slasher copied hundreds of times
Review_body: Friday The 13th is the film that you have seen hundreds of times. If Halloween created the modern slasher film, then Friday The 13th stripped it down and perfected a formula that all future installments and many imitators would follow, even to this day. Now I enjoy this film, I give this a high rating but do admit that the film, if viewed without the knowledge that it was really the first of its kind, will seem boring and stale. However I think this film does offer a different experience to the other classics of horror like Elm Street,Texas Chainsaw and its closest counterpart Halloween.Unlike Halloween, Friday doesn't give you any reason whatsoever to care for these character. They never offer any exposition of themselves or each other, all we are given is the first impressions of them. People like to make the joke today of describing every character with a quirk, or their type. The virgin, the jerk, the nerd, the hot girl. All of them are defined by this statement and nothing else which, if you want, can mean you can identify with the quirk and project yourself on to that character, or like me you can choose to use these quirks as ways to know which character just died a brutal, gory death. The music cues, the POV deaths etc, it all gives the film a strange feeling of you yourself being the killer. Nobody really realised that but this is one of the only classic horror films that truly makes you feel like the killer. You spend most of your time with the teenagers, but you never learn anything about them and you actually come to hate most of them because of their utter stupidity and general likability. This all combines us so by the end, that last girl, the virgin, is on your death list, you want her dead and you don't no why. Strange isn't itOverall, Halloween, Texas Chainsaw Massacre, A Nightmare On Elm Street and Friday The 13th, this film truly deserves to be part of the big 4 of modern Horror, its simple yet effective and it will continue to be the source of inspiration for many budding filmmakers for years to come.

Review title: The start of a craze that knows no end
Review_body: How can this be??? I was born in 1973, and now it is 2014 and I have ONLY JUST WATCHED ALL THE Friday THE 13TH FILMS??? SAD OR WHAT?So, lets begin at the beginning... There is no doubt that the Slasher Genre was born with Hitchcock's PSYCHO - But the Teen Slasher movie owes its birth to This one.The story follows a simple pattern... A Summer Camp is reopened years after some grisly murders took place, with a legend of a child who drowned having come back from the grave to take revenge on those he held responsible for his death...Cue lots of suspense and many deaths...It is now a very dated movie, but I have to say that if Hollywood wants to keep producing horror movies, then it needs to start paying attention to what makes this film work even now.As with Ridley Scotts ALIEN, Much of the film is about Suspense - There are long periods where frankly not much is happening, but there is enough done to make the mind think "OOoooo... We are about to see a killing" when its nothing more than a ploy... And its these ploys, and the camera work that allows you to see vast areas that make it such a draw.There is an understanding of the human Psyche and how we view the world... The old idea of when you sit at home and swear by all the souls you just seen something out of the corner of your eye when nothing is there...The film has these moments in abundance - And it works, It adds to the tension as you wait for the Killer to strike.Another good touch is that the deaths are not overboard... Creative yes, but not blood and guts for the sheer hell of it. Its time Hollywood learnt and viewers began to accept that Lots of Blood does not equal SCARY. In fact it ruins the illusion!So, a nice story build up... Deaths a plenty and a Legendary Character that people have been talking about for years since its release, EXCEPT......And yes, I was actually shocked as EVERYONE talked about Jason Voorhee's when I was young - But he is NOT THE KILLER!!! Its his MOTHER!!!I still cannot decide if this was a let down or a nice twist... As usual, A lone survivor and frankly on of the BEST JUMP SCARES EVER!!! Again, a lesson for Hollywood - Jump Scare are good but only if you PLAY with expectation - Which this film did! You know its coming... It is so obvious... BUT its so drawn out and slow in coming that I can honestly say that I almost dropped my Laptop!!! (Other than my sister, My family are wimps and hate Horror movies...)While effects wise it has not stood the test of time, this film still has the power to deliver some very real scares. A lesson in how to make a PROPER horror movie.If Hollywood is going to start scaring us again - Its time it learnt to go back to basics and get rid o the blood and guts Torture porn!

Review title: The first and best of the series
Review_body: This wasn't really a re-imagining of the horror genre, nor the start of the slasher craze, but this film, along with Halloween certainly made the slasher genre mainstream, successful, and truly marketable to a large segment of the population. Most especially to what would become the most desirable demographic, the 18-24 years old. A gore fest, with some truly inventive kills, which separated this film from many of its predecessors, in that it actually invented new and unexpected ways to die. The series would later go on to dream up more diabolical, and in most cases, silly; ways to meet one's maker, but this film plays it pretty straight. A true shocker, one that has become quite cliché now, some 28 years later, but keep in mind this film was at the forefront of the movement. Pay this film homage, by appreciating the inventiveness, and artistry of the execution (no pun intended) of the film. Some nifty kills, and taught sequences, filled with tension and terror. What horror films of today should be, not carbon copies of this film and the more generalized conventions of the slasher genre, but rather inventive, new, and willing to try new things and delve into new areas and dramatizations.

OK, I am a bit shocked over the negative reviews on this here! C'mon, this is the film that, along with "Halloween," started the big horror craze back in the day! Granted, "Halloween" is much superior, but this little low budget film also made major waves when it was released in 1980. Costing just $750,000 and grossing over $40 million, this film had one huge thing going for it: Betsy Palmer! A former 50's glamour girl, who starred on Broadway, films and TV, Betsy stripped down the glamour and made a fantastic psycho in this film. SPOILERS:(But hasn't everyone seen this?) Speaking outloud to herself in a schizo baby voice and answering in her own gravely voice("Kill her mommy...I will Jason"), Ms. Palmer shocked audiences as Pamela Vorhees, Jason's mother. Though the film would spawn countless sequels featuring her psycho son, Jason, I always remember back how the franchise first started. Too bad Palmer's character was be-headed..She could have shown up at some point during the series, and sent some more shivers down people's spines! I, for one, was very disappointed a different actress played Pamela Vorhees in dream sequences, in last year's "Freddy Vs. Jason." Nobody can replace Betsy as Pamela! The film also features a young unknown, Kevin Bacon,and also featured creative shocking(for it's time) murder sequences. For many years, the original uncut version of this film has been released on DVD in every country except the United States by Warner Bros.(Paramount never foresaw this being such a huge film, and let Warner Brothers own the foreign rights to the original film, but not the sequels). Paramount STILL has never released the uncut version in the United States, sadly. Let's hope one day that will change.

A group of summer camp counselors are mysteriously murdered one-by-one. When the whole twisted story finally unfolds, all hell breaks loose. This is a good movie to watch alone during a rainy afternoon. Betsy Palmer gives a great, if not over-the-top performance. Kevin Bacon has an early role as one of the counselors. Low-budget horror at its finest.

This will always, ALWAYS be remembered, especially since there's about ten of these existent as of now, but the original, of course, will always be remembered.This movie is your basic slasher/stalker film, much like "Halloween", full of suspense, horror, and it's gore. (I like to consider it the beginning of horror/slasher of the 80's, though I'm sure it's really not.) It's based on a vengeful killing spree of a killer that has some connection to the area in which they stalk that involves a terrible accident years before. If you've never seen it, go get it. But at this point, those people are very small in numbers, I'm sure.After all, this series is now 27 years old from the get-go!

The movie that started it all. If all was "Jason Voorhees", that is. Described by the director Sean Cunningham as a cash in on the sudden popularity of John Carpenter's "Halloween" slasher, Friday the 13th lives on as a cult classic. With its "Goosebumps" level of horror, a little blood, and some shaky camera work, apparently the audiences of 1980 were a lot more easily invoked to dread and terror- as the early 80s were a huge renaissance for the horror genre with films like The Shining, The Thing, Poltergeist, and Nightmare On Elm Street coming out all within three short years. However, what those movies did with acting, direction, and effects, Friday the 13th is low budget schlock by comparison.Perhaps Friday the 13th codified the horror genre's stupid, sex crazed, teen protagonists-who-for-no-good-reason-find-reasons-to-go-off-by-themselves, but a welcome introduction to filmmaking, it is not. Convenience is excusable in some cases, but when literally every character does the complete opposite of what makes sense and ventures off on their own into the dark, I found myself watching with dark, if a bit disinterested enthusiasm, that they had what was coming to them for being so idiotic. The movie is entirely overreliant on shock value and jump scares to the point when each character manufactures a reason to walk out, their demise is following as close behind as their shadow.It's a simple movie, and I suppose its place in history makes it worth watching once, but it's absolutely not anything I would want to revisit on a yearly basis.

Review title: Good, not great. Creepy, but not scary
Review_body:
Given it might have been scarier back then than it is now (like most old horror films) but the differences between this and other slashers like halloween, black christmas and a nightmare on elm street are obvious. Not showing the killer until the end is the directors way of taking from black Christmas the difference is Black Christmas had a build of suspense before each kill and each kill was scary. By the time they showed the killer you were on the edge of your seat. And the imagery of the movies Above are more frightening, more memorable and better executed. A long with that the performances of this film are less convincing and muddy. Very little development of the plot let alone the characters. Part of the horror of those foremention slashers, was they built more of a connection to each of the people murdered.
Friday the 13th is good. It has a lot of flaws that people like to overlook but is still a solid movie a good to own if you are a horror fan. But there's not much original here and it's simply not as frightening as the other films coming out at that time.

I think it's safe to say that the Friday the 13th series is a very, very terrible franchise. Jason is a cool killer, but there are just WAY too many movies that are exactly the same. Although every single Friday the 13th sequel is horrible (except for maybe the second one), the original movie is amazing. It has the best death scenes of any slasher movie. That spear through the bed was a masterpiece in slasher art. Mrs. Voorhees was so much better than Jason himself. Her motive was classic. And it's so cool how (if you have never heard anything about the movie at all) you don't know that it's her. Jason could never beat those marvelous killings by his lunatic mother. And the killings have GREAT special effects. Every Friday sequel combined couldn't compare to how real the killings were. Another great thing about this movie is that the story is pretty decent. It doesn't have a lot of scenes where you know what was going to happen. And the acting was much better than the Jennifer Love Hewitt/Neve Campbell movies nowadays. The only things that I don't like about the movie are the fact that it's a total rip off of Halloween and how Mrs. Voorhees dies. But if you forget about those two things, the movie is a very impressive movie for one that has almost TEN sequels that suck. The way I would've done the series is like this: The first one exactly how it was, only not having it the way Jason's mom die the way she did, but a more believable death which would be realistic for her to still live. The second one would be pretty much the way it was, except having Jason find the mask in that movie, not the next, and not having the scene where the girl dresses up as Mrs. Voorhees and tricking Jason. And the third and final one would have Jason's mom come back so both her AND Jason do a killing spree together which would have Jason decapitated and his mom burned to ashes.

Review title: Box office smash - What's all the fuss?
Review_body: When "Friday the 13th" was released in the early summer of 1980 it was a box office smash! Now, almost 19 years later, one must ask what all the fuss was about?A horror film can be stylishly made with plenty of scares thrown in with some gruesomeness (take "Halloween" which has no real on screen violence after the first scene.) FT13th goes for the sickening gore from scene one which kills any suspense the film might have. We know these kids are going to be hunted down and we know they're going to die in some brutal fashion.Perhaps if the film had contained a few more scares we could have forgiven the violence. But the only real scare is the infamous canoe shot at the end and even that ripped off "Carrie."As far as the acting goes - forget it! This is some of the worst actors in the world. (Yes, I know Kevin Bacon is in it. Judging from this film you'd have to bet you couldn't predict the stardom he has achieved). Look at the last scene Adrienne King has in the hospital telling the police about the boy. The only thing I felt was the urge to laugh at how wooden she was.Still, this is probably the best in the series, though I did like the 3-D effects in the third film. But if you're a horror lover and want good (not cheap) scares, "Friday the 13th" is one to steer clear from.

Review title: From the eyes of a camper:
Review_body: Man, to this day this movie still freaks me out. As a young girl I fondly remember watching this movie every summer before heading off to Summer camp and being terrified to leave (or even lie in) my tent at night. And even last summer, watching this movie before heading off to get that same camp ready for my time as a camp counsellor. Watching this movie for the millionth time I realize as scary as it is, why was it so looked down upon? And, Why was it nominated for Worst Picture? It is a classic slasher film and opened the doors for a lot of scary movies.This can actually be quite terrifying to watch. Thinking "could that be me?" "Does things like this actually happen?" etc. Give it go, What have you got to lose other than your sleep?

One of the best horror movies ever made. Friday The 13th was put down for unknown reasons. The movie is just as good as it gets. Scary and Original (in it's day) still holds its own.Think of how it would be if this movie never exsisted.... it would be a down right horrible thing, because this is the movie that started it all (not 'Halloween'). The whole series is fun to watch but none even come close to reaching the first one. The entire concept, lite imagery, shocks, acting, and make-up are way up to par. ...and yes, do make more of this series, it is not one to stop anytime soon, because I know you can do better than its followers, go back to the creepy woodsy camp, drop the teenage sex, grab a point or 2 and you have it! Simple as that, with the set up that is just waiting for more, you have it made. AND the audiance will flock to it. However do not copy the original first one. It is a horror classic that will never die. Friday the 13th is what good horror movies are made from... they always will be. It is the leader, and it still remains as strong as it ever did... and it must be respected. Let's face it... its hard to find an ending that good even these days... now thats a fact!

Review title: The godmother of all the 80s slashers (Halloween is the mother).
Review_body: If someone wants to watch a slasher film, I think that this one should be the one of the first choices, since it became influence to the later ones of the same genre.I think that it's the best way, because if you start to watch the newest ones, or even the remakes, then you will find this one very cliché and predictable, while the exact opposite happens.First of all, it's not cliché. Actually, for this period standards it's very innovative. It came out in 1980. That's about 39 years ago. I know that the presentation of 1980s horror with the 2000s-present differs a lot.I liked its authentic plot. The horror aura that oozes is really special. Different than the todays one, that they just want to scary you with one-after-another jumpscares. It really builds tension.The gore I think is mediocre. For the then standards maybe was very gory, but for the todays one it's very minimal. Tom Savini did a great job.I'm going to be realistic. I've watched many similar themed films before watching this one and that's why I found this one such a cliché, but as I've told above it is not. I kinda knew what was going to happen and how the final girl would find the bodies etc.Another thing I want to mention is that i didnt liked the protagonist (a.k.a. final girl). I didn't liked the acting skills of the actress. She was really really annoying.By the way her screams were obviously so fake. Nothing realistic.It's a classic and very popular film. Many people know the story and the ending without even been watched the film. I was one of them. Of course I didn't knew details, but some general important parts.Generally, I enjoyed this film, and I recommend it, because I think that we sould watch the evolution of this subgenre (slasher). Especially a real horror fan. I can say for sure that the next three ones are way better than this one. They contain more action and we learn more things about the story, so in my opinion, you should continue watching this franchise.

While this is, of course, the original Friday the 13th film that started the whole franchise off, if I'm being completely honest, it's among my least favorites in the franchise. Let's be real, none of the FT13th films are anything amazing, but Jason was the main attraction for them and he's, as we all know, absent from this film, except for seeing kid Jason for that jumpscare at the end. While the Kevin Bacon kill was memorable, it's pretty much the only good kill in the movie that I can recall. All in all, it is a classic, but not even close to being in the top of my favorite in this franchise. 5/10

Review title: Counselors go down for the count!
Review_body: This is the ultimate classic.... and it's easy to tell why!  It's the best movie that even scares me now.  Also, it was Kevin Bacon's debut and now he's working with Neve Campbell and Denise Richards, it can't be all bad. The violence is toned down for the squeamish, though, which stops it short of a 10 rating.  This is a definite must see!

Friday the 13th had its share of scares and suspense but not many.The plot involves counsellors being murdered by an unknown killer.The teens are warned to stay away from the camp because of previous murders and mishappenings that happened at the camp but they do not listen. The overall quality of the film is weak and it relies on gore rather than suspense. Most of the movie takes place in the dark and it is difficult to make out what is happening sometimes. One final note the acting is very poor even for a slasher movie.
Must Watch For Anyone - Truly One of the BEST Horror Movies EVER. Surprisingly Good Story. Original Directing. Best Movie To Watch one A Friday Night.

Friday the 13th. The movie which turned around the horror genre and gave us one of the most unforgettable villains and endings, is, and always will be a horror classic. Friday the 13th doesn't set out to be glossy and glamorous. Friday the 13th sets out to do what it wants to do; and that is, make you sit on the edge of your seat, feel uncomfortable and unnerved, to make you frightened when you go to bed after watching it. Friday the 13th delivers all of the fantastic horror goods. The plot revolves around American teenagers, who are the new counsellors at the apparently jinxed Camp Crystal Lake. These naive, horny youngsters have a one-track mind and break all of the innocent borders which has more depth than you would think. Basically, the message is "Don't have pre-marital sex, or you'll die" just like many of Friday the 13th's predecessors and clones send out as well. Friday the 13th has a variety of characters, all who you could possibly relate to. These characters are then slowly followed and hacked off one by one, in dark, gory, claustrophobic manners, which may leave you frightened in the same way Psycho made showers scary. As the camp counsellors are knocked off one by one, the tension rises higher and higher. Along the journey of carnage, the hugely effective soundtrack really creeps under your skin, highlighting how jumpy and scary the events happening on screen really are. For example when a chase scene occurs, the music may speed up, the tempo rising and jittering, almost moving like the characters on screen are. The acting in Friday the 13th is not bad at all; some of the actors/actresses may be a little amateur, but there is nothing terrible in this picture. The settings are also very effective. The stalkings and slaying in broad daylight and open spaces are a twist in a new direction, showing that not everything has to happen in the dark, in a small isolated house on the top of a hill, so the variation of location makes forests, cabins and even lakes more unappealing to the viewers afterwards, and may leave them creeped out by the aforementioned places. The camera-work is also very effective. The way the camera 'stalks' the victim behind trees and bushes, and the way the camera chases after it's victims as the point of view of the villain is unique and exciting, and adds a more tense and faster chill to the movie. Friday the 13th may play as a clichéd slasher, a story of sex equalling carnage, but it plays so effectively well it is a too important horror movie to simply be dismissed. It collects everything appealing about the 80's horror genre and wraps it up neatly into this fantastic horror package. A classic in it's genre.

Review title: I saw this movie when I was 8 years old
Review_body: And it failed to scare me in the least. Even the most idiot horror movies (except maybe Jaws movies) scared me senseless, but his movie fails in that way.Interesting twist, yes! But other than that it misses the mark completely! And it's not even a very good twist, come to think of it.Anybody who likes this movie must consider giving up on movies altogether.

Friday the 13th is a idiotic movie.  It is boring.  A bunch of teenagers, of which whom there was no real character build up - or should there be because there is not much to build up on, drink beer, have lame sex, play strip monopoly (see idiotic bit), and get murdered.The only good thing about this movie is that it has Tom Savini as the SFX guy.  I appreciate Savini and his work (particularly in George A. Romeros' films)Also, Nightmare on Elm Street is so much better and creative than FT13.  I hope Freddy wins in Freddy vs. Jason.5/10.

Review title: The film that started it all
Review_body: This is the film that started the whole series. I will skip the synopsis since you've probably heard it all before or can read another review for a synopsis. My main focus is on what the film succeeds and fails in. The first film has a lot of pros my first point is the kills and special effects, as always Savini provides great effects and there are a few memorable deaths. The film also succeeds in atmosphere, right from the get go you get a great feel for the setting and suspense that builds as the story continues. There are also a few cons though. The acting for the most part is standard and sometimes lacking, mainly Pamela Voorhees is the real standout and gives it her all. The next thing is a lot of thd characters are undefined, not necessarily a bad thing it just felt really meh, in other films of this series characters are a lot more defined. Finally this film is about as standard as it gets. This movie brought the slasher genre into the public eye alongside Halloween, but in retrospect and after so many slashers and horror film releases from the 80s this one doesn't stand out as much and really only remains iconic for the series of films that followed it. I do enjoy this film its just not the first one I'd pick up to watch.

Review title: A Horror Classic (actually a Classic in general)
Review_body: The first Friday The 13th is great. The movie has been poorly critiqued, but not justly. It's one of the greatest films of all-time. It had a lot of great elements, including a great plot, a great story to go along with it, some great effects too. The story is so involved you really can connect to it and understand why it happens. The unseen killer is really what makes this film so thrilling, you never know what's going to happen. That's unfortunately what got lost in a lot of the future Friday the 13th films. Betsy Palmer is excellent as Mrs. Voorhees, they should have had her comeback in Freddy vs. Jason. Kevin Bacon does a pretty good job too for his debut. This is a masterpiece that needs to be reckoned with.

Ill admit i still dont like the series but as the years go by my thoughts on the first have softened. Its got a great performance from patsy and the effects from Tom Savini are fantastic. But other then that it is nothing more then a slasher film

This movie is a classic. Its a great movie. The score is iconic. It is very suspenseful and the make-up and effects hold up very well. Tom Savini is one of the greats. The movie is very simple yet effective. Yes it is similar to Halloween, but Betsy Palmer's character really elevates the movie. She is great in the movie. She adds depth to the character of Pamela Vorhees and she plays it straight which makes it very effective. She's a mother who is truly broken and angry about what happened to her kid. That final scare scared me to death the first time I saw the movie. Excellent film. Highly recommended. Essential for horror fans.

Review title: The beginning of a legendary slasher movie.
Review_body: One of the best horror films of all time with a amazing cast. Similar to the cast, nobody knew how much this movie would blow up into something epic. I mean Kevin Bacon. Even Bing Crosby's son.how could I forget Betsy Palmer little miss goodie two shoes. Anyway this is one of the best horror films I ever seen and it doesn't have to be Halloween for me to watch it. To me this is the best of the franchise and the ending is one of my all time favorite movie endings. I rate this 10/10 and I recommend this to anyone who wants to watch a real deal slasher flick.

Review title: Just skip to the second one
Review_body: Seriously just skip to the second one the full plot is recapped at the start

Friday the 13th May be considered boring to modern day standards, but there's a lot more to it than it seems. Yes, the acting isn't golden, but it's still humans conveying somewhat emotions. The gory kills and suspense POV shots are well directed and the practical effects covering the bodies of the teenagers are not fun to look at and are effective for their purpose. The movie as a whole may not stand the test of time, but it's the one that created the test of time itself.

Not a real spoiler, but in the early part of the film we see a snake get chopped in half - whilst i'll admit it was distressing to watch, I couldn't help but research if that murder was real... And it was! That left a bad taste in my mouth for the remainder of the movie but whilst finding it mediocre, the last scene was the most entertaining in my opinion. I love 80's slasher or serial killer movies... But yeah, not so much this one.

I saw the first Friday the 13th first before any of them and I have to say it's not a good horror movie, but a bad one. Sure it's not the worst I've ever seen because even the franchise has worse ones.You would think if a movie could get 12 or so sequels it would be good or sort of a classic but the movie truly should never get that status.It had bad fake looking effect, terrible acting, cheap scares that aren't scary and is simply a waste of anyone's time. What I will give this movie though is the fantastic twist at the end. We think it will end one way and the movie completely spun my beliefs. Don't watch it, watch some of the others in the series.

Who would have thought a movie about a bunch of kids going to a camp where two people died years later would be so full of sex and violence? The critic side of me absolutely abhors this movie but the part of me that loves slasher films adores this film. It's such easy fodder to tear into but it's also entertaining despite all the flaws. Bad acting? Check. Bad camera work? Check. Spending four fifths of the movie thinking the camera man is the killer? Check.It's got some decent gore here and there and, unlike Halloween (a movie both sides of me abhors) it actually gets to the killing and doesn't "build suspense" to get to a pointless ending. This movie moves along fast enough to keep you interested and, despite tons of filler, is so much fun to watch because it's so easy to sit with friends and riff it.Thus, it's a pretty great horror film and party movie in my opinion.

I think that today is the right day to make a comment on this movie.The first time ever I saw this film was on TV with my parents one Friday night some 15 years ago... and it really scared me, I mean I enjoyed it and my parents too, and that´s difficult for they don´t like horror movies very much.After that day, I´ve seen "Friday the 13th" several times... (I don´t know how many), and although I know what´s going to happen all the time I still enjoy it and it still scares me...The best of the film is its famous unexpected and scary final scene which I´m not allowed to reveal...If you haven´t seen it yet, just do it... but don´t watch it on your own... just in case.Jason might be lurking somewhere...(10 out of 10)

Review title: One Of The Best Slasher Movies Ever Made
Review_body: In my opinion, this is one of the best slasher movies ever made and it's a real shame and disappointment that they don't make movies like this one anymore.  To this day, I watch the whole friday the 13th series over and over again and will continue to do so because it's one of my favorite horror movies series.

Review title: an obsession of an infamous slasher series that almost didn't happen to me
Review_body: "Friday the 13th" is my favorite horror film, along with JAWS, and BLACK Christmas. now, its kind of weird that i'm a fan of a series that i didn't even know of until a few years ago. in 2003, rumors were going around about the movie FREDDY VS JASON. i was clueless about the movie, so i did a little research. i was familiar with the series from that point on, and when i first saw the first film, i enjoyed it a lot. i won the DVD, which has some minor cuts in the death sequences, such as Jack's (Kevin Bacon) death which was cut after we see the arrow go through him. "Friday the 13th" was just another slasher film at that time, but now, it's probably one of the most famous and notorious slasher films in the history of American Cinema. Thanks, Sean Cunningham! P.S. - Harry Manfredini's music really suits it too! nice n' ominous

Review title: classic slasher film that set the standard for the sub genre at the time
Review_body: Friday the 13th is a film of great notoriety. everybody and their entire bloodline have heard if not seen at least one movie under the Friday the 13th name. there is a reason for this too. the first film is a great movie. Directed by Sean S. Cunningham in the year 1980 this movie set the standard for the sub genre and also spawned 10 sequels. what's most impressive about this film is what was accomplished on such a minuscule budget. made for an estimated 550,00$ this film shows that even with a tiny budget you can still make a totally memorable piece of cinema. with a cast made up of nobodies and a thin plot this movie still stands the test of time as a classic.one of the most memorable things about Friday the 13th (1980) is it's score and atmospheric setting. the two of these things help create a very dark and mysterious tone that sticks with the viewer long after it's over. we also get some excellent gore effects for the its time that still hold up to this day. the final showdown between the lead and the killer also has some genuine suspense and urgency to it that results in a brutal finale that will always be remembered. the final moments before the credits role are also very scare inducing and catch you off guard while also setting up a sequel. for its time this movie was revolutionary in the sense that it set in stone the tropes that would work for countless sequels and imitations throughout the years and would assist the horror genre in staying afloat. for this Friday the 13th (1980) will always be considered a classic.the acting in the film is alright. I wouldn't go as far as to say it's god awful. but it is not good in any way. the actors here are of course playing one dimensional teenagers. you can't exactly expect grade A performances.to conclude the review ill say that while not a perfect film, Friday the 13th is a classic in every sense of the word. it has amazing atmosphere, a memorable score, great special effects, some suspense and tension as well as a few scares. it basically created the 80's slasher craze and maintained it for years.the verdict: 7/10

Review title: Terrible acting, weak plot...I loved it! (!SPOILERS!)
Review_body: If you want to see good acting, smart filmmaking and you're hoping for a story-driven movie, stay clear of this one!But if you're looking for a slasher movie, a classic in the horror genre, this is it! Horny teens getting cut to pieces, some of the finest death scenes ever and good suspense make this movie a must-see for any true horror fan (or anyone else interested in one or several of these points). The acting is pretty awful and the story has its holes (but hey, who cares?). The motive of Mrs. Voorhees is one of the best I have seen in horror films although Jason (coming up in Part 2) is more frightening as the killer. Camp Crystal Lake is a very eerie place and the atmosphere throughout the film is pretty scary too, thanks to the good directing of Sean Cunningham. The chase scene at the end of the film is a little ridiculous (Alice being attacked, knocking down Mrs. Voorhees, running away, being attacked again...) but Kevin Bacon being killed by an arrow through the neck and other great (and very gory!) scenes are worth a watch!The movie certainly is connected to "Halloween" (1978) but then again, the two movies have very little in common.My rating: 8/10 (Check out Part 2)

Pamela hears about this and picks up Annie but slices her throat. Pamela gets to the camp and kills Bill, Jack, Marcie, Brenda, Ned and Steve. Alice is now the only one left. Pamela shows up and tells her how Jason drowned and tries to kill her. Alice picks up Pamela's machete and decapitates her saving herself from a terrible death. Little does she know that Jason (Who did not drown) watched her kill his mother...

Review title: A deadly excursion to Camp Crystal Lake
Review_body: Friday the 13th was one of the first films to follow the formula laid out by Halloween (1978), and writer Victor Miller has admitted that he was 'inspired by' (read: piggybacking on the success of) the earlier picture. It's even got a title which bears little relevance to the plot beyond providing a suitably spooky date for events to take place. Surprisingly, this film would spawn the most sequels (eleven). It is the equal of Star Trek and second only to James Bond in the sheer number of cinematic releases for a single franchise.No prizes for guessing that a group of teenagers (including an early film appearance by Kevin Bacon) are stalked and picked off by an unseen adversary. Slightly unique is the setting: deep in the woods, ten miles from the nearest junction, let alone the nearest town, lies Camp Crystal Lake, site of a brutal double murder in the fifties. Some twenty years later, the curse rears its ugly head when a new generation of entrepreneurs decide to reopen the venue.Summer camp is a benchmark of American culture, bringing a level of isolation almost unfathomable for anyone who has spent their entire life less than six miles away from three major towns (that's me). It has long been the inspiration for ghost stories and campfire tales, but Friday the 13th helped cement the setting as a staple of backwoods horror.The otherwise forgettable Sean S. Cunningham directs, with little of John Carpenter's subtlety. Aside from involvement in later Friday the 13th films, Cunningham produced a number of other horror pictures, including the controversial Last House on the Left (1972) directed by Wes Craven (who would go on to make A Nightmare on Elm Street).Like Halloween, pacing is slow, highlighting the intensity of the murders by comparison, but Friday the 13th is slightly more boring than its predecessor. In other ways, Friday the 13th is more extreme – the body count is higher, and the deaths are more gruesome.Nobody dies off screen save the penultimate victim, and Kevin Bacon's demise stands out as particularly gory. Cunningham does make effective use of point of view throughout, forcing the audience to inhabit the voyeuristic killer, as they peer through leaves and branches.Also intriguing are times when victims greet the killer with recognition, letting their guard down before being murdered. A continuing exercise in misdirection, the choice is made to follow a decoy protagonist during the opening scenes. Her demise provides an effective shock, but also underlines how undeveloped the other characters are.An interpretation of these early slashers is that they are a criticism of hedonistic 70s and 80s youth, and their weakness for drink and drugs and particularly sex. Thus the various killers punish the teenagers, yet fail to defeat the more celibate final heroine.Psychologists have written more academic analyses of this than the overviews that I can offer, but in this vein, Friday the 13th is no different and the thematic ground trod in films like Halloween is more explicitly covered. The flashback murder is once again inspired by sex, and later murders are indeed post coital.Slasher film makers are rarely vocal about their true intentions in this regard, usually preferring to deny or remain ambiguous about their themes. But with franchises so long, and each film so subsidiary to its predecessors, it's easy to lose sight of what the original statements may have been.More practically, the less promiscuous could be argued to survive merely through virtue of not being distracted while a killer's on the rampage. At any rate, the juxtaposition of a sexual scene with a violent one provides effective mood whiplash, maintaining high emotion throughout the film.Apologies if I've already revealed that some characters die, but stop reading if you don't want the big twist spoilt. For while the enduring horror icon of the Friday the 13th franchise became the hockey masked machete wielding Jason, this first instalment features his mother, Mrs. Voorhees (Betsy Palmer) as the killer.Locked in a kind of reverse Psycho arrangement – although she was not responsible for Jason's death, she channels the spirit of her son through asides in his voice. It becomes clear what the chilling musical score was foreshadowing with its echoing vocal chorus: "ki-ki-ki-ma-ma- ma"This film is thus unique amongst the genre for featuring a female murderer, with a general vendetta against camp counsellors, specifically those who would dare to tread upon the hallowed ground where she lost her son all those years ago. She believes Jason drowned whilst his counsellors were distracted having sex, and thus punishes the frivolous shirking of responsibility.It's ridiculous and over the top, and while there are some genuine jumps and scares that make Friday the 13th an entertaining thrill ride, and enough unique material to prevent it from becoming a simple Halloween clone, it ultimately falls slightly flatter than its spiritual predecessor.
