Released in 1980, "Friday the 13th" was not only the heir apparent to the earlier and hyper-successful "Halloween," but would spawn the ubiquitous slasher sub-genre that dominated most of the Eighties.  Movies like "Prom Night," "Terror Train," and "My Bloody Valentine" would benefit from the box-office success of "Friday the 13th," which is to say nothing of the string of sequels it bore that turned a deranged killer into an iconic anti-hero for a disaffected generation.  A garishly graphic yet minimalist psycho-on-the-loose tale, this was an effective and engaging film, tightly directed and unapologetic in its lack of subtlety.  To this day, "Friday the 13th," with its carefully constructed sense of claustrophobic isolation, tension-building camera work, and believable performances, is still a highly entertaining and influential movie that does not pretend to be anything else but a high-adrenaline terror trip.  Betsy Palmer chews the scenery in a climactic showdown that has been often imitated but never duplicated, and it is notable that the villain's motivation is entirely believable ... a fact that, to me, enhances the film's overall appeal.  "Friday the 13th" has earned a well-deserved place in the Pantheon of pop culture and is, without a doubt, a classic of modern horror.

I think Friday the 13th is an iffy movie. It's got good stuff, like some of the acting, the amazing gore by Tom Savini (a great goremaster), and even some of the humor. But, there is a lot of flaws. For one, the snake scene. They used a real snake. It was also a pet snake of one of the crewmembers. He didn't know they would kill it. They didn't even need the scene in the movie, and it costed them an innocent snake. Second, the 3 minute scene of Alice making coffee. We didn't need it! If we removed that scene and the snake scene, which would be 6 minutes less, it would still reach the 80 minute mark! We didn't need these scenes. Third of all, and the most frustrating, ALICE IS STUPID! She had a chance to drive away with Ms. Voorhees' car, but one body made her run away! It's just a body! Drive away! She also has a fully loaded gun, but she doesn't shoot her! She had the chance to shoot her in the 15 seconds of Voorhees just standing there, and also had the chance when she knocked her down, BUT SHE DOESN'T SHOOT HER! She also uses a canoe to go onto the lake instead of driving away with Ms. Voorhees' car! SHE'S A DUMBASS! I would have enjoyed the movie if Brenda or Annie were the final girls!

I love old slasher movies. In fact, I would say that John Carpenter's Halloween and Tobe Hooper's Texas Chainsaw Massacre have become two of my favorite horror movies recently. But sadly, the original Friday the 13th is not one of those movies. Don't get me wrong, I do enjoy it, and I think it's iconic in its own right. Those who've not seen this movie before may be surprised to know that Jason isn't even this movie's present slasher, but rather his mother, which I was quite surprised to find out myself.Moreover to the movie itself, however, it is apparent just from the opening scene that they are trying to replicate the opening to John Carpenter's Halloween (i.e. The opening POV shot showing the events that would be the catalyst for what's to come). And it's also apparent from the first couple kills that this was a film on a rather small budget. Basically the plot centers around a group of teens trying to open up a summer camp that's been closed for a couple decades and they are being killed off one by one by an unknown assailant (Jason's mom, Pamela). Overall, they don't seem to have a bad premise. It's a concept that would spawn a whole slew of summer camp slashers (such as Sleepaway Camp), but overall, not a bad idea for a slasher film.As far as gore goes, it just makes it even more apparent they were on a small budget. The effects in this movie are, well, dated, and haven't aged well. I mean, they were decent enough for the time, but by today's standards, they are rather crude.My final point in this review is that there are scenes that feel dragged out and overly elongated. They pretty much dedicate and entire scene to the film's final girl making tea, I guess to give you a sense of normalcy before the climax, but it really doesn't work here. It feels kind of tacked on and boring.Overall, not a great film, but far from horrible.

Review title: A classic horror film that will be remembered forever
Review_body: Friday the 13th is one of the first original slasher movies, and one of my personal favorites to say the least. The film's near perfect music is just one of the many amazing features this film has to offer.Friday the 13th is a film that you can watch over and over again and never get tired of it. It's villain, and Total Films #100 most loved movie character of all time, Jason Vorheese, stars in the films as an insane phsycopath who kills for the sake of killing itself. What I personally love about the original film, is the directors ability to make so much happen on such a steep budget. Jason was just Jason in this first film, no mask no nothing. You barley even see him throughout the entire movie. All of the "true" Friday the 13th fans will know that Jason does not have the hockey mast until Friday the 13th Part III.The classic film is what many call one of the best horror films ever made, and I agree completely. Everything about it is perfect, and done just as it should.When we look at Friday the 13th we don't see meaningless killing and low budget gore. We see what the director truly wanted us to see, a masterpiece. a work of art that can never be topped. And a series that will live on forever.

Friday the 13th was the first horror movie I ever saw. I saw it on television I believe in 1982, and I was hooked. Once we purchased a VCR, I rented it probably 15 times until it was priced for sell-thru in 1987. To me this movie and the following sequels are part of the definition of 80's culture. Every 12-18 months, these movies would pop up to the excitement of fans. The original, to me, is a great example of how a simple idea can be turned into a successful movie going experience. Is it a masterpiece...well, no. It is a movie that provides the shocks necessary to elevate it to the classic status it now has. I would love to see Adrienne King and Betsy Palmer turn up in some form or fashion in the remake, if produced, even if it's only as a cameo!

Review title: Classic horror film no matter what critics say
Review_body: Friday the 13th is what it is.Within the Horror genre, you have really amazing filmmaking that delivers on all counts the way you expect that it will. Then, you have ones like Friday the 13th, Brahms the Boy Part II or Final Destination part 12. Hopefully the people who view these films have enough sense to know what they're getting into from the beginning. They're fishing bass out of Crystal Lake, not lobster.

I had mixed thoughts about the film. The characters in the movie are stupid (how shocking, that never happens in a slasher film). One lesson is never get into a strangers' car. One of the characters does exactly that and she is killed. Mrs. Voorhees lures the characters into traps. She clips the power line and she attracts the teenagers to the powerhouse, just like how a spider attracts a fly. And then she goes for the kill. The makeup and special effects for the film are well done. The film is a blood fest and it possibly the first bloody/ gory slasher film. But the plot is incoherent and it is too focused on the deaths and the body counts. The characters are not really given personalities, except for the fact that they are all addicted to sex. We don't have much background of them either. If you haven't seen this film yet, you probably think the killer is Jason Voorhees. You are wrong. It is Mrs. Voorhees. A senior citizen- aged woman with a fleece sweater was not quite my original vision of Mrs. Voorhees. What I want to know is how an old woman is able to find all of them out of all the possible places on the camp within hours. I also want to know why the teenagers didn't just walk out of the camp. The film has the elements of a typical horror movie. It has its moments and there are suspenseful parts. But they think they can amuse the audience by having sex and deaths while having poorly constructed characters but that doesn't work in reality.

Review title: Original Friday. Not so original plot
Review_body:
In Friday the 13th, a group of teenagers return to a shut down summer camp to set up and return to being open to the public. All is not as it seems, through the local nutcase warning them to stay away and one of the counselors being killed on the way to the camp site. As the film progresses, more counselors get killed until a final confrontation is presented with a counselor and the killer.Not to give the wrong idea about the title of my review, I love this film. As a massive slasher film fan, I love this film. It has great kills, it has an amazing twist and it starts one of the best franchises in the genre. It makes great steps in the teen stalker slasher film and the twist at the end is amazing. Still makes me a little uneasy, even though I have seen this film so many times.
It is true that the plot is tried and tested, and in some peoples eyes, tied but they do say plagiarism is the highest form of flattery.
I do recommend this film, not only as a bedrock of the slasher sub-genre but also as a film to go back to and enjoy.

Review title: One of the greatest horror movies of all time.
Review_body: If you have not seen this, or the entire Friday the 13th movies. Start watching, of you are a horror fan. Highly recommended.

I'm gonna come out here and say it: I think this is scarier than Halloween. Friday the 13th Part 1 is the best horror IMO. It took what Halloween had, and that's what made it so creepy ... the suspense ... Also, I love the location, the forest; Just thinking that the killer could be hiding behind any tree makes it so scary, also being the abandoned summer camp, and the rainstorm really give you the creeps. Next, it has much more creepy scenes than any horror I've seen (I've counted like 20+), especially the bathroom scenes and the scene with Brenda hearing the voice. But what really makes this movie scary, are the scenes where's there's no killing! Here's some the creepy scenes that actually creep me out: In the beginning where Ms. Voorhees walks into the cabin - The part where they're swimming and you see the hand of the killer touching the tree, then someone hears something and they go to a shot of the forest with nothing moving.... - The lights going out at camp - Steve getting killed - Jack getting killed - The bathroom scenes - the scene where Brenda's in the bathroom and she leaves, then it shows the light shaking... (Creepy) - And MUCH moreThe rest of the Fridays are just trash, especiallt part 4.10/10

Review title: Probably the defining horror movie of the 1980's.
Review_body:
Along with 1978's Halloween, Friday the 13th dragged the "slasher" genre into the mainstream.  It's basic plot - young people go away somewhere; bad things happen - is now a staple of the horror movie (and horror movie satires).  Although this plotline has been hashed to death over the years, I still enjoy this movie; and the musical score creeps me out every time! And I genuinely like the characters in the film.  This film also launched new stars; super gory special effects, and the people who create them.
Hey, I know it's no "Citizen Kane", but my vote of 10 is for what this movie did for the horror genre, for special effects, and, let's face it, for the HUGE scare I got when I saw it opening weekend all those years ago.P.S. - for a camping movie mindbend, rent the comedy "Meatballs" and "Friday the 13th".  After those two movies, you'll never look at summer camp in quite the same way.
It was fun, but not that scary. I know it doesn't have to be but without the scariness it was kinda boring. Probably the lease memorable from the whole series.

Review title: An Excellent Start For A Series of Never-Ending Films
Review_body: Where would I start to describe the sheer genius of the original 1980 "Friday the 13th?" The well-written script by the god Victor Miller (some lines were rewritten by future "Friday the 13th Part 2" writer Ron Kurz)? The thoughtful direction of one of the masters of horror Sean S. Cunningham? The wonderful and deadly character of Pamela Voorhees played by the great Betsy Palmer? OK basically to make this all sum up into one single line for easy reading is this: THIS IS ONE HELL OF A FILM! The cast is great. The special make-up effects by the legendary Tom Savini is great. The villain is great. Heck, the whole thing is great. Ignore all the bad critical reaction this film and all its sequels received, watch it anyway! It's a good 'guilty pleasure' to have and I certainly don't mind. Watch it, I know you will love just as much as me and every other "Friday the 13th" fan! I give "Friday the 13th" 5 decapitated evil mother's heads, out of 5.A true slasher film classic!

Of the three big slasher movies, this one, Halloween, and A Nightmare on Elm Street, this is by far the worst, and that's saying something, considering the other two ain't so great. This film is just plain awful. Painfully boring for the first part, it slips into unintentional comedy punctuated periodically by the least scary murder sequences you can imagine. How this became a supposed horror "classic" is way beyond me. I don't see how anyone could appreciate this film or even call it good cinema, which would imply this is art. The day this is considered art is the day the world ends. Worst of all, this film inspired a million other awful films. Thanks a lot you awful movie.

Review title: The start of a long,unforgettable series
Review_body: The movie that gave birth to one of the most famous killers of all time,Jason Vorhees.Although he became the killer in part 2 this was the movie gave us his name.This is by no means an original horror movie even when it was released in 1980,it borrowed heavily from classics such as Halloween,Psycho,Black Christmas E.T.C .The acting may be cheesy and maybe dull but this started the now extremely tired story of half naked teenagers having sex then being brutally murdered until the virgin girl is the last one left.This does have some scary moments and very creepy music.This is by far the best in the series with part 2,3 and 4 being worthy sequels but part 8,9,and 10 being dire and boring.Overall this is an underrated classic and though some of the sequels make the series look silly i would recommend you watch this one and see when the series was at its best and scariest.

Do not expect a Oscar performance by him but its interesting to see him so young. I now own all of these movies on DVD an enjoy most of them the last few were kind of dragging the name Jason a little out of proportion but what the hell make a little more money why not. This is a must see movie. I know many have already seen the higher numbered movies but one night sit an watch 1 though 4 (the best ones)an then one can appreciate the storyline.If you want to see a classic horror movie then this is a very good choice, just make sure you leave the lights on an the doors locked!!!

Then they start getting killed off one by one in very gruesome ways , but not after getting involved in sex, drink and drugs.This film has spawned hundreds of copies which most have not come close to this. The ending was a big surprise when you find out who the killer was and the finale if that does not make you jump you have no emotion.The cast is not great but does not need to be, but it is nice to see a young Kevin Bacon get wasted, i feel that most of the credit must go to Tom Savini and his special effects which are great. all in all this really is worthy horror treat and a great shocker for its time...

Along with Halloween, one of the most original and widely viewed horror movies over the last twenty five years.  Halloween brought back suspense, Friday showed us gore.  From the moment the audience sees a very young Kevin Bacon squered  through the throat with an arrow,  a new kind of horror film is on it's way to movie history; the teenage slasher film.  Done on a very low budget, with excellent special effects by Tom Savini, this movie set a precedent that was copied thousands of time; the more gore, the better.  The story was pioneering back in 1980, and unlike the horror films of today, original and suspenseful.  Although nine sequels were to follow (parts 2,4, and 7 are worth seeing), none captured the magic of the first one.  All real horror fans must see this film, and realize that 99% of all horror films since then are mere rip-offs.

Review title: The one that started it all
Review_body: Granted Halloween came out 2 years prior, but Friday is in no way a rip-off of Halloween. The plots don't even corrolate other than a 'crazy' person going around killing people, and if you want to get technical about it, then every 'slasher' horror flick is a ripoff of one another going all the back to the birth of horror in movies.You have a kid who killed his sister in Halloween to go on and age to adult hood and then try and seek out his other sister and kill her, all in one movie. Friday the 13th, Jason is only seen briefly at the end and revolves around his mother seeking revenge for allowing the camp counselors to let her son die while they were busy have sex!  Both, at first, are believable plots, a sibling (crazy) wanting to kill his sister, and a mother taking revenge because her son drowned. If we didnt know better, these may be headlines out of a local newspaper. But when it comes right down to it, how many horror films actually have believable plots anyway? And if i wanted something believable I'll go watch documentaries.It's hard to say how scary Friday was, it has been nearly 20 years! Yet it is synonomous with horror films. That alone should tell you something. Times have changed since 1980, more money is invested into the production of the movie, audience expects wild special effects, but in 1980 that wasnt the case. I wasnt fortunate to see the first friday in the theatres, but when I did see it for the first time, it was scary. Not to mention the fact I was going away to camp during the summers. The scene at the end of the movie forever burns a memory into your mind.The first one may not have been the scariest or the best, but it's the original, it spawned more direct sequels than any other horror film of its time. Want to see some great horror films, go rent Friday I, II, & III.

wow! Just wow! Talk about a movie that still hangs with the big boys of today. Though these movies take a huge beating for being cheesy and stereotypical, I beg to disagree. But as far as following a certain formula of characters getting whacked in the woods, it does do that but the characters aren't just blank canvases that die brutal deaths, they each had meaning and they all had there own personality traits, (which was something that was missing in later installments.) Review title: A Legend in its' Own Time: Friday the 13th Part I
Review_body: If you're a slave to story being the most important thing in a movie, and you're the type to go on and on about the scholar like ambitions in a filmmaker's writing of a graphic or exploitation horror film (and you know who you are- the type who might, for example, praise David Lynch or the weaker efforts of David Cronenberg), I pity you.This is not to say I think graphic films, exploitation, and horror films are best when they're dumb or don't try to be serious. Not at all. It's just that horror films have a formula. And no matter what you want to make your movie into, you always have to cheapen them just a bit to use violence for the sake of style or piling on dead bodies. A horror film is not a horror film without the classic Death Scene, or even several of them. Is this all a big lead-up to me praising Friday the 13th? No. It's just an excuse to say we can't be expected to take everything seriously.Films have always been a reflection of what happens in the world around us. Horror as a genre, however, is by definition: unrealistic. And absurd. And out of the ordinary. This is the perfect way to describe Friday the 13th. Which is a film (and later- a franchise) that has been bashed by serious folk for being too violent, gory, and in these excesses- depraved. Like it's really a professionally slick and oppressively dark film with a conservative agenda to punish young people either for indulging in "bad things" or for just being young. I don't think we need a movie to be depraved. What Friday the 13th really is is a simple frightfest scenario. Carefree, easy-going 19-20 year old's take their summer job at an abandoned camp which is getting ready to re-open. But there's a mysterious killer out there. You don't know who they are. Or where they are. Or when they're going to strike! And this is all a precursor to what Jason Voorhees became. Omnipresent, mysterious yet crude and somewhat hulking, and savage "revenge" slasher-killer.Friday the 13th is the definitive slasher film. Because it's not really about anything. But it sure became something, didn't it? The leader in entertaining "And Then There Were None"-styled massacres with cool, bloody death scenes by the dozen. Completely absurd in terms of story, never making sense for a single moment. And filled with shrill, cold, quiet yet loud atmosphere in terms of darkness and isolation. It's truly become a legend. These elements. The white steam rising off the frozen water, wafting into the black night forest with green trees jutting up into your path, blue rain smacking everything in sight, yellow lights in cabin windows, flashlight beams fading into the eternal darkness. And of course... that sound. The unsubtle "ch- ch- ch- ha- ha- ha" just over your head. And that Harry Manfredini string section slicing through the air, through the peace of the gentle woods.It's not story that propels these movies forward. But it is a lack of quality direction that holds them back. With a lax focus on story and strong characterization, and a rushed low-budget filming schedule, results vary and often include painfully bad acting. The original Friday the 13th suffers much from this. Though by the end, it's really not that much of an issue anymore.

Who hasn't heard of Friday the 13th? It's an iconic franchise launched in the 1980's during the height of the slasher genre, and helped write many of the rules that horror movies would follow after it. Sure, Halloween and even Black Christmas started the whole "unseen killer" era of horror movies, but Friday the 13th really kicked it up a few notches.The story here is easy to wrap your head around, which it needed to be to get to the blood and guts of the movie. The story centers around Alice, the new head counselor, and Steve, the new owner of Camp Crystal Lake. They bring out a number of other counselors to help rebuild the place and get it ready to open. Over the course of three days, one by one each teenager is killed before Steve gets it. Alice is eventually the last one left alive, and ends up meeting Mrs. Voorhees, who explains how her young son Jason drowned there twenty years ago while the teenage counselors "made love". This drove her insane, and she set about to kill any teenagers and anyone else that came out to Crystal Lake. The showdown between Alice and Mrs. Voorhees sets up the climax, where Mrs. Voorhees meets her demise via beheading.The look of the movie captures the feeling of being isolated out in the woods, adding to the scariness of the picture. The film moves along at a good pace giving watchers plenty of suspense. With kills every few minutes, you won't get bored watching this one.Who could forget the fantastic score? The creepy stalking music, the famous ki-ki-ki-ki that still sends a chill down my spine works so damn great here. The music is fantastic, and much like it did for Halloween, the music adds to the creepiness of the film.Tom Savini, the master of gore who worked on Dawn of the Dead among other films, really brought it here with the kills. For today's fans, they won't be impressed with the gore, for the time however it was pretty damn shocking. I still winch during the arrow scene, and the final kill of the film memorable.The one complaint I do have is the lack of character development, which won't always be a complaint from me (I swear) in future reviews. Here, however, we really only get to know Mrs. Voorhees and Alice, and we barely get to know them. The other characters are just glossed over here, and are mostly there for fodder. While this would be a normal occurrence for the franchise, there are characters that get plenty of back story and time to develop, just not in this one.This first movie is a toss up for fans thanks to Jason Voorhees, the killer for the majority of the franchise, not being the killer in this one. Spoiler alert for a thirty year old movie, the killer this time around is Jason's mother, Mrs. Voorhees (Jason does make an appearance at the end).Personally, I enjoy the movie even today. While it did bother me that Jason's mother was the killer when I first watched the movie as a kid, I attribute that to having seen the other movies first. I grew up watching the Friday the 13th movies, and this is one of the best in the series.

I didn't know that some 1980 extravaganza like this could blow my socks off, but, boy it sure did. But, it lacks plot holes and has noticeable mistakes. BIG MISTAKE: Alice puts the bucket down twice. (When Steve, Marcie, Ned and Jack are shaking hands.) But like all people, before I saw this movie 2 years ago, I though the 80's icon 'jason' was the killer. Wrong! Mrs. Voorhees... This is easily the best slasher movie hands down.  It was this movie that got me hooked on the horror genre so deeply that I will be hooked the rest of my life.  I was 8 or 9 (can't remember which) when my mother let me rent this movie.  At the time I was just going on what I had heard a friend at school say about the movie but once I saw it I was just left in awe! If you watch this movie and try to judge it against movies with Tom Hanks and a $7million dollar budget, it will probably "suck" in your opinion.  You have got to watch these types of movies with an open mind and just have fun. That is the best way to view movies as it will make you have a helluva lot more fun.  This is the type of movie that will suprisingly entertain you and send chills up and down your spines.  I feel sorry for the so-called "horror fans" that watch only the 90's horrror such as Scream and I Know What You Did Last Summer. They don't really understand what it is like to enjoy such a great film. Don't get me wrong, I enjoy the Screamified movies, but I LOVE the older horror.The actors in this movie (Kevin Bacon being the most memorable) give fun performances and they don't have massive egos (which makes them even better.) Tom Savini's make-up effects are absolutely brilliant. The gore keeps on coming.  Sean S. Cunningham made this one stand out against the rest (all of which were not awful, but could have been better) and the classic sound "ch ch ch ch ha ha ha ha" will give you goosebumps.If you absolutely love this movie, I recommend the sequels as well as other slasher movies such as Halloween and Nigthmare on Elm Street.All in all...an excellent horror flick. I give it a STRONG 10!Josh McBride

Review title: An excellent early slasher that still stands the test of time.
Review_body: Friday the 13th. Sean Cunningham may have directed this film mainly to make some profit returns after a disappointing small run of "family" orientated movies but I still think he was oblivious to what an effective little sleeper he was creating, easily his most significant work since "Last House" with Wes Craven.It was further helped because of when it appeared, with audiences trained and tuned for on screen gore after "Dawn of the Dead" and other films like "Zombie Flesh Eaters". And of course Tom Savini was on board to create the amazingly effective on screen murders.Although the movie can seem like just a routine slasher in terms of plot and murder set pieces today, people sometimes forget it was the film that spawned a million clones. It wasn't unoriginal at the time(although that is open to debate of course with both "Bay of Blood" and "Halloween" both sited as influence on the film and its sequels) and in fact created traits that have been copied countless times by other movies of its type. It has an undeniable atmosphere and a fantastic effective score.Add Savini's masterful effects,the pouring rain, POV shots and a heroine you care about and you have a classic horror film that will never be forgotten.

Let's face it: it's not high art, but this is one entertaining movie.The story (if you can call it that) revolves around a group of young adults who are systemically slaughtered by an unknown assailant while helping re-open a defunct summer camp. On Friday the 13th, of course.Is it well-written? Not exactly. But there are plenty of great set pieces galore. This was before the MTV brand of film-making where loud noises and things suddenly jumping out at you qualified as "scary." This film takes its time to build up the tension before unleashing the scare, which in this day and age is sorely missing from most horror films. And atmosphere...well, it's got plenty of that to boot. You'd be hard-pressed to find a better setting suited for a horror film than the woods. Many other slashers tried to replicate it afterwards, but none succeeded like this one does.Even 31 years later, the film still holds up and manages to entertain with hardly a dull spot in its entire 90-something minute runtime.If you're searching for something along the lines of "The Exorcist" in terms of quality, you might want to reconsider seeing this. It's not high-brow art--it is what it is: a very entertaining, fun slasher movie. Don't take it more seriously than it needs to be.

Review title: One Of The Top Four Best Of The Series
Review_body: In my opinion, the original Friday The 13th is easily one of the top ten best horror films of the 1980s. It had an awesome, often creepy atmosphere, some harsh, sometimes over-the-top kills, a few attractive characters, and some VERY suspenseful sequences. This was one of the most suspenseful of the series, right up there with Part II in that department.My fave scenes? The death of Jack, the scene leading to Marcie's demise, the final fight on the small beach, and Annie's chase. Some people see Alice as boring and typical, and far too innocent, but I think she was pretty developed (especially compared to many of the final girls of the LATE 1980s). Mrs. Voorhees was also fantastic and very intimidating.

Review title: Terrific horror movie; one of the best
Review_body: Friday the 13th is definitely one of the best horror movies ever. This is definitely a must-see for any horror movie fan.The movie begins at Camp Crystal Lake in 1958 with a spooky opening sequence in which two counslers are brutally murdered by an unseen killer. The camp then closes down. We then fast-forward about 20 or so years, and they are trying to open up Camp Crystal Lake to inner-city children. Seven counslers are to report and finish fixing up the camp to make it more suitable. However, someone isn't happy about them opening up. Someone begins stalking them, and then brutally murdering them, one-by-one. There are some throat cuttings, an axe in the face, a spear through the throat, a guy impaled on a door with arrows, a decapitation, and, of course, a few stabbings. Then, we get a twist as we head toward the climax as we find out the killer's identity and motive.This movie is one of the scariest movies i've ever watched. Like Halloween, the suspense slowly builds to an intense, very suspenseful climax. And, just when you think its all over, there is one last "jolt". I strongly recommend this movie. I also recommend Friday the 13th, Part 2 and Halloween.

Review title: The movie that introduced the horror clichés to a wide American audience.
Review_body: Although the conventions that this movie spawned had been done before in other forms, this is the classic camp slasher flick that created a stereotype which was imitated ad nauseum ever since. Halloween may have delivered a bit more suspense and contained better acting and more character development (while still being a bit cheesy in its own right), but this one was the gritty, shocking gore fest that made you scared to go to bed without looking underneath your bed first.The advantage this one has over all its sequels is that it contains mystery. You don't know who the killer is or what his/her motivation might be. You never see much of the killer until the end. As a result, all the deaths come out of nowhere. You never see the killer picking up a weapon or approaching a victim. You just see shadows, brief glimpses, or nothing but a hand yielding a weapon. In addition, the shots of the lake, the trees, and the approaching storm look as real as can be, allowing you to slip into the movie without feeling like it's telegraphed.One of the problems with this movie is that almost half the murders come off-screen. I have read that this a a result of shoddy looking special effects. This is a disappointment since the kills we do get to see are wince-inducing. Another problem is that in all the brief glimpse you get of the killer throughout the movie, it looks like a man. Remember the shot of his/her legs as he/she runs after Annie in the woods. Those were man legs, IMO. The killer, of course, turns out to be an older woman. Also, Mrs. Voorhees moves pretty fast to through Brenda's body through the window at Alice and run to get her jeep, which she drive up just about two minutes later.All in all, this movie is a classic. It is the blueprint for many to come. It offers gore effects which were shocking for their time. And the story line rings true and unsupernatural, unlike future Fridays.

Friday the 13th is good, old fashioned, slasher movie fun. It's not incredibly compelling and it's definitely not worthy of awards, but it's a fun one to watch and reminisce. If you've never seen it, give it a watch!

I love this series, the movies are not great but are cult classics, it's like going to a county fair, not great, but leaves a lasting impression. This film is great the graphics are amazing for 1980. Great twist having Pamela be the killer, too!

This movie scared me very much as a little girl. Jason scared me. But, I bought all the Friday dvd's and am not afraid anymore! I watch them and every once in awhile, a memory will come back to me in the young ages I've seen them!

Friday the 13th may seemed dated and cheesy to some, but the amazing practical effects, cinematography, mythos, musical score and Betsy Palmer's performance all make it great. The arrow through the neck is one of the most clever and inspiring combination of buildup and effects in a horror film.

Years after a young boy drowned and two workers were brutally murdered, camp Crystal Lake is reopening it's doors to offer a wonderful vacation place. However, as soon as the new workers begin to arrive, the murders start again and in a very brutal way. As the bodies begin to appear, Alice (Adrienne king) meets Mrs Voorhees(Betsy Palmer). But this lady isn't what she seems to be, and Alice must battle her for good. Who will survive this Friday night? This is the first and by far the best of all Friday films. The acting is amazing and the special effects are very well-done. The deaths are very well executed and you will never expect the final scene. I give it a 10 out of 10.

Review title: The worst movie I've ever seen.
Review_body: An inane slasher flick that's poorly done in every thinkable way. The acting is horrible, the writing is horrible, and the cinematography is pathetic. The film is too obviously low budget, but not even more money could salvage this turkey of a movie. The film has no thrills, in fact it's PAINFULLY boring. Anyone with half a brain could've written a screenplay better than this. Although the idea of a bunch of teens getting slaughtered at a dark camp by a lake is a rather good premise for a horror movie, it isn't used well here. There's nothing enjoyable about this movie. It's most definately the worst movie I've ever seen. I thought "Halloween" was bad, but "Friday the 13th" makes "Halloween" look like something just short of Shakespeare. Don't think I'm some old person who hates all horror movies. I'm a teenager who loved "Scream" and also liked "I Know What You Did Last Summer".

Does anyone know if there's a box set available? If so, that would make a great X-mas gift for myself, maybe I can convinced my wife to pick me up a copy. She can't stand them and says that they are are stupid. I can still remember when I saw the 1st one. My sister and I sneaked in the theater when I was only 11. I'm still haunted from seeing it that for I will never swim in a lake ever again.

Review title: What Was Scary Then, Is Boring Now.
Review_body: Though Friday the 13th defined the horror genre for decades to come, the first installment of the series hasn't aged too well. Sure the kills are awesome, Betsy Palmer's spine chilling performance as Mrs. Voorhees is great, and the music could make anybody paranoid when even listening to a bit of it in the dark, but everything else is just an hour and a half of sex-driven teens running around and slowly, and I mean dreadfully slowly being picked off one by one by a murderer. Maybe back then it was horrifying to watch, but nowadays it's just one of those movies that you put on your TV, but don't really pay too much attention to anything besides the kills and the climax.

Review title: Highly derivative, boring and worst of all: Not scary.
Review_body: I can understand why people disagree with critics when it comes to horror films. Horror films are not complex pieces of art, thus do not need heavy critique. So on one of my friends recommendation me and a group of friends checked out the original "Friday the 13th".The only thing that scared us in the end was how this film became so iconic. It was strikingly similar to "Halloween" (although to be fair to Cunningham, that did inspire it), only with more unnecessary gore, and contained a villain that heavily resembled Norman Bates from "Psycho".The lack of scares was frustrating, due to the skill Cunningham obviously has. Any moments that could have been scary were quickly sacrificed for violence and gore. Cunningham deserves points for attempting to develop the characters, but in the end you really don't care about them in the slightest, which wouldn't matter if the film had built up suspense more prominently.

Alright. I just finished watching this movie, and I have to say that I was really disappointed. I've always heard that it was a classic, and that it was really scary. But it just wasn't. Never, at any point was I scared or creeped out. I don't remember any jump scenes. And the plot was nonexistent if that. But I think what really let me down was that I didn't care about any of the characters. And I'm not just saying that either, I really didn't care. None of them were even remotely interesting or unique. And some were just downright annoying. (I think maybe the director figured that out since the most annoying of the characters died off screen.) The only positive thing I can say about this movie is that I liked that we never saw the killer until the end. It reminded me of Halloween whenever we saw through the killers eyes. But I liked how this time we didn't know who the killer was. Overall though, I gotta say I was hoping for more. See, I'm just now starting to delve into the "Classic" horror genre, and after seeing this and Halloween, I'm a little worried about the rest of the films.

Any normal human being with insight can see that this film is nothing but a money-spender. Sorry, fans.0/10

Review title: Ki Ki Ki Ma Ma Ma
Review_body: The original Friday The 13th was the one that started it all. The world's first exposure to the infamous Camp Crystal Lake aka Camp Blood. It goes like this. Camp Crystal Lake, after being closed for a number of years is reopening. The Camp has been closed for so long due to a number of catastrophes such as the young boy Jason Voorhees drowning in the lake, cabins catching on fire, and (I almost forgot) tons of camp counselors being brutally slashed and murdered by a killer running loose in the camp. So when the camp is being reopened, its deja vu, the new camp conselors are in for it. The killer is back and is ready for more. This is the movie that started in all, the classic slasher series that has a total of 11 films to date. The movie is good, but don't expect a truly scary horror film. Its full of some tense moments, nice jumps, and gore, lots of gore. What it lacks is some decent acting (not very impressive). Still, any horror collection isn't complete if you don't have at least one Friday the 13th film, so this one is not to be missed.

When it comes to horror movie franchises, the first movie is usually the best. This is one of those. All the classic horror clichés are in this, yet they pull it off, probably cause it was pretty original at the time. If you like some cool and a few funny death scenes, then you will surely like this one. The effects and make up artists are great for the time, with none of that computerized crap that you see now days. This is surely a movie you watch at midnight with a nice blunt to let get you into the mood. The actors are also surprisingly good and the setting is great. A low budget horror film indeed and sometimes those are the best, as most horror fans already know. I loved this movie from the start and so should you. If not then oh well. I give it one thumb up and a bowl to go with it. Give it a shot if you got nothing to do and want to watch a classic.

This is the first of the 10 movie (as of now) series.This movie does not have the loony madman Jason Voorhees in it, no. It's his mother.This movie is probably the best suspense movie of all time. Waiting to find out who the killer is, and when she is revealed, you would probably not suspect it was her. The movie is full of gory deaths, great acting and a great storyline. A woman serial killer? Wow.The movie is all based on the events of the 1950s (not a true story) when the woman's child, Jason Voorhees, drowned in Crystal Lake. The woman's name is Pamela Voorhees. She goes insane, vowing to kill every counsellor in the Crystal Lake area. However, as I said when the killer is revealed, she is revealed to one character, who then chops her head off after a brutal fight between the two ladies.This movie is excellent. Not the best in the series, but awesome. This movie involved great acting, and some actors and actresses who would later go onto fame and fortune (such as Kevin Bacon who stars as Jack). The story is excellent, the acting is awesome, the whole idea rules. This movie is also one of THE best mystery and suspense movies of all time.Often imitated but never equalled, this movie will live on forever as the most shocking film of it's kind.

Review title: The perfect start to a very infamous horror franchise.
Review_body: The original Friday the 13th is my personal 2nd favorite in the series and it's a pretty damn good horror film too. With its iconic music, to loads of memorable scenes that will send shivers down your spine this movie has a pretty good variety of a slasher film, especially in 1980. This film is actually a pretty graphic horror film too, with 3 extremely iconic deaths. Plus the effects for some of the kills are down right amazing, and still hold up too this day. Sure, Jason isn't in the film but allow me to explain how that works. When Friday the 13th (1980) came out we had no idea who Jason was, while when A New Beginning came out we knew about Jason and not seeing this iconic character in that film sucked a little. And plus Pamela Voorhees is a great slasher killer and is pretty damn creepy too. However yes, this film has not aged well which held it back from a 10/10. Overall this film is great and somewhat perfect start to such an iconic movie series.9/10

This film is the greatest of all horror movies!  Even though some of the acting is horrible the plot is great, and the main characters are awesome. The film is about Camp Crystal Lake.  The counselors ignore the legend of a death curse until only two are left.  Alice (Adrienne King) and Bill (Harry Crosby).  When Bill goes to fix the emergency generator and doesn't return, Alice has to face the psycho Mrs. Voorhees (Betsy Palmer) alone.

Friday the 13th (1980)95 MIN- R **Camp Crystal Lake is affectionately known as `Camp Blood' and for good reason.  It's got a death curse.  And on Friday the 13th, the young, dumb, sex obsessed counselors are going to find that out `the hard way'.  Or should I say `the sharp way'!  This film has more suspense than your typical cardboard cutout imitation.  This is mostly due to an unsettling mood, creepy score by Harry Manfredini, and an isolated setting.  Cunningham directed this low budget project just to tie him over until a TV series, about soccer of all things, got picked up.  Adrienne King plays Alice Hardy, who is as convincing as a heroine as Roberto Begini is as a super hero. Rounding out the rest of the cast are Harry Crosby (Bing's son), Laurie Bartrum, Mark Nelson, Jeannie Taylor, and a very young Kevin Bacon in one of his first screen roles.  Robbi Morgan (wife of TV's 'Russian Roulette's Mark Wahlberg) makes a brief appearance as Annie, the hitchhiking cook, that is murdered in the woods.  The late NY character actor Walt Gorney appears briefly as Crazy Ralph, the drunk town loon.  The best offering in the film comes from Betsy Palmer who delivers a terrifying, bloodthirsty performance as Mrs. Voorhees, the grief stricken mother of a murdered boy from the camp, years ago.  The contrived premise of the film does not detract it from delivering the goods in a gory, grisly fashion.  Shot on location in New Jersey and inspired by Mario Bava's `Twitch of the Death Nerve' and Agatha Christie's `Ten Little Indians', Friday the 13th provides a somewhat organic and carnal look at psychotic behavior.  Tom Savini's gruesome special effects provide excellence in creating the unsettling frame of mind needed in a mindless film like this.  This box office smash paved the way for coutless rip-offs not to mention 9 sequels, a spin-off, and an ill-fated TV series by name only.  Associate produced by Steve Miner (billed as Stephen), the director of Part 2 and 3.  Appearing uncredited in here are cult horror actor Irwin Keyes as a busboy and Noel Cunningham (Producer of Jason X & Sean's son) as a customer in the café.

Review title: Good, but not the amazing classic it's held to be
Review_body: For a person who was born in the 2000's, I generally like a lot of 80s and 90s media. And I really enjoyed this film as a horror film, but I wouldn't really revisit it unless I was going to rewatch the series in full. The movie in between kills is generally very mundane and boring. And nothing really happens other than teenagers (you know what) and random conversations that don't matter a whole lot to the films plot. But all of that aside, the actual kills themselves are absolute classics of the series and impressive looking considering they only had a $550,000 budget. Betsy Palmer was great as Pamela Voorhees and was definitely the star of the movie. Her death is absolutely epic and badass, and one of the highlights of the film. Actually the entire final sequence is the best part of the film. So yeah, enjoyable as a horror movie, but boring at times.

So I thought I'd see the first one, and I didn't see no Jason at all. Well, I saw Jason, as a kid jumping out of the lake, but that might as well have been a dream. It's hard to believe that Friday the 13th is 31 years old! It's even harder to believe that a movie that pays no small debt to John Carpenter's Halloween as a source of influence (i.e. rip off) has stood the test of time as a unique horror film.Add to that the irony of Jason Voorhees, a character who hardly appears in this film, going on to become the quintessential slasher icon and you have a truly unique piece of film history in the form of a $500,000 horror flick.I honestly think you have to watch F13 with an audience to enjoy it fully. My friends and I usually have a "Friday the 13th" party when ever that particular calendar date rolls around, and it completely changes the experience of watching the movie. On it's own, it doesn't have nearly as much to offer the viewer. It's a perfect example of how the format in which you watch a film is every bit as important as the film itself.

Review title: Gotta see it on the BIG SCREEN
Review_body: For the past year I have been wading through a lot of these reviews with poor ratings and wonder why so many people are down on this movie. This type of movie(slasher)was designed to give you a roller-coaster ride, to scare you, period. There is little to no character development for a reason, so you don't get too bummed when someone is killed and zone out of the movie. This movie was designed to scare you, let you calm for a bit and then scare you again-hence the roller-coaster analogy. I was 18 when I saw this in 1980 in a real theatre with a screen larger than my 52" LCD, unlike today's multi-plexes. I walked out of there really scared and this movie left an indelible mark on me. Recently, I went to Blairstown, NJ on a Friday the 13th. The movie was shot in Blairstown and at a BoyScout camp just outside the town. The town plays the original movie every Friday the 13th in the historic theatre there. The theatre was packed and dark, the screen was good sized and the sound system was cranked up with tons of bass. I have to tell you, I have seen this movie probably 100 times since the first viewing back in 1980, but this scenario brought back why it was so effective back then. Watching a movie at home with a large flat screen TV is cool, but even with a really good surround sound system, it loses much of it's impact. The background score playing much louder than your surround permits, really keeps the mood frightening and the loud jarring noises become terrifying. Strangers screaming around you really makes a difference you can't get at home. I was surprised to see the audience scream wildly when Jason popped out of the lake at the end and I thought everyone knew the ending. So I say to you, if you ever get a chance, watch this movie at a real theatre with a BIG SCREEN, go. If you aren't a fan, it might change your mind or at least surprise you somewhat. Remember, rollercoasters aren't for everyone, but they are cool.

Review title: No spoilers here safe to read :)
Review_body: I recently watched the entire series of Friday the 13. Order: Part1, Part2, Part3, Part4, Part5, PArt6, Part7, Jason Goes to Hell, Jason X. I really enjoyed the entire series of the Friday the 13 collection except Jason X. It doesn't have to be watched to complete the series, it really had no connection to the others. Though it was more graphic (since it was the last created it had the most advanced technology), i felt it was corny and a waste of my time, for the most part, and Im 13 years old. The character is what makes me enjoy the series the most the way Jason is portrayed, but the movie itself is not very disgusting to me because the blood looked like ketcup! But for an old movie i give it a lot of credit. I was not scared, but there were a few occasional surprises. If you are my age or even 15 i recommend you are careful where and when you watch this movie because it is very graphic when it comes to nudity. I mean, they show everything! I was a little disgusted in that sense as well as the various "scenes" if you know what i mean. I think they over did that a bit. there were like 4 or 5 in each movie from the series. But overall watch these movies and share my love of JASON VORHEESE!

Friday the 13th is an excellent chiller. It's imaginative death scenes, and it's creepy setting are what make it so great. When I first saw the movie I stopped it when Neddy went into that creepy cabin after seeing someone on the porch, of course I was just a kid and that little bit scared the p*** out of me. The second time I watched it(as a teen)all the way through, I already knew who the killer was, but there were so many parts I hadn't seen it was like watching it for the first time and it scared the p*** out of me again. I jumped and literally yelled at the end when Jason jumps out of the lake, Kevin Bacon and his girlfriend's death shocked me beyond belief, and the killers voice freaked me out so much I admit, I turned away from the screen. This movie has come to be my favorite horror movie of all time, I still can't watch it without getting scared or at least getting that feeling in your stomach which moves up to your heart and makes it beat so fast that you can feel your heart in your mouth and then you jump and it returns to normal. It's a great feeling, and only this movie does that to me every time I watch it. Watch it you'll feel the same thing. It is very good, very suspenseful, and very scary. Even listening to that unforgettable music(Ch ch ch ah ah ah) can scare you enough. Try watching it without any shudders, it's impossible.

Many people hail this as a "cult classic". I am a fan of horror and cult movies like this, but personally, I recommend you skip this one. I have not not seen the others in the series, but if they are like this movie, I will not see it.This is the supposed plot: A group of teenage J.Cs at a mysterious camp site called "Camp Crystal Lake" are terrorized by an unknown killer (NOT Jason) who doesn't show his/her (I'll avoid spoilers, as if anyone should see it) face until the last ten minutes of the movie.But here's the more accurate plot: A group of horny kids sit around and a vague omen pops up here and there. This goes on for two thirds of the movie, and needless to say, it gets pretty boring. Suddenly, it's the end, and a killer with horrible acting runs in and a chase scene begins. The final battle isn't much too look out for, either. It basically consists of this: hero hits killer, killer is stunned, hero runs, killer jumps from behind a bush. Repeat.I'll give the movie this: the ending gives a complete feeling but leaves plenty of room for suspense.However, even if you are looking for a cheesy movie with unintentional laughs, I recommend you look somewhere else. This movie isn't so much "funny cheesy" as it is "boring cheesy". And "boring cheesy" isn't entertaining.I only recommend this movie if you are a total die-hard to the Jason series. But even then, you might not want to see it, because Jason only makes the briefest appearance at the end.

Watching this movie, you can't help but wonder just what made this movie turn into such a popular franchise, spawning 11 sequels, a remake, a comic series and a television show. Well, for starters, it jump started the Camp setting for horror movies and brought it into the mainstream. There were SO many camp-cult horror films in the 80's, it makes my head spin thinking about it. It's a good movie. It offers some cheap scares. The characters are pretty unrecognisable (with the exception of Kevin Bacon) and it's about as tense as shredded wheat. But you have to love it- awesome kills, a surprise ending, good effects, and an overall fear of spookiness. It's a classic, and while it may not be the best horror film ever, you can't turn it down.

I have seen this film a couple of times now and I have enjoyed it.I remember first seeing it in the early 80's and it was pretty frightening as I was only young at the time i am waiting for a book called crystal lake memories which i have heard is a good book i have one book called making Friday the 13th by David grove.Certain scenes gave me a bit of worry when I saw it back in the 80's.I have just seen Halloween for the first time and that is a good film the films music is quite scary at times.The characters are interesting as well and the locations are beautiful.We have a wooded area here outside Chelmsford which looks a bit like crystal lake woods so it is a bit haunting at times.

Okay, I do not see at all how Friday the 13th (1980) (or any of its endless sequels for that matter) can be considered a classic. Sure it gave use legendary killer Jason (actually it was Part II to be accurate) I know typically horror movies generally are not known for their great acting abilities, but come on. The only decent acting comes from Betsy Palmer, Adrienne King, and Kevin Bacon. Their is no significance to almost any of the characters and it seems as if they are just walking around waiting to be offed. The script is crappy and so is the directing. The movie only cares about blood and sex which in my opinion shows the signs of a "bad" horror movie. I mean look at some of the intelligent and clever horror movies that came around at the same time- "Halloween" "A Nightmare on Elm Street" etc. I also don't understand how this movie generated so many sequels that only get worse as the series pretty much drags on. Heres an interesting fact: Betsy Palmer said "the only reason I accepted the role was because I needed the money to get my car repaired" and in fact called the movie "a piece of s**t" I agree Betsy.Ugh. Horrible 1/10

Having been on a Friday binge lately, the time finally came to re-watch the original for perhaps the first time in a decade. Two things struck me immediately: 1. Kevin Bacon is in the movie and 2. how well it holds up. Granted, it's nearly 40 years old so the acting and effects aren't always the crispest, but overall it holds up very well, even better than some of the later installments. The movie also contains a sentimentality that the later ones do not; before the series turned into the Jason Voorhees hack-fest we all know and love, it was about a mother who loved her little boy so much she went mad. After the finale ending with the protagonist Alice decapitating Ms. Voorhees (praise Tom Savigni), we get Alice floating floating around in a canoe in Crystal Lake, while the sweet end theme by Harry Manfredini plays, until the infamous Jason-bursting-out-of-the-lake shot into Alice waking up in the hospital. We see some nice dialogue in the hospital as Alice and a police officer briefly talk about the events, ending with this:
Alice: "The boy, is he dead too?"
Police officer: "The boy?"
Alice: "The boy, Jason."
Police officer: "Jason?"
Alice: "The one who attacked me, the one who pulled me underneath the water."
Police officer: "Ma'am, we didn't find any boy."
Alice: "Then he's still there..."
cue a zooming-in shot of Crystal lake into end credits while the melancholic end theme plays again, highlighting the sadness of the little boy who drowned in the lake all those years ago. I got close to shedding a tear here. This piece of dialogue is also a brilliant foreshadowing of what was to come. 
Overall, a well done tragic slasher which by all means deserves to be viewed as a classic in the horror genre.

Review title: For those who like mindless slashers
Review_body: There's no denying the legacy this movie has left behind in pop culture. Having said that, this movie is quite below average even for its time.The acting feels cheesy and forced for the most part, excluding some scenes towards the end of the movie. The plot is very basic and the movie feels really shallow. The movie doesn't explore or build up the characters, they are there to be killed. If you don't build up the characters of the victims or the killers, I'm left wondering why do I care about what's gonna happen to anyone.Music, atmosphere and overall sound effects are pretty good. I feel like they could have done much more with the setting other than having most of the teens die in the cabins. Of course taking into account the time this was released, the kills were quite good.This is a movie for people who enjoy mindless slasher movies and "fun" kills. I'm not one of those people, but I can see the appeal for other people.
A CLASSIC. It has good kills and good makeup but it's very slow. it's ok, not the best, not the worst in the franchise.

Possibly the scariest film I've ever seen, Friday The 13th is the kind of movie that you show to people who don't know anything about horror films. After they see this, they know what they are about.  Best watched late at night in darkness, especially with a storm outside.  Even though the Jason most well-known (the mask-wearing, nearly invincible one) never shows, he does make a drop-in at the end of the movie as a little boy.  That scene with the canoe gave me nightmares when I first saw it as a little boy.Overall, I highly recommend this movie to ANYONE WHO LIKES MOVIES. Obviously if you like horror films then you've already seen it.  The rest of the Friday The 13th Series does not live up to this one, but most of them aren't terrible; Part 6 is a great one if you like fast action and some humor.  The only ones I'm disappointed in are 5 and 8.

Review title: A horrendous film of terror, gore, and suspense that never loses its flair.
Review_body: Despite the eight sequels that were spawned over the following twenty years, perhaps none of them had quite the same effect on the horror genre than the original film, Friday the 13th.  Believed by fans and critics alike to be one of the pioneers of the modern horror genre, Friday the 13th contained a horrendous atmosphere of suspense and despair like no other film of its time, with its terrifying intensity and creative murder sequences never failing to please.Camp Crystal Lake has been silent for nearly twenty years, due to several viscious murders which remain unsolved.  Numerous attempts to reopen the camp have been thwarted with mysterious fires and tainted water.  Now, the camp's new owner and seven young counselors are preparing for another reopening despite the claims of a "death curse" by local residents.  The story is regarded as mere craziness until Friday the 13th, when one by one each of the counselors is stalked and brutally murdered by an unseen killer. Who is responsible for the murders, and what is their involvement the the drowning of a young boy decades earlier?The film features suspense like none other, as scenes can often feature several minutes of silence, despite the killer's obvious presence.  No two murder sequences are alike, as the young counselors are stabbed, maimed, impaled, slashed and axed in this gory romp.  In the end there is one survivor and an intense chase sequence with an unforgettable ending. However, just when you think it's over, the film strikes back with a terrifying ending sequence that the viewer will never forget.  If you have no idea it's coming, you may need to excuse yourself to the restroom momentarily.Although the Friday the 13th series is chock full of sequels, perhaps none of them can compare to the sheer intensity and suspense of the original. Unlike the later films, the key of the original is its psychological terror, not just the physical blood and gore.  This film is worth a late night viewing and most likely worth purchasing.  Truly an integral piece to the modern horror puzzle.

Review title: Good make up effects but film is disappointing and dull.
Review_body: My first encounter with this most infamous of slasher films was on late night television when I was about 12 years old.  It seemed to me, at the time, to be just about the coolest thing I had ever seen.  Now at 24 I have a somewhat less than affectionate view of it.  So what has changed in the last 12 years, not a whole lot in terms of the genre of films that I appreciate the most, except for the fact that I have had the dissatisfying experience of sitting through parts 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9 in various stages of censorship.  The quality, or lack there of, of part one hardly justifies the enormous investment that must have gone into producing it's many numbered clones.  Still somebody, like me, paid to see them I guess.  The originals cult status I am a loss to explain.  Set on friday the 13th (of course) the story centres around a group of nubile camp councellors out in the woods for a weekend of booze and bonking.  But from the opening minutes of the film it appears frighteningly obvious that not many of them are going to make it out alive as someone, who I won't reveal here, starts hacking through the supporting cast. It would be great to say that there is something, anything, in this film that separates it from the rest of it's kind, but there simply isn't.  It owes more than a little to 'Halloween', it's stalk an slash melodrama just isn't original.  There is on thing I will say however, and that is that Tom Savini's grizzly make-up effects do make the grade, even by todays standards, freeze frame them if you like, they are pretty flawless (my personal favourite:  Kevin Bacon's bed side skewering). The film is dull, and pretty disappointing, badly acted and flatly directed I can't help but get the feeling the Sean S. Cunningham has just yelled "action" at every cut.  There is one thing you can count on though and that is that somewhere in the world on this most superstitious of dates some T.V. network will hash it up and run it again for old times sake.  If you find this to be the case, by all means watch it and watch out for that final fright, it's a doozy. In my discussions with friends 'Friday the 13th' comes up quite a bit.  I do admire it on some level I certainly admire it's staying power but I don't find it entertaining and I don't go out of my way to watch it.  Sitting alone on a dusty video store shelf it waits for a new generation a horror addicts to find and who knows, maybe in another 12 years I will see it again, late one rainy night the glass in the opening titles will shatter and I will once again be reminded of what it was like to be a 12 year old kid with the run of parents video machine.

Review title: The Best Slasher Flick I Have Ever Seen!
Review_body: Unlike the modern horror movie killers of the 90's, Mrs. Voorhees, the sagacious and brutal killer in this flick, is creepy. Betsy Palmer did an incredible job in brilliantly transfiguring herself into this--should I rightly say--satanic killer. Hearing the spooky music by Harry Manfredini is enough to scare you even without having seen the movie. Proof of this is that I, being a musician, am able to play the music to this movie by ear. When I played it for my class in chorus they told me to "stop or they would have nightmares". The acting, though admittedly boring, is very realistic, not exaggerated as in the 90's slasher flicks. The murders--if you get the uncut version--are no joke. They are frighteningly realistic and can be pretty gruesome as well as horrifying to a high degree! Most of us say this movie set the standard for modern horror, but also remember who made this movie horror--Mrs. Voorhees. She can, indeed, be called the "mother of horror" because she set the standards and everyone else follows in awe. My regrets is that they did not make another "Friday the 13th" film with her in it.Please give this movie a chance. I believe you will love it. My friends played it in class at school, and they loved it death. Everyone was walking around school chanting "Ch ch ch ch ch ch ha ha ha ha ha ha", and they raved about this movie as if it were a blockbuster hit! You may not like it that much, but it may impress you.

Review title: Friday the 13th - not exactly Oscar material.

However, his budget was low, so he skipped the horror film idea and went on to direct Friday the 13th, which became a huge success. Review title: Defines a new genre of Horror
Review_body: The 'Exorcist' was unreal; 'Texas Chainsaw Massacre' was campy; 'Halloween' played upon childish fears of one night out of the year...'Friday the 13th' could, and (if you read the paper,) to some extent, does happen all the time which makes it all the more terrifying. Now, some 20 years later, studios are still trying to frighten people by using the same type of "Shock-Special Effects(fx) used not originally, but used better than, anyone else before or since. That is why I gave this movie a 10.

Although a Halloween clone, Friday the 13th is a whole different monster. The twist at the end with Mrs. Voorhees was something I actually didn't expect, and Tom Savini does a great job, as always, with the effects, and Final Girl Alice is a good character. Not a flawless movie, but it's a good one nontheless

I HATE it when ppl say its just a ripp off of the Psycho score. Harry Manfredini wrote the score to Friday, NOT Bernard. The Score to Friday includes dodeacaphonic atonal techniques, aleatoric music, non-functioning coloristic use of harmony, vocal and percussive effects, prepared piano, and synths. I DO NOT remember hearing that in the score to Psycho!!!!!

Friday the 13th I thought is the BEST in the entire Friday the 13th series. After 10 sequals (including Freddy VS Jason) this is the one that actually stands up after 25 years. I mean granted that seeing Jason killing people in 9 movies is alot of fun. But it gets tired and dragged down after awhile. But the first is origanal, scary, has the best effects, cool characters, and two killer endings.The film is pretty straight forward when it comes to plot. A summer camp has a terrible tragedy. A young boy drownds. The camp counselors who are supposed to be watching this young boy are having sex. And someone gets a little p***ed off.Ahead we go to present day. Where the camp is readying the camp for re-opening. The town is against this. They say the place is cursed and no one should enter. There have been murders, fires, water poisoning. But of course no one listens and all plans go forward to reopen the camp. But then someone is stalking the camp counselors and killing them off one by one. In cool, gross, nasty ways. You gotta love it!So I have to say everytime I watch this film its like I am watching it for the first time. I never get tired of it. I love everything about the movie. Even the actors don't annoy me like they did in the later sequals. And this movie is scary and has alot of great suspense and chilling moments.
But the best part in the finale. Granted the last 30min is then ending so it kind of drags out. But its our heroine against villan. In about a 20min chase scene that is great. And then seeing the killer's head chopped off was a HUGE shock and was awesome. So just when I think the film has ended like a predictable slasher should. Another chain of events happen that scared me and got me going 10 times more then seeing the killer's head chopped off.Trust me this movie kicks ass! And if your tired of seeing the same old Jason walking and killing people. Come back to its roots and watch the orignal. It might not have Jason in a hockey mask. But it still is a classic and a great horror movie. **** out of ****

Review title: Everything you need to know about Friday the 13th
Review_body: Friday THE 13TH (1980)death listBarry - stabbed in abdomen Claudette - killed off screen (assumed that she's stabbed in neck) Annie - throat slit with hunter's knife Ned - throat slit Jack - back of throat impaled with spear Marcie - axed in face Mr. Christy - knifed in abdomen Brenda - killed off screen (assumed death by archery weapons) Mrs. Voorhees (killer) - decapitated with machetesynopsisA young boy by the name of Jason Voorhees drowns to death in 1957 when the two counselors responsible for his safety snuck off to have sex. In 1958, the two teens who were responsible for his death were viscously killed by an unknown killer. Years later, bizarre murders take place when teen counselors fix up Camp Crystal Lake, re-bought by a man named Steve Christy. The killer is unknown until the sole survivor meets them in a heated scuffle.This film is widely acclaimed for it's creative yet horrifying murder sequences.

Review title: serial killer stalks co-ed camp counselors
Review_body: This movie gets a Vote of 10 from me for shear brilliance.Victor Miller's Friday the 13th(1980) combines a more gory Ten Little Indians style mystery with the darkness and suspense of Carpenter's Halloween(1978). Friday stands on it's own merit as the first serial killer horror movie with a high body count. Another contributing factor to the endurable greatness of this film is the fact that the motive behind the murders is saved until near the end. The character development is subtle, but present. There is Mr. Christy, who wants to make the camp a success after taking it over from his family. He has an attraction to his right-hand employee, Alice, who may have to go back to California to take care of some personal business. There is a love triangle of sorts involving Kevin Bacon's character, his girlfriend and their best friend,Ned. Local crazy,Ralph tries to warn the lot to no avail and the murders happen. And Betsy Palmer as Mrs. Vorhees is the would-be scene stealer were it not for the formidable performance of Adrianne King who hasn't done much since this movie and it's sequel probably because of the association to her character. The population of this movie with people who seem real, not too melodramatic makes a wonderful partnership with Tom Savini's special effects artistry.This is the most realistic stuff I've ever seen on film. The soundtrack is unforgettable. The name of the composer is right on the tip of my tongue, but alas, it escapes me.The stories told in the sequels really don't hold up against the first one. I am more sympathetic to the killer(s) in the earlier movies as tragic victoms of grief rather than being evil. This less-dramatic plot device makes the movie all the scarier.There is a sequel, or rather a re-imagining of Friday the thirteenth in the works. I hope that through a multitude of sequels the producers have learned not to tamper with a winning formula.I'm Cecil Miller. Thank you for reading.

Review title: You're doomed, you're all doomed! (Crazy Ralph)
Review_body: You'll definitely be doomed if you watch this poor excuse for a "classic" horror movie. I love horror movies, but I don't care for thisone at all. The characters are forgettable and you simply don't care if any of them live or die. It is a knock-off of some great flicks like Halloween and Psycho. The movie was nearly unbearable to watch.Halloween and Psycho still hold up today as some very frightening movies, where as this movie is nearly laugh out loud stupid. The movie uses the camera shot of the killer's view, which was used in Halloween. The killer is a crazy mother who's obsessed about her dead son (he's not really dead, he's Jason), Norman Bates reversed. It's not an original movie. Whoever decided to make this movie must of thought.. Hey let's have a bunch of rebellious, horny teens learn their lesson by getting massacred. When a movie is mostly remembered for its gory death sequences, you may have a problem. Tom Savini, the special make-up effects artist, does a great job with the death sequences, but if you want to see himat his finest see another movie that is a classic horror Dawn of the Dead (1978). Don't waste your time on this poorly acted, directed, written piece of crap.

Review_body: This was a good horror movie in 1980 but in 2003, it's slow and definitely not scary.  Watched this for the first time with my teenage nieces and we were bored and disappointed.  We're fairly new to the genre so we're no experts, however, I do not recommend it for anyone looking for a scare. We enjoyed Nightmare on Elm St. more. Friday the 13th may have terrible dialog, mediocre actors, and a story line that has been mimicked time and time again, but it has one thing going for it: it is so damn entertaining. Anyone who's familiar with the character of Jason Vorhees but not the specifics is in for a surprise for this one. Although the whole bunch of characters are pretty one dimensional, there are some scenes that are pretty stand out. One particularly stands out, because it is the first "modern" encounter with the killer. The innocent, naive teenage girl getting a ride to the oh-so famous Camp Crystal Lake. I found it particularly terrifying when I first saw it because it's a large amount of terror- during the daytime. Many movies always stick to night time horror, but Friday the 13th is terrifying whenever it wants. It's also particularly funny to see a young Kevin Bacon. Yes, we may have seen and heard the movies/stories of camp counselors getting knocked off, but Friday the 13th made a name for itself. I must give a generous amount of props to that music and other noises, and it deservingly is cemented in pop culture(cheecheecheeahhahhahh.) This is a very entertaining movie, and although it may not be Grade A, it sure as hell can be as entertaining as one(at the worst a Grade C.)
