Review title: For those of you unlucky enough to watch this movie...
Review_body: Once in a while a movie comes along that is so terribly, terribly bad that you could almost cry for the lost time you gave to it. Angry and frightened, you feel like you should tell someone (anyone!) what happened, because it feels like a crime has been committed. But who would listen? Only you and the movie know what happened, and the movie's not telling. Such a movie is the original Friday the 13th. By rights, this movie should have been good. Obviously I wasn't expecting a Citizen Kane or a Gone With the Wind, but when one considers that Friday the 13th has spawned eleven various sequels, mash-ups, and remakes which, taken together as a franchise, have grossed nearly $500,000,000 worldwide, that might raise the expectations slightly. Those numbers would make any movie studio proud, and such a cinematic juggernaut has to be based on an incredibly strong foundation, right? The answer is "not so much," actually. Watching the first film, one gets the sense that the sequels are basically unplanned pregnancies that just sort of happened, and not the result of careful planned franchise-hood.Truly, I gave it every chance to succeed. I even coaxed it like a puppy, or a tiny sprout: "Come on, little guy, you can do it." Guess it just wasn't my lucky day, but isn't that the point?Why is this overrated "classic" so bad, you ask? Well, it has almost no plot or characters, and no real sense of purpose. At all. Really. It just sort ofis. I swear there is a five-minute scene of a girl making coffee, and that about sums up the film. Clearly, it was a great directorial decision to establish beverage preference before such superfluous things as motivation and personality. As a result of such ground-breaking work, the pace of this movie is somewhere between amateur golf and colonoscopy, tending towards the latter. That's how I love my horror movies; you never know what's going to happen next. Will she use one teaspoon of sugar or two? Will she stir clockwise or counter-clockwise? Oh, I can't take it! That's the kind of edge-of-your-seat, beaded-sweat-on-the-brow tension you can only get at the nursing home during naptime. And the best part is, after all that wonderfully taut buildup, you just know you're going to get to see another fantastically realistic, squeal-inducing death, delivered by a master thespian. It has been my experience that in most movies, the actors are the ones who usually act. Interestingly, actors were not required for this one. As a result, most of the killings look like people having painful gas or pretending to pass a kidney stone while trying to recall masterful dialogue lifted from Bazooka Joe wrappers. Why this film didn't win any Oscars is one of the great, enduring mysteries of Hollywood. Still, despite its nearly-complete cinematic insouciance, some ardent fans defend this movie ferociously, citing its "iconic" appeal and cult status. They rebuff criticism that Friday the 13th is a rip-off of superior films such John Carpenter's Halloween or the Italian-made Reazione a catena among others. Instead, they rally behind its "old-school" reliance on the audience's imagination, and the feeling of atmospheric dread it inspires in the viewer. I'm all for imagination, but I'm not going to imagine the whole movie, because the director lacks the originality and skill to do so himself. Second, just because Friday the 13th is "old-school" and not explicitly violent and gory does not give it license to suck. Hitchcock was old school, and his movies definitely inspire dread. If you want to go even more "old-school," Tod Browning's Dracula has zero gore but enough atmospheric dread for twenty movies. Even Roger Corman does dread better. There was more dread in Judge Dredd.My point is, this movie is weak on almost every level, and the fact that it has been so successful leaves me scratching my head. Despite all of that, (here comes the surprise ending) I can't wait to watch part II

I would like to begin by saying that this is one of the greatest films of all time, not just horror/slasher films. What Sean Cunningham did in 1980 would be impossible today: turned a tiny budget into the first of 11 films that are known worldwide. Some may argue that it was just cashing in on the success of other previous horror films, including "The Texas Chain Saw Massare" (1974) and "Halloween" (1978), but let's remember that neither of those were at all similar to Friday the 13th. Also, classics such as "The Evil Dead" (1981) and "A Nightmare on Elm Street" (1984) came after it was made. Friday the 13th was completely independent, and should be required viewing for all film-making students and actors.

Friday the 13th, by Sean S. Cunningham. This movie tells the story of a group of camp counselors who are stalked and murdered by an unknown woman whilst attempting to reopen the camp.Writer Victor Miller claims to have taken a crash course in horror writing when he wrote "Friday the 13th", as both he and Sean were in dire need of a success and saw that the horror genre had potential, but knew next-to-nothing about it. Taking "Halloween" as a model, Miller crafted his story about the spine-chilling night where a group of teens end up isolated and at the mercy of an unknown serial killer, with the sole purpose of making a successful horror movie. And he succeeded, as he took the many different elements that would create the "slasher rules" and turned the simple and derivative plot into a roller-coaster of horror, with the perfect mix of fun, horror and mystery that just keeps getting better and better until it reaches the climatic finale.The 80's were practically a golden decade for the horror genre, since the roundup of many 70's horror flicks dealt with similar plots and concepts. We had quite a few paranormal movies, like "The Omen" and "The Exorcist", and then we had mythological horror movies. Things relating to zombies, vampires and werewolves. In fact, "Halloween" and "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" were two of the very few serial killer movies at the time. "Friday The 13th" was released in May of 1980, and eventually paved the way for many other slasher and serial killer movies like "The Nightmare On Elm Street" series. Since "Friday The 13th" was released in the summer of 1980, this was worth seeing. The filmmakers of Friday the 13th were always the first to admit just how much of the film was inspired by Halloween, like the faceless murder machine, the promiscuous teens and the prophet of doom – with Halloween it was Dr. Loomis, here it is local soothsayer, Crazy Ralph. But whereas Carpenter's film was a well-crafted movie with professional cinematography, Friday the 13th was a cheap exploitation film directed by a businessman. However, despite its technical flaws, there are many aspects to enjoy with this movie that are guaranteed to entertain. The cast are likable, especially Crosby and Bartram, who portray their characters as genuinely pleasant individuals. Morgan, too, makes her role sympathetic, with her passion for the camp evident. Whilst Bacon and Taylor are fairly generic, Nelson adds a touch of humor as the joker which would then go on to become a staple of the genre.Friday the 13th was also a landmark film for Tom Savini. He further proved his uncanny ability to get the most effect out of the least financial backing. Savini will go down in history as one of the greats in special effects - and Friday the 13th helped him prove his mastery of the art.One thing this movie handles well is pacing. It isn't too slow, it doesn't move too fast and it's not that hard to follow. It takes about twenty minutes to get to an actual murder scene, which gives the movie enough time to flesh out some characters without taking too long to add unneeded exposition or add too much than what is needed. I can only think of one scene where this is negated. The ending scene with Mrs. Voorhees rushed a little too quickly for my tastes. Not so much in the action, but in terms of the dialog and the story. I rushed itself just a bit, but that didn't ruin the scene itself. Other than that, I feel like the movie did a good job of focusing on what was really needed, while fleshing out the murder scenes in an orderly fashion. That's something that makes a horror movie very good.The dialog can be very good, very awkward or just strange. Good moments can come from the characters we don't really see too often, or the characters we only see once or twice. The trucker gives a fairly good speech on how Camp Crystal Lake is not a happy place to be, the diner waitress was very sweet and kinda nice to listen to and I feel like Alice Hardy's character reacted like any person in this situation would react. In terms of awkward and strange dialog displays, I had a very hard time understanding Steve when he was introduced. A shirtless guy with a mustache and red bandanna around his neck hitting on Hardy in the way he did might not have been the best approach in hindsight. Maybe slap on a polo shirt and then we'll see. The police officer was a little strange as well. This all might be due to this movie being a little bit dated, so we tend to look back on dialog from older movies and laugh at how strange they are. In this movie's case, the teenagers didn't really feel like regular teenagers. They had moments where they didn't quite speak or act like they were teens. Mark Nelson was probably the better example of how a sarcastic teenager would behave. Although, with this in mind, the actors themselves displayed a decent amount of emotion in their performances. The acting isn't spectacular, but they did well with the script they were given. The story is exceedingly well crafted and works greatly with the pace. While the story may be somewhat basic, it's the execution that really pays off. Not only is it well crafted, but it's overall fun to watch, and it's very pivotal to the horror genre, and without it we wouldn't have some of the greats that we are now familiar with in the horror category. There's a reason it spawned 10 sequels and a re-imagining. Overall, as long as there's a Friday the 13th, the tale of Camp Blood will always continue.

Review title: One of the Finest in the Genre.
Review_body: To properly review a movie like "Friday the 13th" you have to compare it to other films in it's genre. To try to compare horror/slasher films to "The Godfather" or "Citizen Kane" you'll come up with a 1 out of 10 every time. So here goes...As far as the "Slasher" genre goes "Friday the 13th" is one of the most entertaining and innovative films of all time. It has everything fans of the genre like: Suspense, Attractive Teens, A few laughs, A bit of Campiness, a bit of Gore, and a very memorable and creepy musical score. Much like "Halloween", the first "Friday" film features one of the stronger plot lines in the series. It also spawned a whole sub genre of slasher flicks. The "Psychopath in the Woods" thing has been imitated time and time again since the release of this film. Where "Halloween" made people feel uneasy about the suburbs, "Friday" made the woods an uncomfortable place to be.This films also has some of the better performances in the series, mostly from the younger actors in the film. A few of the older actors' performances come of as forced and unnatural (I believe overacting is the term). The script isn't bad with a few cheesy lines here and there, but all in all it's pretty good.So, when all is said and done, this movie is quite good, one of the best in the genre. I'd give it a 7.5 out of 10 when compared to other horror films. I recommend this film as well as parts II and IV of the series to moderate horror fans. The hardcore fans have already seen them all.

Although I did not have a familiarity with horror movies at the time, I was indeed swept away by Friday the 13th. All the elements incorporated such as casting and plots were well thought-out. The reasons why I loved Friday the 13th so much was because the suspense was killing me in a very good way. I felt like the killer would strike at any moment. When Ned happened to wander upon the killer while walking at the lakeside, I caught a glimpse at the build of the killer and noticed how big and scary the killer looked even though you couldn't see the killer's face. Suspense was employed throughout the movie and was very effective indeed. The middle of the movie was suspenseful too as the killer really begun the killing spree at that point. The character Brenda's idea of fun seemed to be quite interesting as well. The ending was phenomenal in my opinion as the revelation of the killer slightly shocked me but nevertheless, the motive behind the killing was what spawned the many sequels that followed Friday the 13th. When the seemingly dead Jason Voorhees made his appearance in the couple of minutes in Friday the 13th, I cringed in fear and was swept away by its excellence. My personal recommendation would be that anyone who is just settling into the horror genre please watch Friday the 13th. That movie inspired me to continue to watch many other slashers such as Halloween and Slumber Party Massacre. Thanks for reading :) My rating: 10/10

Review title: Dated, But Still Worthwhile and Entertaining
Review_body: There are some movies that just standout and become timeless classics most consider the best the film industry can offer. This does indeed standout, and is a "classic" for the horror genre and those who continue to watch it even though they could reproduce the script from memory. It offers some good moments of shock, but allows the core and supporting characters to act as normal as possible, even when some are not always "normal". When elements of terror start to creep in, one can become more mindful and fearful, knowing that someone or something is out there and the antics of the characters we still see separates one from fear momentarily, but you know there is more to happen. It does take awhile to start up, but then increases steadily from there. It does not reveal too much and almost seems to let you want to try and guess who the killer is. Some of the end results are quite memorable, and like many movies, the music seems to make all the bit of difference. Some elements are probably dated, such as the occasional reference to classic actors/actresses and the idea of seeing a lack of now-modern technology is too much to bare for some. Either way, don't let its age get the best of you. If you're into fear and scares while coming out generally pleased with the results, give this a shot.

For all my life I had heard about Friday The 13th, and finally decided to watch it. I researched it, and found out that Jason isn't the killer! I didn't want to watch it after finding that out, so I never watched, until a long while later when it came on TV, but I hated it. I thought it was slow and boring, and didn't deserve its praise.Then I realized that maybe it was slow because it was on TV and had commercials, and had most violence taken out, so I gave it another chance, and loved it.What a movie! I think what makes it scarier than the rest is that this one could really happen. There's no monsters or magic or zombie, its about a serial killer that could exist, much like Halloween.The characters were likable and seemed real, and I was impressed by Adrienne King's performance of Alice. It looked as if she was really in danger, and that she was really scared. It didn't look like it was acting at all, much like Alex Vincent's performance in Child's Play. I even felt sorry for Annie when she died. Everything seemed so real.This movie didn't need buckets of gore to be scary. Most of the deaths are off screen or are in a first-person point of view, which adds to the suspense, making it scary. The killer, Mrs. Voorhees, stays hidden until the very end, where she reveals that she killed everyone, and that Jason was her son. Another thing I love about this movie is the music. The ki ki ki, ma ma ma is just awesome, and adds to the suspense. And the scary fast music sounds like its from Old Yeller, but as awesome as it is, we don't care.The clichés used are just awesome, like when Annie trips over three times, and hiding in stupid places, and how sex equals death, and how the good girl lives.Overall, Friday The 13th is just a classic slasher and I'm glad I gave it a second chance. Everything is just awesome about it, and the acting is really convincing. From start to finish, this movie is awesome! 8/10, and definitely give it watch if you're a true horror fan!

Review title: One Of The Films That Started It All
Review_body: The First Installmant of the popular Friday The 13th series. With the Producing skills of Sean S. Cunningham ( Last house on the left,House) and the special effect talents of Tom Savini (dawn of the dead,Dusk Till Dawn) Paramount was able to release a cult classic that still scares audiences today. Although the plot outline is slightly from cliché, the gore and suspense will keep you on your feet and wanting more. A couple of young camp counselors try to re-open and clear the name of the infamous Camp Crystal Lake i.e "Camp Blood" In doing so the camp counselors are picked off one by one and brutally murdered by an unknown culprit. Some of the horrifying slainings include an axe being driven through a young girls head and a spear protruding from a mans neck.Although the acting was very dry the special effects make up for all the perks and flaws in the movie All in all Friday the 13th is a classic slasher film that could be watched over and over again....best recommended for rainy nights with a girl or guy....

Review title: Just like Jason this movie will never die.
Review_body: We all know the rules Sex=death Drinking and Drug=death. Now don't you think after all these years the counselors would learn something? No thats what makes this Low budget independent film a true Classic. Back in 1980 we were just getting settled into the Horror/Slasher genre(please note Halloween 2 years earlier and Psycho 20 years earlier. Friday the 13th was a major boost to the slasher genre. All the different Clichés especially POV Shots. This movie brought out the scared little kid in all of us. This movie also Defined the psychopathic killer we all know as Jason Voorhees. If there ever becomes 13 wonders of the world Friday the 13th should be the thirteenth wonder No Pun Intended!

When going into a movie so vamped by people and critics, I could not help but expect nothing but the best. However, the movie is not at all what I expected it to be. Now this is both a good thing and a bad thing. For when someone watches a Friday movie, they want the blood/gore (which I got) but there was absolutely no Jason Voorhees. I wanted to see some hockey masked monster just ripping someone in half with a machete, but I was severely disappointed.Plus, the movie was very slow, not a lot of movement in the film which makes it drag on and on. There were great jump scares but this is a movie that I was greatly disappointed in.

Review title: The Grandaddy of all Slaughter Flicks
Review_body: The one that started it all, and no sequel has ever been able to match it. Several camp counselors attempt to reopen Camp Crystal Lake, closed for many years due to a supposed "curse", only to be killed one by one in gruesome detail.The plot is a little thin and the characters don't really come off as anything more than just objects for the killer's sharp objects, but this remains groundbreaking in many areas.Director Sean S. Cunningham makes excellent use of the dark, isolated camp location, making it seem like a place where there is no escape, or any chance of outside help. Of course, he would not be able to do this without the help of Harry Manfredini's masterful music score, which really heightens the tension. Tom Savini's gore effects are outstanding as well, some of the best he has done.The cast, which includes a young Kevin Bacon, gives decent performances, though most of them get very little showcase before they are brutally slaughtered. Adrienne King, however, is likable as the heroine; convincingly scared, yet resourceful. Capping off with a brilliant double climax, and you got yourself the Graddaddy of all slaughter flicks, along with "Halloween".**** out of ****
